Brief Specifications & particulars of the Building

Description A log building, dovetailed at corners, shingle roof flumed on the inside with ceiling.

The building measures on the outside 18 x 24. The whole is well chinked and plastered. The building has a mansard roof with pediment windows on East side, & a square iron safe & chimney.

The building is entered by two doors, one on the South side & the other on the North. Both doors are of Cedar extra strong panelled.

The Inside.

Downstairs are two rooms & pantry

(1) Dining & General living room - with two windows, one on the South side & the other on the East, measuring 17 x 10.

(2) Kitchen: Containing one window on the East side a lavatory & lockers measuring 17 x 10.

(3) Pantry under the staircase with shelves. The staircase is very solid placed between the partitions of the Dining Room & Kitchen. There is a door with lock at the bottom.

Upstairs are 2 rooms a Dormitory & a Masters Room containing linen closet. The partitions between the two are formed by the walls of the staircase which are not carried higher than two feet above the flooring, thus allowing a better ventilation.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo relative to the Boarding School being erected on the Lance Reserve and to state in reply that at the two Lance day schools there has always been a difficulty in securing any thing like a satisfactory attendance, and a desire having been expressed on the part of the Church Authorities to endeavour to overcome this difficulty by establishing a Boarding School, and closing one of our two day schools, the Indians promised that in the event of provision being made for their children as boarders a number would attend.

This appeared to be the only

means of overcoming their prejudices.

I was asked if in the event of a suitable building being erected to keep the children as boarders whether a grant might be expected, and I promised that on the completion of a suitable building the Department would contribute £100 towards the cost of the erection provided it cost double what the Department would be called to pay. The building is now finished and is worth about £300.

The nice to be given to ensure the maintenance of the children will be pictures and clothing etc., most of which they would otherwise require even if not otherwise attending school.

The building being such a good one and the authorities anxious by enlarging it, I would ask the Dept to authorize a grant of £200 instead of £100, as it will I think be more particularly well expended.

November 15th 1893

Sir,

With reference to your letter No 044 dated the 1st instant, I beg to inform you that eight parents or guardians have signed an agreement to give up their children for an indefinite time.

Six girls and two boys are now ready to attend the boarding school when school room is provided and the rest of the children can be obtained without much difficulty. I do not think it is advisable to ask for more of the children until a new school is provided.

A matron for the girl's school has been obtained by the mission and the girls will be taken in as soon as school room is provided.

You will see there is nothing speculative about obtaining the pupils, all that is required is a school house that will accommodate an increased number; it would be unsafe to put any more in the old school house.

I am Sir

Your obedient Servant

26th April 1893

To Deputy Minister

I have examined the plans and specifications of the proposed additions to the Sarcee Indian Residential Boarding School. These additions consist of a main addition one and a half stories high 24' x 30' - a lean-to 12' x 22' and a cellar 20' x 10'. The total cost including £194.50 property chargeable to the original building was £1364.10.

The plan, specifications and cost appear to be quite satisfactory. It is not evident whether the whole of the additions mentioned in connection with the enlargement of the Mission house are included in the work for which is stated to have cost £241.95. This would not be exorbitant for the girls dormitory alone. I think the sketch specification and cost may be accepted as satisfactory without any question.

The Girls' House accommodation

1. Additions have been made to the Mission House to accommodate not more than 12 girls at the entire cost of a lady in England.

2. On the eastern side, a lean-to of lumber only (12 x 26) has been added for a dormitory.

3. The walls are of 5 thicknesses of lumber with tar paper.

4. The whole is ceiled carefully.

5. A substantial concrete foundation underlies the whole.

6. It is connected with a long well built room (9 x 30) on the North side, & outside the outside has an entrance from outside (protected by a porch) at the North east corner.

7. The room is lighted by 3 windows.

8. It has a large cupboard.

9. It is heated by means of a register in connection with the Mission furnace.

10. The large room referred to in No. 6, is to answer the double purpose of a kitchen & dining room for the girls. It is lighted by 2 windows.

11. To avoid the children meeting with the Indians in a general way, a special...
room has been erected adjoining the Missionary study at the North West corner.

12. The object of arranging for the site in this way above specified, has been for the sake of economy, & with a view to close supervision.

Specifications as to Boys' Home.

1. The old building (18x24) - of which particular have already been furnished to the Department - has been covered on the outside with Clapboarding.

2. The original Dining-room has been divided into a pantry & store-room & a laundress, bath-room (with cook stove & the usual fittings).

3. The Kitchen remains as it was.

4. The original front entrance has been removed & a window has taken its place.

5. Upstairs, the original Dormitory, has been turned into a Linen & Clothes-room, with passage way leading to new dormitory. A good supply of shelves have been placed in the rooms.

6. The large addition (24x30) has been affixed to the West side of the original building, & doors have been placed in the centre (one upstairs, one below) to connect the buildings.

7. The addition is entirely of lumber (without logs) & the walls are of 3 thicknesses, with tarpaper.

8. The building is 14 ft. in height, with sills & window square resting on substantial concrete foundations.

9. The spaces between the joists have been filled.
in carefully with good gravel.

10. A large cellar of about 20 x 10 feet with entrance from lean-to kitchen by substantial steps; underlies the centre of the building. The same is well ventilated.

11. The lean-to kitchen (12 x 22) is a lumber addition to the north side of the old building extending also over the north entrance to the addition. It consists of the usual frame-work & sheeted only with clapboarding. The roof is lumber & shingle. This well finished externally.

12. The dining & general room is warmly & well constructed (20 x 24) heated by a large stove from. The piping passes through the dormitory into a brick chimney. Over the stove is also placed a large register for heating the dormitory at night.

13. There are 2 rooms at the west end of the addition (each 10 x 10) separated by passage way leading to front entrance—which is protected by a good sized porch.

14. The habitation is excellent.

15. The building is surrounded by a belfry at the west end.

16. The addition is ceiled throughout.

Regina, November 20th, 1893

Sir,

I have the honour to transmit herewith for the information of the department a copy of a letter from Mr Agent Lucas relative to a new school building asked for by the Rev Mr Gibbon - Stoken, at an estimated cost of $600.00.

This letter is in reply to one from this office, telling the Agent: under the department's instructions, that, since so far as could be seen, the matter of procuring children was more or less speculative, and in view of no funds being provided to meet the estimated cost, it would be better to defer building until Spring or until such time as we could be assured of the extra attendance anticipated by the Principal and that the present school room should therefore suffice for the requirements of the coming Winter, and if, during the Winter months, the actual necessity

The Deputy of the
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
St. Barnabas' Mission
Sarcee Reserve.

Calgary, H.W.T., 189.

(as the Architect's Report shows) is only large enough
(under the Regulations of your Department) for Eight—
under these circumstances we feel it would be
unwise to crowd into it 9 or 10 more children.

The winter has been very severe, & my brother
has found it extremely difficult to make the
building at all comfortable, for instruction each day.

The Carpenter who is now erecting the Boarding
School at the South Blackfoot Camp is prepared to
undertake the erection of a School here whenever the
Department give the word. The Agent as well as
ourselves would do all in our power & save expense.

I shall indeed be grateful if you will enable
us to put this building up at once, & so not only
provide comfort for teachers & scholars, but enable us
to take in those children who are waiting for admission.

I am, my dear sir

Your very faithfully,

H.W.Gibson Stockham.

"Child & Wilson, Architects"
Office of Town Engineer,
Calgary N.W.T.
Oct 12th 1893

On School Building
Sarcee Indian Reserve, Alta N.W.T.

"Agreeably to instructions we have surveyed the above building and beg to report as follows:
This building was erected 7 years ago; it is built of logs with shingled roof; inside, the internally, the walls & ceiling are lined with beaded tongue, & grooved wainscoting.
The building is by no means proof against cold air, the window frames are poor & out of repair, the chinking between the logs is defective in many places & the logs themselves are full of snake, also the roof is not tight at the wall plates, consequently it is not surprising that the building proves to be very cold in winter. The bottom bays & cills are more or less rotten & decayed.
The building is quite unsuitable for school purposes, being very low & narrow - at 4'5" to each child's cubic capacity for only eight persons. This includes the small recess at end. The floor space of school room at 10' x 16' ft. to each, would accommodate 32 persons, but the width of the building being only 16'0", this could not be readily accomplished done. 16'0" is altogether too narrow for a school room & the capacity of the room..."
decreased by book-closet, store &c.

The School-room is rather dark, the windows which are two in number, and consist of 8 panes each of 10 x 12" glass; they are on one side of the room. The tops of their sills are only 15" above the floor, and consequently much useful light is lost, being obstructed by desks &c. We are given to understand that it is proposed with a view of enlarging this school room, to bring bodily from a distance of 5 miles a log building similar in all respects to the building in question & adding it on to the same; this will prove to be a very costly & difficult undertaking; the country being very hilly. We are of opinion that the most satisfactory plan, and the most economical to adopt, is to erect an entirely new building of lumber with concrete or stone foundations.

The Department have been anxious for me to get into our Homes and the children on the Reserve with the exception of possibly 5 girls all are in our Homes.

I have no doubt of such a course, and I am quite sure that all interested in the Indians would evince generally any such progressive movement, but I for my part, will certainly prefer to send these backs to camp rather than run the risks of anything approaching an epidemic amongst them.

My Lord,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 9th instant, transmitting memoranda from the Rev. Mr. Stocken relative to the necessity for and cost of an addition to the Boys' Home, and in reply to inform you as follows.

When the Department enters into any educational undertaking on the understanding that it is on a certain scale, it causes it no small amount of embarrassment to have unforeseen and unexpected demands made upon it in connection with the same, and can only meet them by cramping itself in other directions, and endangering other interests.

In the case in point this has been felt so strongly, on account of calls in other directions, that Mr. Stocken has already been told that there seemed no other way out of the difficulty than to keep the number of pupils to within the limit justified by the available accommodation.

In Mr. Stocken's case, however, the Department would stretch a point in a way it would do for a very few, because it has always recognised an endeavour on his part to assist its Agents in carrying out the Department's policy, and a readiness to defend such policy when attacked by people who apparently did

In recognition, therefore, of such services, the Department has been searching for some means by which to meet Mr. Stocken's desire, and although unable to find funds directly in the school appropriation, the following plan has occurred to it as feasible.

There is a moderate appropriation for hospital building for the benefit of the Blackfoot, and if the old school building which Mr. Stocken considers so insufficient for class room purpose can be made to serve for a Hospital for the Reserve, then the sum of $300, which might otherwise be expended in providing such a building, might without impropriety be devoted to providing the new class rooms asked for. My dear Mr. Reed,

May I, without unduly encroaching upon your time, ask you whether it will be in your power to let me know definitely about the proposed Girls' Home for this Reserve, within the next 4 weeks? The reason I ask is that the excessive heat in Japan after the middle of July necessitates my leaving here by the last of May, returning by 30th July. Under these circumstances I am naturally very anxious about my Mission house, which of course I shall need by the end of July. Underwood tells me he could complete the Girls' Home in a very satisfactory manner in about 5 weeks. I am also expecting a grant from our Missionary Society to repair the Mission House which will take about a fortnight or so, so that time, as you will see, is very precious to me. My dear Mr. Reed,

I am in somewhat of a dilemma—If you are not able to find funds out of the current fiscal year's savings—have you made any provision for the Girls Home in the Estimates for the New Year? My position is just this, that I have nowhere else but the Mission Office where I could accommodate the girls, although I have the same room as now available as a dormitory, if necessary, I have no separate quarters for their general dining room—or any separate kitchen—which must serve, as means whatever of accommodating the Matrons. Should you therefore find it impossible to provide funds, I think it wise to advise me to let the girls go back to the Camp (which would be a thousand pities). I ought to know at once as the Matrons will require a long notice. It is unfortunate that I am obliged to start for Japan so early (36th inst.) but it is unavoidable. Am I lacking too much in a telegram of advice? The Matrons want to know before I leave.

Yours very sincerely,

The pupils gave a repetition of their work of the past quarter in reading, spelling, meanings, arithmetic, mental arithmetic, geography, each class according to its standard - it is pleasing to report they have made good progress in all branches, with the exception that they do not speak out, which may - in a measure - be accounted for through extreme shyness. They read well and understandingly, with a clear enunciation, (not slurring the words as is too often the case with a long one particularly).

Their spelling was rather surprising by its accuracy.

They were up in Tables and have made good progress in arithmetic according to each standard.
In Geography they have a wide general knowledge with some specific knowledge as regards this country. I saw that the Teacher had gone outside Schoolroom routine in giving them "talks" on general subjects, and that the pupils have taken a good deal of it in - a form of teaching in addition to routine - that should be more general than it is, as Indian children neither learn from their parents or from each other like White children and are dependant upon their teachers entirely for instruction and when this is limited strictly to school-room work, their progress in common sense knowledge (I may call it) is very slow indeed.

School-room.

Through a rearrangement of the offices of the building the school-room is now a well lighted building of sufficient size to accommodate comfortably all the pupils.

It is furnished with patent seats, blackboards, maps, lesson cards, teachers chair and table; also an organ.

Dormitories.

These are large, clean, well ventilated, and furnished with single iron cots - they were neatly made up with clean linen and clean bed clothing, with colored counter-pane.

-Clothing Closets-

A large one for the boys contained quantities of new clothing - such as suits, shirts and underclothing.

While another one for the girls contained dresses, petticoats and underclothing.

I understand that most of this clothing was donated, it shows that this school has large hearted and liberal friends.

Those friends had not forgotten the little girls for there were dolls of all descriptions which had been thoughtfully sent for their amusement as well as instruction, for there is a lot of instruction in dressing and undressing a modern doll.

The girls matron had large quantities of the girls handiwork to show me - well knitted stockings, hemming new underclothing, darning, &c., they also do their share in general housework, cooking and kitchen work.

The boys and girls are all well clothed and look healthy and well nourished.

By a reference to my list of names you will observe that one of the pupils has been more than a year at school, 3 over two years, 1 over 4 years, 7 over five years, and 2 over six years, and 2 may be called new pupils having been there only one quarter.

The head boy has just been promoted to
the Calgary Industrial School to learn a trade.

If they were White children the larger number after so many years at School would be fit for graduation, but Sarcee children have even more to contend against than other Indian children, not the least being their native dialect and peculiar disposition.

-Fire extinguishing appliances-

The fire buckets were filled with water in the dormitories, the fire axes were in convenient places, and hand grenades were distributed about.

A Windmill for pumping purposes has been added to the establishment since my last visit to this school.

They have a large and productive vegetable garden, it is a great fight to keep down the gophers which are numerous and very destructive. The boys and Teacher have done all the work therein.

-Building-

My attention was directed to the sinking of the foundation of the main and original building, caused by the caving in of the cellar which was never properly constructed, a few hundred dollars, say $250.00, would set this matter right now; while if it is not attended to will soon end in the destruction of the buildings.

All
All the buildings require to be repainted, outside as well as inside. The fences are in good repair, and the whole establishment presents a creditable appearance.

Your obedient servant,
(Sgd) T.P. Wadsworth.
Insp. Indian Agencies.

EXTRACT from Report of Provincial School Inspector J. A. MacGregor, regarding his inspection of the SAROEE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on the 15th of September, 1931.

Original on File 120-1-6.

It appears to be a problem to place pupils in desks of the proper size. A careful survey should be made and I am satisfied that, with the present equipment, this matter can be satisfactorily adjusted.

As much as possible, desks should be the same size in each row, also they should be screwed to strips or to the floor, care being taken to see that they are properly placed. This is not the case at present, some pupils being seated on one size of desk, while they work on a desk of another size.
Ottawa, November 4, 1931.

Sir:

The Provincial School Inspector, in a report on his inspection in September, last, of the Sarcee Indian Day School states as follows regarding the seating accommodation:

"It appears to be a problem to place pupils in desks of the proper size. A careful survey should be made and I am satisfied that, with the present equipment, this matter can be satisfactorily adjusted. As much as possible, desks should be the same size in each row, also they should be screwed to strips or to the floor, care being taken to see that they are properly placed. This is not the case at present, some pupils being seated on one size of desk, while they work on a desk of another size."

I shall be pleased if you will take up with the teacher the matter of the proper arrangement of the desks, and endeavour to place the same size in each row, after which they should be screwed to strips of wood - two or three desks fastened to the one strip. The Department will pay the cost of any work in having the desks properly adjusted and fastened to strips, as recommended by the Inspector.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding the action taken and an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering any expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM THOS. F. MURRAY, INDIAN AGENT, CALGARY, ALTA., dated September 2, 1931, submitting Estimates for fiscal year 1932-33.

Orig. on 1932E-1.

The enlargement of the schoolroom has been recommended by School Inspector McGregor, who states that we have not sufficient square feet in the schoolroom for the children in attendance. To enlarge this schoolroom there are two inside walls that can be torn down. A new floor can then be laid over stair wells. The foundation on both sides would have to be completed to take care of this floor. The outside wall could then be cut through and double doors put in. From the floor level to the ground is a distance of eight feet. A wide set of stairs, with balustrade, would have to be built from the floor level to the ground. A platform holding an outside porch (6' x 6'), with double doors, would be necessary. Two windows on each side of the door would have to be cut in the wall. To take care of the heating of this additional space, two new radiators would have to be installed. I am submitting this Estimate in order to conform with the School Inspector's recommendation.

FORM No. 506
Sir:

With reference your letter No. 120-1-6 of the 31st ult., regarding the fire escape from the school-room at the Hospital, I beg to submit the following report:

The fire escape in use at the present time consists of a platform 4ft x 3ft with a 3ft guard rail, with a trap door leading to a ladder which is nailed to the side of the building. It is not a very good escape for small children. I would suggest that the Department builds a new fire escape as follows:

Have a door cut through the end window with a 4ft by 3ft platform. This platform to have a 3ft railing with balustrades 3" apart. Have steps leading to another platform 12ft below up against the side of the building. This second platform to be 3ft square. Then have steps leading to the ground at right angles to this platform. The steps should be made of 2x10 planking and the risers of 1x8 square edge. The entire steps from top to bottom should have a 3ft railing with the balustrades 3" apart. The first platform would be supported from the ground below by 6x6 timber, spliced. In addition there should be three iron rods of 1" diameter going through the building and being caught inside by a 2x4. The second platform could be supported by 4x4 timber. Every 4th step should have a ½" iron bar to ensure against any buckling. The door should open out on to the platform and the upper half should have four lights of glass. A mortise lock and a barrel bolt would be necessary for securing the door. The supporting timber could in its turn be supported and secured by 2x6 timber.

February 12th, 1938.
Sarcee Agency, Calgary.
February 12th, 1938.

The entire cost to build this fire escape would be $110.00. The lumber, nails and miscellaneous hardware and blacksmith material would cost $80.00; and the labour would cost $30.00.

Sir:

Dear Sir:

Installation of a new hot air furnace is approved. It is noted that you have secured a price of $338.00 from P. Kennedy, Calgary, Alta. Re employment of Mr. Thos. H. Varcoe, I regret that I did not make myself clear on this point, and that I confused you somewhat in the matter, by referring to him as "carpenter and handy-man at the Agency." Mr. Varcoe is not in our service, or a member of our Staff: The following is an abstract from my inspection report dated May 29th, 1941, Page 5:

"Mr. Thos. H. Varcoe - Fireman-Engineer-Handy-man. While not a salaried employee, this man makes his home at the hospital, where he does the work of fireman-labourer, handyman and chore boy, for his board and room. He is a fair mechanic and engineer, and a good farm carpenter. From information I got in conversation, he came to the reserve in 1934, with the Department's approval, to work on Indian buildings (houses) for which he was paid from Band Funds. In between times, he did odd jobs at the Agency and hospital, for which he made no charge. He remained and has now become a living part of the institution. His doing so for his board and room saves us the cash salary of a fireman-engineer. He is a good worker, well behaved, unassuming, does not interfere, and would be missed by everyone on the reserve were he to leave. When there is any carpenter work to be done on the reserve for the Indians, or the Department, he is employed to do so, and is paid -- from Band Funds or Appropriation, as the case may be. He appears to be well satisfied with his lot, and wishes to remain where he is and carry on as he has been doing for the past seven or eight years."

This will explain how he came to the Agency, where he has remained.

As will be noted, Mr. Varcoe has submitted a quotation for each piece of work to be done, and he now informs me that this was based on an hourly rate of 40¢. He has his own tools. I would recommend giving him the work, which I feel certain he will do most carefully and satisfactorily. I do not believe that we could get an outsider to go to the Reserve and do the work for 40¢ per hour.

I have asked Dr. Murray to obtain quotations on the material required, and to have same delivered at the Agency as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Calgary, January 19, 1942

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your No. 120-1-1 of the 15th instant, approving of the installation of a hot air furnace at the Sarcee Indian Reserve Day School.

Upon receipt of your letter, I immediately got in touch with Messrs. Bell and Morris, of Calgary, who informed me that Mr. (Major) J.A. McLean had joined the Army, and was not now in the furnace business, and that they (Bell and Morris) did not handle hot air furnaces. They recommended Anderson Plumbing and Heating Company (Mr. Wm. Anderson), or the Chesney Hardware Company. Both of these firms are on the preferred list.

I then got in touch with Mr. Wm. Anderson, who stated his firm did not handle hot air furnaces.

I then contacted the Chesney Hardware Company, and Mr. C.L. Chesney drove out to the Reserve with me on Saturday, the 17th instant. He has now handed me his quotation, which I enclose herewith, together with cut and specifications.

I have also asked Mr. P.J. Kennedy to give more details re the furnace on which he had quoted: (Ref. my No. 408-11A of the 12th instant, forwarding his quotation). I asked him to give the name of the manufacturer, and state whether the furnace was an all-cast, heavy duty. Mr. Kennedy has this day handed me the Beach Foundry Ltd. illustrated pamphlet, which I am attaching hereto, stating that he was quoting on a No. 519 furnace, which I have marked on the pamphlet, in red.

I presume that the Department can decide from these, which is the best value, and I beg to ask for instructions, by radio, please, as the furnace will have to be ordered from Edmonton or Winnipeg.

Dear Sir:

It would be of very great help with me, as the teacher at Sarcee Day School, if you will again take up with the proper Authorities the matter of providing a Piano for our School. You are of course aware that since I commenced my duties here I have asked for this most necessary item of School equipment.

In his Report last year Inspector Wilson, the Provincial Inspector urged that a Piano be obtained. He visited the School again this week and was not happy that we are still without the piano. The singing as we are able to undertake it, without music pleased him, and better work could be done with the assistance of music.

You will remember that the Piano that used to be in the School when Mr. Gibney was teacher, was his own property, and was sold by his Widow. I am getting to the position where I feel I must do something about the purchase of a Piano, and recently I have been looking for used Pianos at the Eaton Company. Something that will be of good service to us is obtainable from $240 to $260. I am sure that I can get a reduction if I purchase myself. However you will realize that with my little family this means a considerable outlay and the money difficult to find. However I would go ahead, if I had from you or from the Department some assurance that they would give me some assistance, at least.

Eatons of Calgary have been kind enough to put a Reserved card on a Williams Upright used Piano and will hold it until they hear from me. The price is $40.00, and as a Clergyman I would get 10% off of that and possibly by seeing the Manager who is a Sarcee Chief (Cut Knife) more consideration could be arranged. Will you therefore kindly take up this matter with the Department by Air Mail so that I may make some decision within the next few days.

I can only add, that I am a fair Judge of instruments and mechanically this one is good—it has defects on the Case which is of no disadvantage for the School.

Yours Sincerely,

[Signature]
Teacher-Sarcee Day School.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I beg to enclose herewith a letter from the Reverend L.F. Rowe, teacher of the Sarcee Indian Day School, in which he requests the Department to furnish a Piano for the school-room. This is the first occasion on which Mr. Rowe has asked for a Piano. There is no doubt that a Piano would be of considerable assistance in teaching singing to the Indian school children. However, the request for the Piano was made to me three months after my 1946-47 Estimates were forwarded to Mr. Inspector C.P. Schmidt. Neither was a request made for this Piano before the 1945-46 Estimates were compiled. The amount requested by Reverend Rowe is considerable for a used Piano; but, I am not familiar with the prices required for these instruments. The Department is undoubtedly familiar with the necessity for a Piano in the teaching of Indian children. Consequently, I beg to have the Department's opinion as to the advisability of this purchase.

Dr. T. F. Murray, Indian Agent,
Calgary, Alberta.

I have your letter of the first instant, with reference to purchasing a piano for the Sarcee Indian Day School.

It is not our general practice to purchase equipment such as this for reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you. In any case, we would not consider allowing the amount mentioned by Mr. Rowe. While the piano which he mentions may be worth the amount requested, there are often possibilities of securing second hand pianos, in reasonably good condition, for a much lower price. Due to the requirements of the Armed Services, second hand pianos have been bought up rather readily during the past few years and consequently there are very few on the market. I am inclined to feel that this condition will change within the next few months and if it is possible to secure a second hand piano at a lower price than that mentioned by Mr. Rowe, you might bring the matter to my attention later.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I beg to give you an extract from a letter received from our present teacher, Rev. I. F. Rowe:

"The Class-Room. This building adjoins the former Residential School Quarters, now termed Sarcee Hospital. As a room it is fair, being recently redecorated and is fairly well equipped with desks and other necessary articles. There is a very nice cloak room for the girls and ample space for boys. The heating arrangements are poor. During the days of the Residential School this Room was heated by steam from the main plant, and was never apparently very satisfactory, being slow in heating up in the morning. After becoming a Day School a hot air furnace was placed in the school basement. This works well enough during mild weather. While the Furnace has some defects, as all such installations have, the trouble is not the Furnace. To-day, as an illustration, with the Temperature about Zero, the class room was at no time above 55 deg., very draughty and altogether most uncomfortable. On the West wall are two cold air suction grates, placed there with the intention that they induct the cold air from the room into the air jacket of the furnace. During cold times and when there is the least bit of wind they reverse their function sending a cold draft across the teachers back and then upon the children's feet. This adds up to the fact that some insulation is needed around the top of the basement wall and floor of the class room, also the ceiling of the said room. If something could be done to overcome this trouble it would be of great satisfaction to Children and Teacher. Too much time has to be spent by the pupils warming up around the hot air vents. I might add that in Calgary a teacher has the liberty to dismiss her pupils should the class room be under 60 degs.

As we have asked for the appointment of a lady teacher, Miss Winnifred Timms, from the beginning of the year I trust it may be possible to have your local agent attend to this obvious need. Apparently it is mainly a matter of insulating the building properly so that the heating plant may be able to function.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary."

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School

An effort is being made to temporarily improve the above school, to brighten the environment and provide better heating facilities for the coming winter. To accomplish this, the following units will be required:

1. Circulating Oil Heater for the schoolroom, estimated cost from $25.00 to $30.00. If a new school is constructed later on, this heater may be used therein, or traded in on whatever type of heating unit is then installed.

2. A second hand coal range for the basement, to be used to heat the school floor and the basement room where manual training is conducted. Also, to heat soups etc., to augment lunches carried by the pupils who must come too far to warrant their returning home for the noon-day meal. Cost is only an estimate, but a good second hand coal stove could be purchased at around $35 to $40, possibly less.

The old furnace presently used is not satisfactory. The firebox and jacket are in poor shape, and I am advised by the tinsmith that additional heat take-offs and registers could not be installed. Circulation is poor.

With minor repairs in addition to the above, the school may be made clean and brighter at a minimum of expense. Enrollment is expected to be in excess of thirty students. This school is bleak and dismal in its present condition, and very cold and draughty in winter. Storm sash must be made for the lower portion of the deep windows, and basement windows must be sealed.

(over)
An entirely useless partition is being removed from the basement to allow more room for manual training and for recreational facilities in winter. In addition to the heater and stove, as well as five storm sash at a total cost of approximately $20.00, there will be such items as nails and possibly some small hardware. From two to three days labor on the part of a carpenter will be required, and any lumber or other materials needed can be salvaged on the spot.

The coal stove can be purchased at any time, but your approval is requested in order that purchase of the oil heater might be protected by placement of an order now. These heaters are very much in demand and are in short supply.

For your consideration and approval please.

G. H. Gooderham,

Director, Indian Health Services,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,- With Mr. C.J. Connelly and local Indian Affairs officers I have gone over the old Sarcee Hospital again. It is universal local opinion, which I think Mr. Connelly will join in, that the building should be torn down while its salvage value is still considerable and before it burns down from causes unknown. I believe that Mr. Connelly will report that its renovation cost would be prohibitive and I cannot conceive of any useful purpose it could serve.

There is much useful, and more useless, equipment in it. I have directed that:

1. Equipment suitable for a local nursing station be selected and put into safer storage at the Agency. This will include a good chesterfield suite, a good dining room suite and two good beds and dressers; ample kitchen equipment except a range; much good linoleum; a very limited amount of dispensary or clinic room furnishings.

2. Some square yards of linoleum, surplus to local needs, be taken up and sent to the Indian hospitals in southern Alberta for patching or other minor use; other linoleum to be used to cover the floors of two rooms in the Sarcee Agency offices which are being fitted up for a temporary medical clinic.

This will leave over a lot of miscellaneous articles, the best of which are about 24 good hospital beds without casters and with many defective but repairable springs; a number of good bedside tables; and much kitchen equipment.

The purpose of this letter is to inquire whether:

(a) The Department can think of any use for the building or, to put it otherwise, whether it concurs in its being demolished.

(b) It will be in order to invite representatives from Indian hospitals in southern Alberta to come and select what they can use at their hospitals.

(c) Whether it will be in order to turn over what remains to Indian Affairs for free distribution among old and needy Indians.

(d) Whether it will be in order to have the hospital beds repaired. The heads and feet are all good, the spring frames are good, the cable netting is mostly bad. I should say that the cost of repair would be $2 or $3 per bed. They will need 4 inch rubber castors to bring them to standard height.

M.B.,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services.

RE: Demolition of Sarcee Indian Hospital Building

With reference to the m/n subject and in accordance with instructions received from the Branch, an effort has been made to obtain a quotation on the m/n work.

The Ziegler Construction Co. of Calgary, Alta., was requested to look over this building in the company of the writer and Mr. M. McLeod, now in charge of the Sarcee Indian Agency. The attached quotation has been received in connection with this work. As will be noted, the quotation appears to be extremely high and in conversation with Mr. A.R. Williamson of this company, we have been advised that it will approximate 2 or 3 months work and will employ one foreman, three experienced whites and 9 to 12 Indians, all of whom, I understand, would have to be paid the minimum wage rate and would necessarily have to be covered by Workmen's Compensation.

The tender would include the removal of the large heating boiler, piping, radiators, plumbing fixtures and electric light fixtures. All lumber would be de-nailed and piled. All windows and frames stacked and the site levelled, leaving only a lean-to building housing the well and pump which would be used for stock watering purposes on the Agency premises.

There is a considerable amount of salvageable material in this building, as well as the heating plant, radiators with the necessary piping, there are a number of baths, toilets and hand basins.

The removal of the heating plant in itself would require more or less special equipment, and the heavy water and steam carrying pipes, which in the basement are insulated with asbestos, would also require technical knowledge.

There is also a considerable quantity of fir flooring which, if taken up, would have salvage value. With all this equipment in mind the writer has wondered if such fixtures as the heating plant, piping and radiators, the plumbing fixtures etc., could be offered as salvage and sold to the highest bidder, leaving such successful bidder to remove same. But in considering this, the writer wonders, if such material were moved out of the building by experienced contractors such as this or some other company, whether a higher bid would not be obtained as salvage over that of offering the same in the building when the successful bidder would have to remove same.
As the Branch is aware, this is a fairly large building and is in very bad condition, and if allowed to remain in its present state might leave the Branch open to severe criticism when supplies of this nature are at a premium.

The writer feels that merely to go in and tear the building down would be the wrong policy, especially in view of the fact that the equipment therein has a certain value. It is suggested that, perhaps, it might be advertised on a basis of taking down the building, salvaging of saleable products and perhaps comparative prices might lower the bid which the writer is now presenting. I do not think we would be justified in merely putting on one or two white men with a number of Indians to tear the buildings down with due consideration to the materials as mentioned above.

A second recourse would be to offer the heating plant, piping and plumbing for sale as and where is, then proceeding to tear down the building.

The writer would be glad of advice and instructions in the matter.

(John E. Pugh)
Superintendent,
Stony-Sarcee Indian Agencies.

Department of Mines & Resources,

Re: Demolition of Sarcee Indian Hospital Building

Reference is made to your letters, file 120-1-5 (WT1) and 120-1-1 (WT).

The demolition of this building has been given considerable attention locally. Attached hereto you will please find a copy of the tender supplied by the Zeigler Construction Company of Calgary, and copy of a report by Superintendent Pugh.

It will be noted that the construction company offer to do this work at a cost plus five per cent basis and the company estimates the cost will total $9,200.00. It might easily exceed that amount, and after it is all finished it is difficult to say what value will be received for it. The building was erected in 1912, I believe, and has been chopped and added on to from time to time. It is equipped with some old obsolete plant and some new. It is very likely that considerable of the lumber and timbers that went into it will be of value, but there is bound to be considerable of little or no value except for kindling.

It is our considered opinion that the building should be considered surplus to our requirements on that Reserve, and turned over to the War Assets Corporation for disposal. Aside from some work that the Indians might get in tearing it down, it is not believed that our Branch is justified in carrying out this work in the hope of retrieving plant and material which may be used again.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Attention: Mr. Neary

Re: Sarcee Day School

Mrs. Watson, newly appointed teacher of the Sarcee Day School, was in this office today. She said that they had requisitioned for baseball equipment and a football, but that these had not been received. Could authority be given to purchase locally a football at an estimated cost of $5.00.

The enthusiasm at this school appears to be high and still increasing. The attendance reached 35 last week, with the return of three or four children over 16 years of age. There is little at the school in the way of sporting equipment.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

AGREEMENT

BETWEEN: The Carpenters Section of the Amalgamated Building & Construction Workers of Canada, Local No. 5, Canadian Congress of Labour.

AND: The Calgary General Contractors Association.

OR: Certain other Calgary Contractors.

This Agreement shall become effective on April 1st, 1949.

This Agreement is to be effective until March 31st, 1950. Should either party wish to change, add to, or amend this agreement, sixty days notice in writing shall be given prior to termination date.

The object of this agreement is to stabilize the industry, elevate the trade, and to promote peace and harmony between Employers & Employees; to facilitate the peaceful adjustment of all disputes and grievances, to prevent strikes and lockouts, waste expense, avoidable delays in construction and repair work.

1. WAGES

(a) The minimum rate of wages shall be one dollar and forty-seven cents ($1.47) per hour. Foreman in charge of work shall be paid not less than 10 cents per hour extra. Any adjustment to be made in wages at March 31st, 1950, shall be made on the basis of the difference in the Federal Cost of Living Index as of March, 1949 and March, 1950. Adjustment to be calculated on the basis of .25¢ per week per point of the index.

(b) Wages shall be paid fortnightly or semi-monthly on the job and not more than three days pay shall be held back. When a carpenter is laid off, dismissed or leaves work of his own accord one hour's notice shall be issued at once on the job and all wages due shall be paid on the expiration of such time, and if the men are kept waiting they shall be paid at the rate they have been receiving. In the absence of such notice by either party, the one hour's notice shall be paid or forfeited. The Unemployment Insurance Book and the Holiday with Pay Book shall be stamped up to date and mailed from the office forthwith.

2. HOURS OF LABOUR

Eight hours shall constitute a day's work between the hours of eight a.m. and five p.m., with at least 3/4 hour for lunch. Forty hours shall constitute a week's work Monday to Friday. All work done outside of the regular working hours shall be considered over-time and paid for at the rates provided.

3. OVERTIME

Time worked after eight hours shall be considered overtime, and shall be paid for at the rate of time and one-half for the first four hours and double time thereafter. Saturday morning time and one-half, Saturday afternoons, Sundays and all Statutory Holidays double time.

OVER
STATUTORY HOLIDAYS

The Nine Legal and recognized Holidays shall be:

New Years Day; Good Friday; Victoria Day;
Dominion Day; Labour Day; Thanksgiving Day;
Remembrance Day; Christmas Day; Boxing Day.

When one of these specified Holidays falls on a Sunday the day following will be observed. No work shall be performed on Labour Day except where safety to life or property makes it necessary.

5. NIGHT SHIFT

Any time worked after 5 p.m. and before 8 a.m. shall be paid for at the rate of time and one seventh if these hours are part of the regular seven hour shift. If they are over-time in excess of the seven hour shift, then overtime rates as provided in clause (3) shall be paid in lieu of time and one seventh.

6. WORKING CONDITIONS

(a) The tools of a Carpenter starting a new job shall be in a good condition, and shall be kept so in the Employers time.

(b) If the use of a patent mitre box or power machine for the better carrying out of the work is desirable, they shall be supplied by the Employer, and operated by a skilled carpenter or tradesman.

(c) Laborers employed where carpentry work is being performed shall be confined to work that does not require the use of carpenters tools, with the exception of the claw hammer and claw bar, which must not be used by them for nailing.

(d) A suitable water-proof lock-fast place shall be provided by the Employer for the Carpenter's tools. Same to be equipped with a stove in the winter.

(e) No more than one spokesman shall be recognized in any one firm of Contractors.

(f) The Employer shall see that suitable messing and sanitary arrangements are provided for the men on the job.

7. TRANSPORTATION

On jobs in the City of Calgary which are beyond the regular terminus of the street car line or bus service, the Employer shall pay for any additional transportation or provide same.

The City of Calgary is defined as the area within a radius of ten miles from the City General Post Office.

On jobs away from Calgary where Carpenters are hired in Calgary, first-class transportation is to be provided by the Employer and travelling time on the basis of eight hours in twenty-four.
JOB STEWARDS

Shall be recognized and they shall not be discriminated against. Business Agent is to have access to all jobs covered by this Agreement in carrying out their regular duties.

DEFINITION

Carpentry: Shall include all woodworking in connection with or incidental to, the construction, erection, altering, remodelling or renovation of any building, or structure or part thereof, fixing or replacing, temporarily or permanently lumber of all kinds or substitute thereof, such as wallboard (except plaster board), all forming, framing, flooring, wood and finishing.

When a Contractor lays his own finish floors, he shall employ Carpenters and pay carpenters wages as set forth in this agreement, but there is nothing to prevent the Contractor from subletting his finish floors to a Floor Laying Contractor on a unit price basis.

No piece work shall be allowed except as provided for in Section 9.

EMPLOYER, EMPLOYEE RELATIONS COMMITTEE

It is agreed that should any dispute arise between the two parties of this Agreement, there shall be a Committee consisting of three members of each of the parties to this Agreement appointed, and upon notification must meet within forty-eight hours to investigate into and try and settle same, and any settlement arrived at by this Committee shall be binding on both parties.

KEEPING FAITH IN AGREEMENT

It is also agreed that before working for any Contractor who is not a member of the Calgary General Contractors Association, all efforts will be made to have such a contractor sign this Agreement; but in the event of not being able to obtain the signature, no member of the Amalgamated Union Local No. 5 shall work for any employer except under the conditions of this Agreement.

Enclosed herewith, please find final Progress Report on the marginally noted buildings constructed by The Ziegler Construction & Manufacturing Co Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, under PB # 4459, dated 5/10/48.

In connection with the rendering of this statement it is desired to state that we have had some difficulty in getting these final figures and such have only just come to hand as will be noted from the date of Oct 5th 1949, and our comments are as follows:

3. The writer authorized the lining of the ceiling joists with Gyproc wall board, being of the opinion that open joists are dust collectors and a fire hazard, and we trust we did not exceed our authority in so authorizing.

4. Bolting of screens was considered necessary by the inspector of engineering services, and this recommendation was carried out.

5. Window screens have not as yet been placed on the school, it being impossible to obtain Galvanized wire as per specifications. We have authorized these screens in green wire.

6. Levelling of grounds was carried out to our satisfaction and a little more done by the Contractor in this respect but no charge made for the additional work of levelling.

7. We have not drawn up any instrument to cover the guarantee of workmanship and materials on this building, as laid down in the Specifications, and for this the occupation date we presume should result as at the opening of the School on September 6th 1949, although the teacherage was occupied by a teacher during the month of June 1949. Will the Branch provide this guarantee instrument?

8. Additional works to this building have been dealt with and include "Wiring of Building", "Floor Painting or Varnish work", accounts having been cleared for the above.

9. The writer is satisfied with the building as "In Charge" of construction, and recommends the attached final progress estimates for payment.

When your letter of November 30th was received, Mr. Pugh and I interviewed Mr. Williamson of the Ziegler Construction Company. He maintained that the Company's original tender contained an escalator clause. Under cover of our letter of August 9th, file 120-6-3, we mailed you the original of the Ziegler Construction Company's offer and the copy we have on file contains the following notation below the signature of Mr. Williamson: "N.B.- labour and materials costs subject to any increase after date of quoting".

However, we advised Mr. Williamson that we were prepared to recommend payment for the following extras mentioned in the first paragraph of the second page of your letter of November 3rd:

| Item 1 and 2 | - $21.80 |
| Item 3       | - $555.67 |

$377.47.

Payment for these extras had been previously recommended by Mr. Pugh and his reasons were outlined in his letter of October 10th, 1949, file 120-6-3. Items 1 and 2 were completed on the recommendation of the Inspecting Engineer and Item 3 was authorized by Mr. Pugh because he considered that the open joists on the basement ceiling constituted a fire hazard and dust collector.

We also advised Mr. Williamson that we would ask you to reconsider the following items.

(1) Administration, use of equipment, Public liability Insurance and Profit @ 10%........ $39.46
(2) Extra on Stewart & Phillips invoice........... $68.60
   (for heating)

Total...........$108.06

However, we gave the firm no assurance that these last two items would be paid. Mr. Ziegler stated that item 1 is standard procedure with Construction Companies and we asked him for statement to this effect, as well as a statement indicating the difference in cost of materials used in the heating installation which created the extra $68.60 under Item 2. Apparently the heating contractor could not obtain galvanized iron and was forced to use aluminum sheeting in carrying out the furnace work.

Mr. Williamson, on behalf of the Company, accepted the two cheques, one for $937.80 and the other for $1,437.20.

(continued)
These were deposited and Mr. Williamson drew separate cheques and issued them to the sub-contractors as follows:

Wm. Sigalet Company Ltd........ $1100.00
Applicators Limited............. 750.00
Stewart & Phillips .............. 484.00
B.H. Sands and Son Ltd.......... 40.00

Total.......$2374.00

All this took place on December 5th. To date we have not received the information requested from the firm. Mr. Pugh has been in contact with them and wrote them as late as January 16th, again requesting the information.

Although a cheque could be issued for the first three items totalling $377.47, we think this should be delayed until we have heard further from Mr. Williamson because I am of the opinion that if another payment is made to this firm, it should be definitely the final and last payment.

If Mr. Pugh does not hear from Mr. Williamson very soon we shall endeavor to contact him personally.

Dear Col. Neary:

Ret: Sarcee Day School
Your file 701 - 5

From the minutes of a recent meeting of the Council of the Indian Association of Alberta, you will note there is a resolution asking that electric power be made available to the new school before the September term. In speaking to the resolution, the Chief of the Band stated that the school is three miles from the power line and it is intimated that the power line be extended to the school.

It is known that the Calgary Power has so large a demand on the available electric energy that it is not anxious for new business at present. The cost of running a line for three miles would, I believe, be greater than is justified.

If sufficient funds were still available, I would recommend that an electric unit be installed. The school is wired and the expenditure would be confined almost entirely to the cost of the unit.

During a visit to this school this week with Mr. Blair Fraser, Ottawa Editor of Maclean's Magazine, electrification of the building came up for discussion. The principal of the school stated there is always a danger of using lamps and at the same time the light is poor. Everybody agreed that that was so and it was further agreed that it was poor business to put in a small 32-Volt plant. It is suggested that a 110-Volt automatic set, capable of producing 2000 watts would answer the purpose. It is estimated that the total cost of plant and installation should not exceed $750.00. If funds are now available, I hope you will consider this.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Enclosed herewith please find requisition for a lighting plant for the Sarcee Indian Day School.

Quotations were received from Bruce Robinson Electric Ltd. and Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company, Limited, and their quotations are enclosed.

Mr. Pugh was here yesterday and on going over the quotations received from the two firms it was considered that the 1750 watt with A.C. 110 volt and 32 volts D.C. would be the unit more suitable for this school for efficient operation, in that the teacherage can use the 32 volt battery line of the plant, and if in full operation for school and teacherage, the full capacity of 110 volts can be utilized.

The Bruce Robinson Electric Limited will install the plant, but the Branch will have to provide a concrete base. The cost of this is estimated at $10.00 for material and $15.00 for labour.

The building was wired for electric current at the time of construction, but no fixtures for lighting has been provided. It is impossible at the present time, due to snow blocked roads, to get a quotation on this, but it is estimated that $100.00 will cover, approximately, this expenditure.

Bruce Robinson Electric Limited have one of these plants in stock and will be ready to install it on receipt of the order.

Dear Col. Neary:

Further to my letter of February 24th, and your reply of the 2nd, file 701-5 (E), Superintendent Pugh and Assistant Agent MacLeod went to a number of wholesalers, including C.G.E., Electric Wholesales Limited, Ashdowns Limited, Fairbanks-Morse Company Limited, and Bruce Robinson Electric Limited, to inspect what lighting units they might have to offer. Only the two latter companies had any unit to offer which was at all suitable. The other firms could not quote.

Mr. MacLeod has submitted a covering letter, with quotations from these two latter companies. Requisitions and copy of letter attached hereto.

Following the suggestion that was made in my letter of the 24th, Bruce Robinson Electric's offer of a special combination unit is our choice for the reasons set out in Mr. MacLeod's letter.

If you refer to the Fairbanks-Morse quotations, the 2000 Watt, 115 Volt A.C. Automatic would be continually in operation while there is light, and this is not desirable. If power is being used only in the teacherage, there is no need for the full plant being operated. The 32 Volt D.C. Electric requires batteries and the total cost of this plant is not justified.

It is our firm conclusion that the Bruce Robinson's offer to supply a 1750 BAS plant, with a set of battery cells is the suitable plant, and it is hoped that the Purchasing Agent can see his way clear to purchase it. It is available for immediate delivery. If the plant is supplied, the fixtures can be installed in April.

Yours truly,

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Sarcee Day School - Janitor Services

We have noted the comments of Mr. Crow Child as reported in the Minutes of the meeting of the Sarcee Band Council held on March 27, 1950.

Departmental policy is clearly outlined in a recent circular letter on caretaking in Indian day schools. Our educational expenses have risen rapidly and we feel that the least Indian parents and children can do is to assist to keep their day schools clean and orderly. This is done in most rural schools throughout Canada and we have never had any objection previously from the Indians to the children assisting the teacher in keeping the school clean. I feel that this matter should be raised at the next meeting of the Sarcee Band Council and that it should be explained to the council members that the Department is paying all expenses in connection with the operation of the Sarcee School. We have built them a very fine school, have equipped it with the latest educational materials and have provided two good teachers. Surely they should not object to their children helping to keep this new school clean and orderly as is done in small provincial schools.

Bernard F. Henry,

I wish to submit herewith Requisition for eves troughing and down spouts for the Sarcee Indian Day School. It is considered essential that the South side of this school be equipped with eves troughing as the teacherage is on this side, and the roof of the teacherage joins the roof of the main building on this side, and on both sides of the teacherage, by the entrance doors, a heavy flow of water comes down this trough in wet weather, and this water soaks into the ground and is liable to damage the concrete walls and basement.

It is proposed to have one down spout, 16 ft., at the SE and SW corners to carry off this water, which the Teacher would like to collect in barrels for the use of the family, as the water in the Band well, 100 yds. East of the School is very hard and a poor supply.

I would be glad if this requisition could be submitted with your approval to the Branch.

Attention, Col: B.F Neary.

Under date of August 17th, Your File No 701-5 (E), addressed to G.H. Gooderham, sq., reg: Supervisor of Indian Agencies, Calgary, Alta., we have been requested to complete the attached questionnaire, and report upon the progress of the Sarcee Indian Day School.

In this connection it is advised that no action was taken during the writer's vacation, and upon our return we contacted Mr Williamson, Manager of the Ziegler Construction & Manf Co Ltd, in connection with winding up this work.

In doing so, we pointed out that three Calgary firms had billed us for work performed under his Contract, stating that they had not received payment; these are:

Stewart & Phillips. Furnace ........................................ $993.60
W. Sieglet & Co Ltd. Painting ........................................ $2200.00
Applicator's Ltd. Roofing ........................................ $1400.00

These accounts were drawn to the company's manager with the request that he attend to the payments prior to our being off duty, and again after our return, but as yet not paid. In view of this we requested Mr Williamson to render his accounts in full on the project, indicating those accounts not paid, which we are advised are only the above, no other parties making any claim to-date to this he has agreed, and at the time of our interview with him, he advised that he had asked the Royalumber Lards Ltd, to supply him with "Difference in Price Statement" as between Contract Tender and Delivery", indicating that the escalator clause in the Contract was applicable. We then asked for the complete accounting set-up, based on the contract and the above clause in order to submit the matter to the Branch, at the same time asking that he provide us with an order to the effect, that, under the contract, and providing there was sufficient funds from the project to their credit, we be authorized to either pay the above outstanding accounts, or that he would in the presence of a Field Officer, endorse such cheques that may issue to the respective firms, to which Mr Williamson agreed. We advised him to make the necessary deductions for cement provided by us, and to complete his accounts with all possible speed. The writer has now been advised by Mr Williamson that he is
is in Vancouver, B.C., until the end of the month, but has requested a supply of forms to complete the accounting requested.

The building in question is completed to our satisfaction, except that the window screens have not been provided, due to the fact that Galvanized wire screening was specified, and this cannot be obtained, such information being given to us by The Royal Timber Yards Ltd., we therefore instructed Mr. Williamson to procure Black wire screens. Should this not meet with the approval of the Branch, may we so advised by return mail.

The question of occupancy does arise while the accounting is pending, and we advised Mr. Williamson of the fact that we desired to commence school on the 6th of September, and it is apparent, that we shall not have the matter cleared up at that time. Would our occupation of the building at the above date render the branch liable under the Contract?

The guarantee on the building for one year was also brought to Mr. Williamson's attention, and he was asked to provide this. Is there a special form for this purpose, if so may we be provided with same?

In reply to the questionnaire form provided by the firm of Middleton and Tait, we have answered this advisedly, and are attaching the complete file for your perusal, this action being taken in view of the existing conditions surrounding this Contract. May we be advised if concurred in as to the data provided on the above form.

We will forward the accounting on this Contract as soon as we are in receipt of same, and we regret very much that our powers of direction in this matter have been of so little avail, in spite of giving our full attention at all times.

In fairness to all concerned, we might add that construction of this type in winter months when remotely removed as to road conditions makes it a difficult task, and Mr. Williamson advises that this feature has entailed a loss. We feel that we should also mention the fact that this Company have been doing work for The Department of National Defence, and he informs us that they have a very substantial amount outstanding with that Department, hence their inability to meet the accounts quoted above.

Advise in the matter will be appreciated.

John E. Pugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School

Extracts from Report of Supervising Engineer J.H. Snelson who Inspected this School on May 9, 1949.

Building Outside:
The outside of the building is covered with brick imitation asphalt siding. This looks O.K. The roof is covered with asphalt shingles; many show a slight turning up and should be fastened down. The peak of the roof is not on the same level throughout, having a variation above and below the correct level, possibly ½ inch. It looks slightly wavey.

Plaster on outside of concrete basement wall was carried down to present ground level only. When site is levelled or when fill around building settles, a ragged line showing lower extent of plaster will be exposed. Plaster should be carried down well below finished grade.

Aluminum flashing around water-table at bottom of asphalt siding should be painted. At present it shines and is not in harmony with siding.

Building Inside:
All inside work in the classrooms and in other rooms is satisfactory with two exceptions:

(a) Most doors have expanded due to moisture absorption and painting. Doors should be planed to fit.

(b) Blackboards have absorbed moisture and bulged in centre as much as ¼". Mould around edges should be removed, blackboards thoroughly dried out and cemented to wall underneath. When set, boards to be trimmed to fit replaced or renewed moulding.

General:
(1) Basement floors were painted before concrete was thoroughly cured, hence paint did not all stick and floors will need repainting.

(2) A metal sheathed door for the coal bin is yet to come.
(3) The outdoor toilets have been finished and equipped with catch cans that must be emptied. Door catches are too close to jamb and will have to be reset.

(4) Grounds are to be cleaned up.

Dear Sir:

Re: Two Room Indian Day School,
Sarcee Reserve,
Stony-Sarcee Agency, Alta.

In compliance with your request of April 30th,
Mr. Snelson inspected this school on the 9th instant,
accompanied by Mr. Pugh.

Well
A drilled well, at present equipped with a
hand pump, 164 feet in depth, supplies 3
barrels of water (135 gallons) per hour.
Water was struck at a depth of 96 feet.
Drilling 70 feet deeper through slate fur-
nished no additional supply.

Building Outside
The outside of the building is covered with
brick imitation asphalt siding. This looks
o.k. The roof is covered with asphalt shingles;
many show a slight turning up and should be fas-
tened down. The peak of the roof is not on the
same level throughout, having a variation above
and below the correct level, possibly 1/2 inch.
It looks slightly wavey.

Plaster on outside of concrete basement wall was
carried down to present ground level only. When
site is levelled or when fill around building
settles, a ragged line showing lower extent of
plaster will be exposed. Plaster should be
carried down well below finished grade.

Aluminum flashing placed around water-table at
bottom of asphalt siding should be painted. At
present it shines and is not in harmony with
siding.

Building Inside
All inside work in the classrooms and in other
rooms is satisfactory with two exceptions:-

(a) Most doors have expanded due to moisture
absorption and painting. Doors should be
planed to fit.

(b) Blackboards have absorbed moisture and
bulged in centre as much as 4". Mould
around edges should be removed; black-
boards thoroughly dried and cemented to
wall underneath. When set, boards to be
trimmed to fit replaced or renewed mould-
ing.

Walls are Gyprock wall board on studs strap-
ped and painted, good job.

Floors are excellent, good edgegrain fir;
well laid, sanded and finished.
General

Built up beams in basement, four 4" x 10" are rather loosely spiked together but are to be bolted, also every 3 feet.

Some additional cementing was necessary around basement windows. This will need repainting.

A large Good Cheer hot air furnace and necessary hot and cold air ducts have been installed.

All necessary conduits and outlet boxes have been built in.

A full quota of storm windows have been made and painted. Screens have not yet arrived.

All conduit pipe is aluminum.

Basement floors were painted before concrete was thoroughly cured, hence paint did not all stick and floors will need repainting.

A metal sheathed door for the coal bin is yet to come.

The outdoor toilets have been finished and equipped with catch cans that must be emptied. Door catches are too close to jamb and will have to be reset.

Grounds are to be cleaned up.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) J.H. Mitchell,
Supervising Engineer.

A letter from that Company was also enclosed approving the transaction.

We submitted a Voucher to the Treasury Branch, but they refused to issue a cheque, as they pointed out that it is contrary to Government practice to accept and act on Assignment of Accounts. They further pointed out as follows:

"There are two things you can do in the matter:

1. I am enclosing three copies of C.T. 127, the usual Government Power of Attorney forms for completion by an incorporated company, and if the Ziegler Construction Company is willing to execute such a Power of Attorney in favour of Royal Lumber Yards Limited, we shall be governed accordingly.

2. If you care to re-apply for the cheque in favour of the Ziegler Construction Company Limited, in the same manner as previous Progress Payments, we will

In view of the above, I enclose cheque for $5,350.00 issued in favor of the Ziegler Construction Company. It is felt that if we sent the Power of Attorney forms, there would be considerably more delay in making payment.

Memorandum:

Mr. T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Division,
Lands and Development Services.

Sarcee Indian Day School.

As you are aware, we are constructing, under contract, a two-room Indian Day School on the Sarcee Reserve, near Calgary, Alberta. Arrangements were completed to have one of your engineers periodically visit the project and assist the local Superintendent, Mr. Pugh, with his inspections.

We have just received an airmail letter from Mr. Gooderham, advising that the school will be completed in the very near future, and asking for a final inspection report by an engineer or architect before the final Progress Payment is made and a security deposit returned to the Ziegler Construction Company.

Mr. Cornish of the Banff Engineering Staff has resigned his position and the school has therefore not had engineering supervision lately. Would it be possible to arrange to have another engineer visit this project as soon as possible for a final inspection. If so, could this official contact Mr. Gooderham in Calgary, who will arrange to take him out to the project.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Department of Mines and Resources,

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School (New)

It is advised that the Ziegler Construction Company will probably be finishing their contract at the above noted school at the end of the first week in April, and it is desired to ascertain if the undersigned should have an engineer or architect pass upon this school, together with the writer, before passing the final Progress Report.

We are advised that Mr. Cornish of the Banff Engineering Staff has resigned his position and the school has, therefore, not received their inspection during the course of construction. This has been in the hands of the undersigned. It is not known whether there is a new appointee at Banff in the engineering staff for our work, and therefore the writer has to suggest that we obtain either the architect or one of the engineers of the Dominion Public Works Department at Calgary to pass upon this building as noted above.

Should the school be completed as anticipated by approximately April 9th next, would you recommend that we move into the school for teaching purposes after the Easter holidays, providing that the equipment in the line of desks and the procurement of the teachers is concluded by that time. The Chief, David Crowchild, has requested that the school be opened formally, asking that the Regional Supervisor, the Superintendent Stony-Sarcee Agency and other guests be invited to the opening.

We have referred to you a letter pertaining to the procurement of equipment for this school, and we trust that the requisition, which we asked the branch to complete, will be in the process of purchase and delivery.

Your reply airmail will be appreciated.

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant we are prepared to supply new desks for the Sarcee School. However, desks are made in three sizes, large, medium and small, and you should let us know the number of each size you consider we should purchase.

We have a standard list of equipment for teacher's living quarters, and we can arrange to place an order for what we supply.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.

Re: School Equipment, Sarcee New Day School.

It is anticipated that the above school may be ready for occupation towards the middle or end of April next, and the question of desks and other equipment arises.

Our Mr Macleod, Assistant, Indian Agency, Sarcee, was requested to examine the desks at the old school and he advises that these are all in bad condition after many years of use. With this in mind, may we suggest that new desks inclusive of teachers' desks be approved.

It is suggested that we provide for approximately sixty pupils, if this is in accordance with Major Clark's figures on potential pupilage for this school.

May we ask if the Branch will undertake the equipping of this school without requisition for such from this office. We suggest this as we feel that the Branch have equipped many day schools during the past two or three years, and would therefore be in a better position than the undersigned.

May we be advised, please?

John E. Pugh, Supt.
Stony - Sarcee Indian Agency.

Enclosed herewith please find 3rd Progress Report in connection with the erection of the two room day school and teacherage at the Sarcee Indian Reserve, Calgary, Alta.

This is submitted in accordance with Branch File 701-5 (E) of October 29th 1948.

Due to cold weather and drifted roads some delay has been occasioned during the past two weeks, but good progress has been made on the building.

The Electrical conduit system has been completed and all inside walls covered with plaster board. Doors and window frames set and finished. Insul brick siding completed with all trim in place.

The undersigned has made regular visits to this school throughout the period of this Progress report, and is satisfied with the work executed, and the payment of the attached Progress Report is recommended.

Re: Two Outside Toilets - Schoolhouse & Teacherages.
Sarcee Indian Reserve, Calgary, Alberta.

With further reference to our Tender submitted in the sum of $1057.80 for the construction of Two Outside Toilets as per plan and specification and our recent conversation regarding the cost of same we have to advise that when these were estimated for we allowed for the installation of a new 6' - 6" Porcelain Urinal as from past experience of Plumbers as well as Building Contractors metal lined urinals do not stand up.

We have carefully re-estimated on these toilets and find that the only possible way we can reduce our figure is by supplying a Used Porcelain Urinal. The used Urinal would be in perfect condition, having been dismantled from a former Royal Canadian Air Force Training Station. This would reduce the Tender by $120.00 making our figure NINE HUNDRED AND SEVENTY SEVEN DOLLARS AND EIGHTY CENTS ($977.80).

We trust this revised price will meet with your approval and will be glad to hear from you in due course.

Thanking you,

We are,
