MEMORANDUM

OTTAWA January 7, 1949.

Re: Outside Toilets,
One Classroom Day School,
Sarcee Agency, Alberta.

In reply to your notation of December 27, 1948, on memorandum from the Acting Director of Indian Affairs Branch dated December 21, 1948, a check has been made of quantities and costs for the supply and erection of two outside toilets as shown on our Drawing 837, Sheet No. T.I., for which the Ziegler Construction and Manufacturing Co., Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, have tendered in the sum of $937.80.

It is noted that the tender specified a used but servicable porcelain urinal trough in place of a metal lined trough as called for on plans. As the difference in cost between the used porcelain type and the metal lined is small compared to the formers durability and sanitary features, it is recommended that the used porcelain fixture be accepted in lieu of the metal lined.

Assuming that the porcelain type fixture is acceptable to Indian Affairs, we consider the sum of $937.80 is fair and reasonable for the construction of the two separate buildings and the installation of fixtures as specified. The Ziegler tender is returned herewith for return to Indian Affairs.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Sarcee Indian Day School

Receipt is acknowledged of your Army Message of November 19, in which you ask for a complete report indicating on whose authority the building was so constructed that the class room faces north instead of south.

Before construction of the school was begun at Sarcee, Mr. Ziegler and Mr. Williamson, of the construction company, met with Mr. J. E. Pugh and myself in this office. Among other matters discussed was the orientation of the building. Neither the plans or the specifications, so far as we could determine, made any mention of this in a way to indicate that the classrooms were to face south. Those of us who favored a northern exposure, based our stand on the fact that northern light is more evenly distributed throughout the room and is therefor steadier; that the direct approach of the sun's rays through windows facing south tends to cause considerable glare within the room so much so, that the blinds are usually drawn to cut out these rays. It had been fairly well agreed that a northern exposure should be used but to be more certain that we were correct in our choice, I called in Mr. Berton, who is an architect employed in the office of the District Resident Architect. He stated that if he were constructing the building, the classroom windows would be oriented to the north. He outlined briefly the reasons for this and his advice was given quite unofficially.

We therefor decided on a northern exposure, and the contractor marked the plan accordingly. It is not the purpose of this letter to argue against a southern exposure. Indeed, had we known the plan was designed to allow southern lighting, the matter would not even have been discussed.

I quite casually mentioned the location of the school to Mr. Clark when I met him at Gleichen last Tuesday. The following day he wired me at Gleichen, and wired and phoned this office, recommending that the necessary structural changes be carried out. Neither I nor Mr. Pugh suspected for a moment that we were acting contrary to any specific Departmental instructions in this matter.

This is all I have to report on the subject.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Subject: Indian Day Schools.

You will recall our previous correspondence with regard to the acceptance of tenders submitted for the erection of a standard two-room Indian day school (your index No. 849) on the above Indian Reserve near Calgary, Alberta.

In accordance with your recommendation, we have had authorized the acceptance of the contract of the Ziegler Construction and Manufacturing Company of Calgary, Alberta. By authority of P.C. 4459 of October 5, 1946, their lump sum tender of $32,430.00 has been accepted.

In accordance with similar requests made where we are erecting two-room schools, it would be appreciated if one of your engineers from Banff could visit this project during the course of his other duties in the area. While the primary responsibility for the construction of this school rests with this branch, the advice of your local engineers would be most valuable to our local Indian Superintendent. If a fortnightly visit could be arranged, this would be of great help to us. If your Engineer would contact Mr. John E. Pugh, Indian Superintendent, Norley, he can obtain the necessary detail.

Acting Director.

Re: Sarcee Day School and Combined Residence

With reference to the construction of the above mentioned building, it is advised that we have today met Mr. Ziegler and Mr. Williamson of the Ziegler Construction Company in connection with the erection of this school and discussed the following points:

1. Contract - Terms and Conditions

Will this contract be available as soon as possible, as it is the intention of this company to commence work Monday the next, October 15th? The Construction Company cannot obtain the $10,000.00 bond until the issuing company views a copy of the contract. It is suggested that the contract be sent to me; I shall see that the bond is obtained and forwarded to Ottawa together with the signed contract.

2. This tender does not include the provision of outside toilets, no plans or specifications being available at the time the tender was asked. It is estimated the additional cost would be approximately $350.00 to $500.00 per toilet. It is understood that two toilets must be provided, one for girls and one for boys.

3. Inspection

May we be advised if the inspection of this work will be carried out by a Field Officer or by an officer appointed by the Indian Affairs Branch independent of your field service?

4. May we be provided with the necessary Progress Reports, as we understand that this company will be making application for funds from time to time based upon progress of work at this school.

In connection with the above, may we ask if in support of the progress report, when rendered, would it be necessary to provide the receipted accounts for materials supplied and time sheets covering labor, or certified affidavit as to the amount of material provided and labour performed? It is possible that the Branch may have a specific rule in regard to the rendering of these on the basis of weekly, semi-monthly, monthly or on demand from the contractor.

With reference to the amount of cement provided - $25 sacks at a cost of $658.71, if advantage was taken of the discount, plus haulage charges of $74.00, totalling $642.71, which will be assumed by the Ziegler Construction Company in as much as they are now providing all the material and labour in their tender. May we be advised by airmail, in view of the fact that this company is commencing construction on Monday.

Re: Two-Room Indian Day School, Sarcee Reserve,
Stoney Indian Agency, Alta.

We have examined your file 120-1-5 Vol. 3 insofar as tenders for the above are concerned, and it is noted that Regional Supervisor Gooderham has had considerable difficulty in attracting contractors to submit tenders.

You will recall that this school was designed for erection by contract, and that specifications rather than a bill of material were furnished with working drawings. Unless the material is purchased and supplied through the Department, bills of materials are the responsibility of the Contractor.

We note that only two bona-fide tenders have been obtained by Indian Affairs namely:

(a) From the Watson Construction Co., General Contractors, Calgary, Alberta, dated August 20th, 1948, on the basis of cost, plus 10%.

Their estimated cost is .................. $35,500.00

(b) From the Zeigler Construction and Manufacturing Co., Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, dated July 30th, 1948, giving three alternatives as follows:

(i) Firm tender amounting to ............. $32,430.00

(ii) To supply labour, sand and gravel only, with balance of materials supplied by the Department .......... $19,516.00

(iii) With all materials supplied by the Department to carry out the work for a fee of 10% of the total cost or 12% of their established labour costs.

(iv) Estimating the cost of labour and materials to be $27,350.00.00, to carry out the work for a fixed fee of $2,560.00.

This cost is not justified.

Regarding (b), the tender from the Zeigler Co., it is noted that the tender under any alternative is subject to increase due to any rise in the cost of labour or material during construction.

Re: Teacher's Residence - Sarcee Reserve

The Rev. Mr. Lord, the new Anglican Missionary for the Sarcee Reserve, called at this office today. In view of the fact that the Sarcee Day School teacher, Mrs. Watson, is occupying a residence belonging to the M.S.C.O., he wondered if something could not be done about obtaining a reasonable rental for this building from the Department.

Since it is the policy of the Department to provide living quarters for day school teachers, I feel that we should pay some rental for the use of this house.

It is my understanding that the building was formerly a Mission Hall, but that it was made over into a residence for the use of the late Miss Timms. Though we have no record of this on file, I am of the opinion that the Department either paid for these alterations or contributed a portion of the cost.

It is known that the Mission is short of funds, and I would suggest that we pay a nominal rental of say $15.00 per month for the use of the building until such time as the new school and teacherage is completed. It is understood that the residence would revert to its former use when vacated by the present teacher, The Rev. Mr. Lord is writing the M.S.C.O. in this regard. If the Department approves of the rental, it should be paid from September first.

I wish to submit herewith Voucher No. 118, representing payment made to the City of Calgary for electric current consumed in the Sarcee Anglican Mission house for the month ending May 15th, 1948.

In regard to this voucher I wish to state that the Sarcee School teacherage is supplied water from the pump in the Mission house, piped into the teacherage. The account for this was paid by the Missionery, Rev. L.F. Rowe, in the past, but Mr. Rowe left here the 1st of April and the electric power was shut off from the Mission house, leaving the teacherage and school without water. I approached the Electric light Department and asked them to have this power turned on again to enable us to have water for these buildings assuring them that we would assume the payment for the current used.

Rev. Mr. Rowe approached me before he left stating that it would be expected that the Indian Affairs Branch should be expected to pay part of this electric light account in future, and as a new Minister has taken over the Mission house from June 1st I anticipate this will be brought up. As the only current used during the month mentioned was used pumping water for the teacherage and school I would suggest that this amount, $1.95 per month, be taken as a basis and the occupant of the Mission house re-imburse monthly to this amount.

M. MacLeod,

I have known in the past that this has been a customary practice at residential schools and the payment being made from the per capita grant to the schools, but as this is a day school and no grant being paid, I brought the matter up with the Chief and Council who were of the opinion that, inasmuch as no per capita school grant was paid on this reserve, extras of this kind should be paid from appropriation, but in the event of this not being approved they were agreeable to sign a resolution payable from Band Funds.

Dear Doctor Stone:

Your letter of March 16, addressed to Dr. Moore, has been referred to me. I discussed your letter with the Director several days ago, and as I informed you verbally before you left Ottawa, the Training Division is prepared to pay the salary of a teacher, on the understanding that the Hospital will provide living accommodation and board.

When a teacher is engaged, it is felt that she should not be required to perform any other duties than teaching. The number of hours per day during which she carries out her duties would of course be subject to your direction.

Please make enquiries with a view to obtaining the services of a qualified teacher, and when you are successful let me know her name and qualifications. At the same time you should make a recommendation regarding the monthly salary which we should allow her.

At the Coqualeetza Hospital we have been employing two teachers, one Catholic and one non-Catholic. I discussed this phase of the matter with the Director the other day, and he agreed with me that similar procedure should be adopted at the Edmonton Hospital. Possibly two teachers are not absolutely necessary at the present time, but no doubt the number of your patients will increase and subsequently two teachers will be required. You are in the best position to judge whether a Catholic or a non-Catholic teacher should first be employed.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your recent letter, the Archbishop of Edmonton has nominated a Mrs. Kernes as Roman Catholic School teacher at this hospital. This lady is the wife of a disabled war veteran, lives very near the hospital, has a permanent Alberta teaching certificate up to Grade 9, and has taught Grade 10. She has good inspector's reports, and seems suitable in every respect.

She expects to be paid the minimum salary of a qualified teacher in Edmonton which is $1500 per year for 10 months. She agrees, at this salary, to work a Civil Service year if so required, or with such holidays as the Medical Director may prescribe for the sick pupils. She will not expect maintenance.

It is recommended:

1. That you authorize engagement of Mrs. Kernes on the terms set out above.

2. That you authorize purchase of such Alberta text-books as she may prescribe, with scribblers, pencils, etc., or make provision for such supplies as you ordinarily do.

It would be a good thing to have the school started as soon as possible. Mrs. Kernes is ready to come on at anytime.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, May 3, 1946.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, with reference to the establishment of an Indian Day School at the Edmonton Indian Hospital.

I discussed the contents of your letter with the Director and we are prepared to allow the teacher $120.00 a teaching month, plus bonus of $18.42 a month.

In accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, we have to obtain an Order-in-Council for the establishment of a day school in the Edmonton Hospital before we can pay salary to the teacher. The necessary steps are being taken to obtain this Order-in-Council, which we expect will be passed in the near future. Mrs. Kerns may be allowed to begin duties at any time. I enclose the necessary forms which she should complete and return.

You may purchase approximately Fifty Dollars' worth of books to permit her to start at once, but additional books and classroom supplies should be ordered on requisition, in order to permit us to supply them through the Government Stationery Office.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. Stone forwarded to Mr. Hoey's letter authorizing this hospital to employ a second teacher, in the person of Mrs. Grantham.

In the few weeks that Mrs. Kerans, our present teacher, has functioned, we have nothing but praise for her efforts, and are agreeably surprised at the excellent response on the part of the patients. Both young and old have shown a desire to do school work, and with this number being well above the number that one teacher could reasonably handle, we are looking forward to the early arrival of the second teacher. She has already been notified, and I am quite sure will be available here very shortly.

We are enclosing a brief report on the school work covering a period of six (6) weeks. We hope that this report will give you some idea of the response that Mrs. Kerans has found in her work.

In the treatment of Tuberculosis, the occupation of the patients apart from their rest periods, is very important. The educational facilities serve a dual purpose. Firstly, to advance the educational level of our Indians, and secondly, to keep their minds occupied so there is less tendency to run around, or want to go home. This latter tendency is one of our major problems.

We would therefore like to express our sincere thanks for the efforts of your Department in making available these educational facilities.

Owing to admissions and discharges the number of patients receiving instruction fluctuates. Progress is evident in all cases. It is felt that the influence of this department is satisfying a desire in the lives of the patients. They look forward with eagerness to their lessons and supplementary readers.

Donations from various sources have increased our supplementary library from 130 to 273 books. Unfortunately many of these are in a poor state of repair. These books are circulated among approximately 100 patients. Many who had done little or no reading prior to admission are now regular and enthusiastic readers.

Meetings were held once a week with the doctor, charge nurse and occupational therapist, for the purpose of discussing the physical and mental capabilities of each patient. Thence, it was determined how much time could be safely devoted to each activity.

Weekly car rides were an established custom for high routine patients. Now the planning of these rides has been turned over to this department and organized excursions are made to places such as, University dairy barns, McGavin's Bakery, the Zoo, the Press and Canada Dry Bottling Works.

Visual Education has been recently introduced into the program. Once a month two educational films are shown in all wards with explanatory comments.

In answer to a need for a stimulant to the morale of the patients a monthly hospital newspaper, The Camsell Arrow, was inaugurated on Empire Day. The newspaper is used by the doctors as a medium for simple instruction relating to Tuberculosis and by the patients for the reporting of ward activities. Outstanding improvement has been noted in:
1. The ready response to requests for news.
2. The facility of expression (many news items are being printed verbatim).
3. The consciousness of others, as exemplified by the expression of laudable sentiments for those ministering to them.
4. The appreciation of simple humour.
5. The awakening to the possibilities of poetry.

The co-operation and courtesy of the staff at all times is very much appreciated, as also, the ready response of the Department in supplying our needs.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

Re: Treaty Indian Wm. Nelson

I am the Education Officer for D.V.A. at the Charles Camsell Hospital in a part time capacity. I am also a senior student for the B. Ed degree in the Faculty of Education University of Alberta and have several years teaching experience.

I was approached by Mr. Bruce through D.V.A. with regard to the above Nelson. After interviewing Mr. Nelson I find him a young man of fine personality, keen intellect, and lots of ambition. Working with Mr. Yates of the Correspondence School Branch we have recommended that Nelson register in Algebra I and French III to start with. I am going to administer some diagnostic tests in English and we will start him at the grade level indicated by the tests. When his plans are settled we will expand his course to include the required sciences and social studies. Because of his age, if he can handle the French III course he will be given credit in French I and II by the Dept. of Education in Alberta. Similarly with English, Social Studies, and Biology. This will save him considerable time.

Here is a little problem. He expects to be discharged from the hospital within a month or six weeks. Have arrangements been completed for him to become a resident of the Indian Residential School near Edmonton as you suggested to Col. B.F. Neary in your letter of 25 Oct., 1947?

After discussing his case we felt he could make much faster progress in correspondence courses than he could if
he went to school. I am quite willing to give him whatever assistance I can if he stays in or near the city. I feel he should be able to enter the Faculty of Education a year from this coming fall and so graduate in the spring of 1950 with an Elementary and Intermediate Certificate. I intend to do post graduate work here next year.

Would you please let me or Nelson know at your earliest convenience what will be done for him.

Thank you,

Yours sincerely,

Colonel Neary:

Charles Camsell Indian Hospital—Education:

With Mr. Supt. Robertson I discussed educational activities with the only teacher on duty, Mrs. Grantham. Her associate, Miss Ferguson, had been given special leave because of a bereavement in her family.

Occupational therapy has not been conducted since February when Miss Oakden left to take employment elsewhere. There is prospect that another appointment may be made in July.

Because of the absence of Mrs. Kerans, Mrs. Grantham has not been able to conduct motion pictures, although the National Film Board, in answer to your request, has been in correspondence with her.

Work with adults is to be resumed when Miss Ferguson returns. This is a department in which the teachers are very pleased with the progress which patients make. Some formerly illiterate adults can now write.

Patients who are eligible are being encouraged to take correspondence courses in high school subjects.

I suggested to Mrs. Grantham that she investigate the possibilities of educational radio broadcasts.

Mrs. Grantham requests consideration of the following suggestion: as it is difficult for bed-patients to write in scribblers, may an exception be made in their case and may they be permitted to write the words in the spaces provided in the work-books?

Dr. Meltzer has moved the teachers' office to a room where a washroom adjoins. There seems no need as yet for a classroom as the ambulant groups are very small. In lieu of the book-wagon previously suggested, a wheel-chair is
sometimes used.

No registers have been issued to these teachers. The work done is, of course, more important than the keeping of statistics on it, but we might consider further how best to keep the records of what is being done.

C.A.F. Clark

Dear Mr. Neary:

I regret very much that I was unable to find time during my short visit to Ottawa, to discuss our educational problems with you in person.

You may recall that I pointed out, that with our patient population increasing steadily, two teachers could not possibly handle the amount of work which should be done. At the present time we have 330 patients, and of these over 200 will require some tuition. I therefore urge that we be given permission to take on a third teacher.

Mrs. Kerans, who was our original teacher when we started, is doing very well from a health standpoint, and we hope to have her back on our staff by the fall. We have a Miss Ferguson who is acting in a temporary capacity until Mrs. Kerans is fit to return to her work; if we are allowed a third teaching position, I would think that Miss Ferguson should be seriously considered for this position. Mrs. Grahtham, who is our second teacher, has carried on very satisfactorily since Mrs. Kerans took sick.

You pointed out in our short talk, that if we have 3 positions, we are then entitled to appoint one of the teachers as Principal. If so, I would suggest that Mrs. Kerans be considered for this particular appointment.

As the above table shows the number of patients receiving instruction has increased considerably.

Mrs. Kerans was hospitalized on November 5, 1947. As a result of this it was found necessary for Mrs. Grantham to discontinue some of the established activities. Individual teaching of adults was temporarily stopped; but approximately twenty patients who were particularly keen carried on their work alone with the help of assignments and checking. Visual education was halted from January till May, 1948.

The time available was devoted chiefly to the instruction of the children of school age. The newly-aroused interest in reading for pleasure amongst adults was kept up and library books were distributed regularly. Two adult patients, admitted during this period, were enrolled in Correspondence Courses, one in Grade XII and one in Business English. Assistance and supervision were given them when necessary. The publication of "The Arrow" was continued with the circulation increasing to 350.

On May 1, Miss Z. Ferguson joined the staff as substitute and adult and visual education were again resumed.

The suggestions offered by Mr. C.A.F. Clark, Educational Survey Officer of Ottawa, on his visits were found very helpful. Acting upon one of these the National Film Board was contacted and since May, 1948, their films have been used regularly in our visual educational program.

On October 1 Mrs. Kerans resumed her duties and Miss H. Kammrath joined the staff. The work has been divided by wards. Because of the variance in grading, background, and physical condition of the patients, individual teaching has been found the most practical method. All activities have been resumed and the patients are showing interest and making progress.
To date we have listed 1744 books, including text books and supplementary books. Most of the fictional books have been donated by interested city organizations. As can be easily understood books, pencils, crayons, etc., have a very short life in an institution such as this. So the promptness of the Department in forwarding materials and books has been very encouraging.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Enclosed you will find a brief report
for the year, 1948, on the activities at the
Charles Camsell Indian Hospital Day School.

Our teaching staff is now much more
settled and with the three members now available
the work is proceeding at a much more efficient
level.

We now have 325 Indian and Eskimo
patients. This is an increase of practically 100
during the past year. It will be readily seen
that even with the increase of our staff to three
teachers the work is very heavy as practically
all the teaching is individual rather than to a
group.

You will see from the report that
there have been 276 patients taught during the year;
some of these were discharged reducing the final
number to 216. This is a very large number when
you realize that Mrs. Grantham carried on single
handed for a few months. Since the 1st October,
1948, our staff has been better able to cope with
the large assignment noted above.

Quite apart from the actual numbers being taught the quality of the work has been very good and we feel that quite a number of the people have shown more response in their school work here than they have shown in a much longer period at various schools elsewhere. We are very proud of this latter fact.

During our discussion in May, 1943, you mentioned that we could elect one of our teachers to be a principal. We have not forgotten this fact but we felt we would wait a longer period before making our decision.

The work of all three teachers at the present time is very satisfactory and I certainly feel we are fortunate in the quality of our teaching staff.

We appreciate very much the real co-operation shown by yourself and your Department in furthering the educational work at this hospital.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Neary;

Mrs. J. Kerans, one of our teachers, handed me your letter regarding two patients who are under treatment in this hospital, Mary Johnson, age 15 and Theresa Larocque, age 12.

As Mrs. Kerans has no control over patients unless we refer them to her I felt that I should answer your enquiry.

First of all these two children are not blind. Mary Johnson has moderately good vision but is suffering from trachoma. We are pleased to say that this condition is now under control and that she will be fit to carry on out of hospital very shortly. While she was on active treatment it was impossible to have her receive any tuition as the condition is contagious and besides rest to the eyes is important during the active phase of the disease.

Theresa Larocque is also much improved and has regained a fair percentage of vision.
She has a chronic eye condition which we now feel may have a Tuberculous basis. She has been treated with the new drug streptomycin with definite improvement. Here again we refrained from giving her any school work while we are actively treating her eye condition. We hope shortly that this girl can also carry on out of hospital.

Both children when they leave hospital can return to ordinary schools for their education as we do not feel they have sufficient loss of vision to class them in a special group.

H. Meltzer, M.D.
Medical Director.

Superintendent of Education: Nov 5, 1949

Charles Camsell Indian Hospital School:

I had a discussion with the four teachers today, meeting Mr. Dew for the first time.

As you are aware, Mrs. Grantham and Mr. Dew have asked for the $120 bonus for degrees.

Their worry is that conditions of work prevent them obtaining social science degrees or which the bonus for Grade 3 Welfare Teachers depends. They think that there is an element of unfairness that day school teachers get a bonus for degrees whereas welfare teachers get no recognition for "education" degrees. I told them that their qualifications are considered in making the original classification, and that, to my mind, there is considerable difference in the duties of welfare teachers in hospitals and welfare teachers on reserves where the social science aspects are emphasized. Hospital duty emphasizes pedagogy in the fullest American sense. Within the walls the social worker has little scope for her talents, and of course, it is true, as these teachers say, that social workers don't seek teaching jobs. And so, once again, I opine that perhaps hospital teachers may have to be classified apart from welfare teachers on reserves.

Supplies: For bed-patients the teachers would like to have E.H. Reid's Arithmetic Work Books

To accompany the Highlands readers above Grade 3 they would like the "My Literature Book" work-books.

Mr. Dew is an enthusiast for testing, especially in the aptitude field. I reminded him of the special considerations attaching to the testing of Indians. A few individuals for clerical or typing aptitude testing were all that are likely to be approved for some time yet. Perhaps one or two prospects for training as departmental employees may be found.

C.A. Clark

Depending on the Routine
Perhaps that may be true.

I walk into the children's ward,
My mind is quite at ease —
When suddenly a small boy says,
"Some water, Mister, please!"

I hurry up and get the drink
To quench the burning thirst
Of this dear child— and twenty more —
Each asking to be first.

I fill the pitcher to the brim,
And turning from the sink —
I hear another voice ring out,
"Don't bother with the drink."

"Jones has to go to X-ray —
Some dressings to be done —
The dinner wagon must be brought!"
It keeps one on the run!

I get Jones for the X-ray —
Am well upon my way —
When that same voice calls after me,
"Oh, I guess you'd better stay.

"Jones can wait till after lunch —
You go to Seven B."
I put the patient back in bed —
And hasten in to see.

A dozen voices all at once —
A dozen wants to fill —
A dozen errands to be run —
A pan, a drink, a pill!

I hurry to fulfill their needs,
I change a towel — a sheet —
I wipe a spot up here and there,
To keep them clean and sweet.

And then I rush for dinner trays —
They're nearly always late —
And think of all that could be done
While there I fume and wait.

(Continued on next page)
At last the trays are ready —
The dinner's finally served —
I hurry down to get my own
(If it has been reserved).

I eat a hasty dinner,
And hurry back to see
What's gone on while I've been gone —
But — OH DEAR, GOODNESS ME!
The soup's been spilled upon the floor
Potatoes on the wall —
The hinges broken off the door,
Pat Evans had a fall.

Jones hasn't been to X-ray,
The dressing still aren't done.
The rooms must also be tidied up—
BOY! Am I having fun!

And as the day draws to its close,
I hear that same voice say,
"Where is that LAZY ORDERLY?
What has he done to-day?"

H.W.

MRS. MONTURE SPEAKS TO CANADIAN CLUB

Brighter future for Canada's Indians is predicted by Ethel
Brant Monture, whose own life illustrates perfectly her belief that
the Indians are an up-and-coming group of people.

Mrs. Monture is the great-great grand-daughter of the celebrated
Mohawk chieftain, Joseph Brant. She is travelling across Canada on
a lecture tour. Last Friday she spoke to the Canadian Club here on
"The Indians of the Twentieth Century". She gave instances of how
her own people had fitted into the business and professional life
of the 20th century as magistrates, nurses and teachers.

For relaxation Mrs. Monture studies Spanish. First part of her
history of the Indians in the American Revolution, "West of the
Setting Sun" has had four printings, and she is at work on the
second volume.

WARD I C

Dear Friends,

Lent is starting now, so what kind of sacrifices are you going to make?

We girls in our ward are all trying to make some sacrifice during this season. Agnes Willier is trying her best to keep from looking out of the window, and trying not to be lazy. I have resolved not to "sneak" out of bed, and I have given up candies. This is a real sacrifice for me as I love candies and could eat a whole box in one day.

So friends, try to make some sacrifice during Lent, no matter how small it may be.

Elizabeth Bugle

WARD I D

I appreciate very much the opportunity of writing in the Arrow once more. All of us in Ward I D are doing well. One of our patients, who had been here for three weeks, went home yesterday. I hope we'll all go home soon.

My son, Maurice, came to the hospital on the eighth of January for an operation. He left for home again last week and I do hope that he does not have to come back to the hospital again.

(Mrs.) Harriet Buffalo

WARD I E

We have no news for the paper,
We haven't been out for days -
We know not of the fashions
Nor any worldly ways.

We didn't get our letters
And visitors were "taboo" -
Quarantined for days and days!
Enough to make us blue.

Kept to ourselves in old Ward E -
And all in the dark like weasels -
Because that Mary Murphy
She up and got the MEASLES!
WARD NEWS (Continued)

WARD I F

I take this opportunity of letting you know the news from our ward. We are feeling fine. We were in quarantine for measles for the past couple of weeks. We were allowed no visitors.

My husband came to visit me last month for the first time since I have been in the hospital. It was a big surprise for me.

We are sewing for our sewing teacher. We get paid for our work and it is nice to earn the odd bit of spending money.

All the girls in this ward are on Routine 1. We are trying to behave ourselves and get well. We wish to thank the doctors and nurses who are in charge of us. We hope and pray that you will all continue towards a speedy recovery.

Georgina Young

WARD I G

Ward I G has been invaded and taken over by the girls from Dawson City. They were flown here after the fire in the hospital there. Bessie Ellis, Rosalie Allen and Mary Shorty are all enjoying getting acquainted with the ways of the Gamsell; and although they come from so far North, are looking forward to meeting their first Eskimo in the hospital here.

WARD I H

Everything is fine in our ward. Our main recreation is playing the guitar and singing. We think we are better than "Them Tennessee Cowboys" — especially ward sister Mary Shortman. You should hear her when she starts singing "Best in the West". Everything in the ward stops to listen — even the curtains stop rustling.

From Maggie and Bella
(Please don't sign our last names, Thanks.)

WARD II A

One time Doris Beaulieu was wishing that she had a hundred dollars to her name. Josephine was doing the spending of it for her, and told her that she had used up NINETY-NINE dollars. "Don't worry," said Rosa. "You still have a dollar left."

Doris — Wonder what I'll get next Christmas.

Leonie — Your two front teeth!
WARD NEWS (Continued)

Victoria — What size are your stockings?
Rosa — 6 feet 5 inches long.

WARD II D to I

Hello One and All,

We are glad to be out of quarantine, after having been isolated for nearly two months for measles. We are glad, too, to see Mrs. Grantham again and happy to be back at our school lessons.

We send a special "Hello" up to Elise, our former ward-mate, who has been moved upstairs for her operation. We hope you are feeling fine and are looking forward to the time when you will be back with us again. Best wishes for a speedy recovery.

Rose Calihoo

We miss Celine Piche, who was discharged on the 27th of January, from Ward G. We also miss Violet Currie who went home this month.

One night Elsie Letendre wakened us all by calling in her sleep "Sally Black Socks! Sally Black Socks!" meaning, we suppose Sally Black Jack.

One afternoon Adeline Jackson and Bertha Quinn were ironing together. Bertha picked up one handkerchief and hastily ran the iron over it and handed it to Adeline. But to her surprise Adeline handed it back. It was not hers. It was Bertha's own. So Bertha was seen quietly slipping back to the ironing board and ironing the handkerchief VERY CAREFULLY on both sides and in all the corners!

Last month we spent in Ward II D —

Don't ask the reason why —

But now we're back in G again —

And aren't we GOOD — O-O-H MY!

The girls in Ward II G

Happy Easter
WARD NEWS (Continued)

WARD II D to I

We are glad to have Jessie Yellowbird and Gladys Willier from Ward VII in Ward Two I, and Shirley Geddes from Ward V B in Two H. We are glad to welcome, too, Louise Hoka Nocza from Hay River.

WARD III D

First of all we wish to say 'Hello' to all our local friends. As we are in quarantine at this time we cannot answer our mail. But just as soon as the sign is taken down we promise to write.

Bella Boysis had her operation and is now in a cast.

We think that Vivian Davidson is going to have a hard time packing all she has collected during her stay here. She expects to leave for Miller Bay at the end of the month. Has anyone an extra trunk to help her out?

Florence Johnson, Marie Metikassus, Beatrice Callihoo and Rema Bull are still the same as ever.

We are all hoping for an early cure, aren't you? Bea

Once an old lady went shopping. She couldn't speak English very well so her daughter made out a shopping list for her. Just as the old lady was leaving in the wagon her daughter ran out, "Chaskowa,(Wait), Please get two mantles for the gas lamp and a generator. I'll write it down for you."

"Namoia,(No), I'll remember." called the old lady.

So all the way to the store she kept repeating," Two mantles for the gas lamp and one generator!"

But somewhere along the way she got mixed up and so when, at the end of her shopping list, the clerk said,"Anything more?" the old lady answered,"Oh, yes, I want two gas bags and oh yes—one generation."

WARD III E

At last we have a chance to express our thanks to the doctors and nurses and the rest of the staff for all the work they did to give the patients an enjoyable Christmas. Everyone had such a lovely time.

Florence --(Pressing at the ironing board)

Flora -- Florence, my curiosity is getting the better of me,

What are you ironing?

Florence -- I am pressing the wrinkles out of my Grandpa's face — I mean his picture.
WARD NEWS (Continued)

WARD III E

Florence White Quills is worrying about her toy dog. She thinks it should be X-rayed, given a gastric wash and sent down for a rib operation. My opinion is that the dog has T.B. of the tail -- for he can't wiggle it.

- Lilly Many Bears

We all miss Mrs. Mary Many Chiefs. We miss her cheerful jokes and hope she will soon be back with us after her operation. We wish her and Mrs. Maryanne Many Fires a speedy recovery.

From Lilly Many Bears

P.S. Please excuse the many "Many"s.

For the first time Grandma Waghey had been weighed. She asked Lilly how much she weighed. Lilly explained "...100 lbs. flour, 20 lbs. rolled oats, 5 lbs. sugar and 1 lb. margarine. You catch 'em, Waghey?"

"I catch 'em!" smiled Grandma Waghey.

One night we were all very frightened and upset when we saw three lights north of our ward. When the nurse answered our bell she told us to get back into bed; that they were only fog lights.

WARD IV A

Here we are again to say a few words about our ward. First there are three of us in the P.O. ward: Max Wood, Marcel Mercredi, Jerry Chalifoux; Peter Nanda David Koomyak and Paul Gladu are in the private ward. Paul Gladu has just had his operation and is doing fine. We have wonderful nurses and ward aids who are doing their best for us.

I would like to thank all the doctors, especially Dr. Meltzer, who is doing his best for us. I thank the nurses, too. I never will forget what they are doing for us. Remember always, my friends, what good doctors and nurses and staff we have looking after us!

Jerry Chalifoux

WARD IV C

We certainly miss Olive Creighton, who has gone up for her operation. She is the "cheerer upper" of Ward IV C. Good luck, Olive, and don't have too many ribs out.
WARD IV E

HELLO!

We girls from Ward IV E would like to express our thanks to all the staff for their trouble and work in giving us such a wonderful Christmas. We surely did enjoy ourselves, but at the same time we felt sad, thinking about the Christmas back home.

But we know that we are here for our own good, so we pray and hope that we won't have to spend another Christmas in bed.

Hi Friends, We thank the doctors and nurses for trying to make us well and the teachers for showing us the shows—(we hope to have them often) and for providing lessons and books for us to read.

Mrs. Dolly Chief, sitting by the fire smoking her pipe, took the cure the "chicken" way! She tells us that if we take her advice and follow her way, we will get better soon—but we don't know what her advice is.

We are glad that we have had no measles in Ward IV, so far. (Touch wood, Ward IV.)

Lorraine usually gives us all the news from her paper. One day when she was reading her newspaper, she told us that British immigrants were coming to Canada. She said, "I always give you girls the important news. You should buy my candy. I spend all my money on newspapers and have no money left for candy."

WARD IV F

So far we are all still breathing and everyone doing well. Vicky S. is expecting to go up for her operation soon.

Margie is anxious to visit Dr. Meltzer once again—that means that she is anxious to have her operation.

We never seem to have much to say for the Arrow—but anyway you'll be hearing from us again in the next issue. Good Luck!

From the N.W. Girls

WARD IV G

There are seven of us here in this ward—five Eskimos, and two Indians from down south. We are quite a happy crowd. We had a movie on January 25 which was called "Hot Ice"—it was a very exciting hockey game between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the New York Rangers.
WARD IV G (Continued)

Bell — Tuberculosis is a very bad sickness, isn't it?
Dot — Yes, of course, it is, and what do you think you have?
Bell — Oh, I've got T.B.
Dot — Well, T.B. is just short for Tuberculosis and you have it!
Bell — (In surprise) Oh-hi! I thought that this Tuberculosis that they talk about over the radio was another kind of sickness much worse than T.B. And so I have this Tuberculosis!
Never mind, Bell, don't worry, you are doing fine! With the help of the doctors and nurses you will soon be well. We send a special thanks to our kind nurse, Miss Bentley.

WARD IV I

We welcome Martha back to our ward. We are all happy for her, now that she has completed her operations. Soon she expects to leave us and go back to Miller Bay Hospital. We shall miss her.

We can never express, too often, our gratitude to all the doctors and nurses for helping us to get better and to all those who have helped to keep us happy through our illness. Good luck to everyone in the hospital and a speedy recovery to every patient.

From the Happy Gang in Ward IV I

Martha Lewis has been taking lessons on how to sing Indian songs. One evening she had been singing so much that she sang in her sleep—but the song she sang in her sleep was so wild and spooky that it scared some of the patients. So now Martha has given up singing lessons and is learning to talk Cree instead!

Hubba Hubba Hubba!
Who wants to join the Hubba Club?
Interview the President,
No line-up yet, except Eva and Lillian.

WARD IV Sunporch

There is not much to relate here in the sunporch. Jane Moses and Louisa Wakheeniw are learning to yodel. It is their main pastime these days.

When the windows are open we often lie in bed and listen to the merry shouts and laughter of the children and adults, skating on the open-air rink just below our window. How we wish we could get up and watch them and find out what all the merry shouts of fun are about!
WARD NEWS (Continued)

WARD V A

Greetings Everyone, We hope that everyone is feeling as fine as we are. We were moved down to this ward in January and we like it as well as any of the other wards in which we have been. Mrs. Alice Monias, Anne Athanas and Mary Martel came from Ward I. Mrs. Nora Young, Moya Esumbo, Lucy Thomas, Paulette Anrodiluk and Bessie Jim came from Ward I Sunporch. Harriet Dennehy, a former patient, joined our number and a month ago Mrs. May Craft, from White Horse arrived after having been in the University hospital for a while. Bessie Jim and all the rest of us are happy to have her with us. We are sure she must be doing well because she is always laughing and joking. We all keep ourselves busy and have no time to be lonely.

Lucy Thomas got out of her cast a week ago. She will be put into a jacket after a while. We are looking forward to the time (which we hope won't be too long) when we shall "emerge from the chrysalis stage".

A special big 'Hello' to all the staff in Ward I and to all the patients, "Be of good courage."

WARD V C

Let us introduce the occupants of Ward V C: We'll start off with Henry "Carlson" Collinson, our salesman, who sells everything from safety-pins to greetings cards. Being such a high-pressure salesman, he once even sold some headache tablets to a nurse.

In the next bed we find Luke "Duke" Brown. He tickles the ivories like Duke Ellington -- hence the name. How about a boogie?

Turning around we find Horace "Slap Happy" Herron. "Happy" was a boxer before he landed in here and should have been a semi-pro by now. Tough luck, Happy, but keep your chin up-- you may be a promoter some day.

Next we come face to face with "Trigger Happy" Hodgson. He is also a disc jockey but is never happy unless he is pulling the trigger on his little "hip" shooter that Santa gave him last year. At present he is out of ammunition.

On the other side of the partition we find Jimmy "Scratch" Johnson-- "Scratch" because he is always scratching on his guitar.

(Continued)
WARD V C (Continued)

But don't make any mistake about this -- it is not all scratching -- he plays anything from Boogie to Hank Snow's "Two-Timer Woman".

Next is an old friend, Jean Marie "Wolf" Cardinal — "Wolf" because he is a mighty hunter. He has hunted bears, mooses (or is it moose?) and deer (both the four-legged and the two-legged kind).

Then we come to Peter "Checker Champ" Mountain — the undefeated Checker Champ of Cassell.

Now meet Jimmie "Hot Lips" Ominyak. He is striving to play the trumpet better than Harry James — hence the name. He says, "Harry James can play 'The Flight of the Bumble Bee' so I am going to learn to play 'The Flight of Two Bumble Bees.'" Good luck, "Hot Lips" every time I hear a bee — I'll think of you.

Next in line for introduction is William "Howdy Doo" Sewi — he never fails to say "Howdy Doo" to the gals every time he goes by the window.

And now the last in the bed is Jimmy "Take the Cure" Thompson. I guess you have something there alright, Jimmy. We should follow your fine example.

So there they are — the finest "bunch" of fellows that could be found all in one ward. A great big 'hello' from all of us to all you fellow patients wherever you may be. Keep smiling and always remember to keep your face to the sun and you'll reach your goal.

— Harry Gray

WARD V R

We are only little girls and all of us are in casts but we are happy and try to be good. Mary Tomenguk left us two weeks ago. She has gone to Edmonton Indian Residential School. Last week Ann Jonas went home to Dawson City. Esther Powderface has no radio just now and we miss it. Florence Drybones, Elizabeth Ilaiyak, Elsie Mercereau, and Rose Dumas are learning to speak English and chatter all the time. Annie Jackson, Annie Moosewah, Augustine Blessé and Thelma D'Or are doing well in their school work.

One day the dinner trays had just been passed. It was a lovely dinner. There were spare ribs! Suddenly one of the little girls squealed with delight, "OH-H-H-H GOODY. BONES!"
WARD VI A

Once again it is my privilege to write a message for the Camsell Arrow — a special 'thank-you' to the doctors and staff who are doing all they can in every way to get us well again. We were transferred over here to Ward VI A not very long ago. We like our new home very much. Don't expect very much from us, as all of us, except three, are in casts. Before closing we would like to wish all the Arrow readers a happy and prosperous 1950.

From the Boys of Ward VI A

Hello Everyone,

On the eve of my discharge from the hospital I would like to express my heartfelt appreciation for the acts of kindness from the doctors, nurses, teachers and everyone on this staff. You have all been wonderful to me during my long stay in the hospital. It is grand, for me, after having been sick for so many years to be able to be on my feet again and looking forward to going home to see all my loved ones again. Best of luck to you all, boys, as I go, and remember, all of you, try your best to do what you are asked to do, so that you, like I, may get better soon. Thanks.

Sincerely,

Robert Laboucon

WARD V I B

This is the first time that I have written for the Arrow and I have not much to say except to offer my thanks, too, to the doctors and the staff who are helping us get well.

Our teacher, Miss Kammerath, brings picture shows every week to Ward VII and VIII. We enjoy them very much indeed.

Fred Cleary, our violinist, gave a demonstration of his ability the other night. This was well-appreciated by his fellow room-mates. The applause brought an encore, "The Devil's Dream" with guitar accompaniment by Isadore Gladu and Buzzie (Baptiste Abraham).

Mr. Burnstick enquired of me, one day, if the thermometer was used each day as part of the cure for T.B. I told him it was. So, since then, Mr. Burnstick has been taking his own temperature four and five times a day.

WARD IX B

Jim Collison

We wish to welcome a new patient, Fred Marcel, who seems to be getting along well.

Louis Henault is getting to be quite a guitar player and singer. He also is an expert radio mechanic — so if any of you have a radio that needs fixing just send it along to Ward IX and Louis will fix it for you. Charges are moderate.

WARD IX C

It is a pleasure for me to be writing for the Camsell Arrow. On behalf of the boys here, I want to wish everyone a speedy recovery in the year 1950.

There have been a great many changes in our ward recently. Most of us have been transferred to this ward from Ward V C. We miss the old ward and the boys. Keep up the good work in taking care of yourselves. We are doing fine and hope that if we keep on improving, we may be heading home by spring.

I shall have been here three years on the eleventh of June. During that time I have had one set-back; that was four months after I came in. No one knew whether I would pull through or not; but with the help of the doctors and nurses I did. I often recall those days. To think I was once a hopeless case makes me feel that almost anyone can get well again if he co-operates and follows the rules that are given him by the doctor in charge. So now that I am feeling quite well again I would like very much to express my feeling of gratitude to the doctors and nurses who have helped me in a lot of my difficulties in these past few years. (Continued)
WARD IX C (Continued)

I have a great deal to thank them for and it seems that words cannot quite adequately express my feeling of gratitude. Hoping that you will all understand what I mean and wishing you all a very prosperous future and success in your work.

about 30 beds but there is no doctor. We hope to have a new doctor for Fort Rae before many months and he will then run the hospital in the same way as the one at Resolution. Eskimo Girl Guides Practice For a Visit

Two hundred miles inside the Arctic Circle, the world's most northern company of Girl Guides is preparing for an inspection visit from Beth Riddoch of Edmonton, field Secretary for Alberta.

Dorothy L. Robinson, formerly of Ottawa, - school teacher - is the leader of the Girl Guides and Brownies. She has 20 little Eskimo and Indian girls practising their calls, knots and songs for the visit next month.

Most Guides and Brownies in the Territories are native Eskimo and Indian children but gradually white people are moving in. They are bringing their Guide traditions with them and the companies are growing.

The young girls follow the same rules as the other 68,000 Guides throughout the country with a few interesting variations of their own. They wear the same blue uniform as the Canadian Guides but add a fur-lined parka and a flowered cotton outer dress, gay with color over the parka.

To the Patients and Staff of the Charles Camsell Hospital,

With the advent of the New Year the Superintendency of the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital became my responsibility. I wish to assure you that my first concern will be for your comfort and better health and I will do all in my power to maintain the high standard and reputation already gained for the Hospital.

Dr. Meltzer has been in charge of this Hospital since its inception as a treatment unit under the Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare. His professional ability as a surgeon has been recognized for years; his good judgment in the administration of the Hospital has been well demonstrated; his devoted service in organizing and establishing the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital, as a treatment centre for tuberculosis that can be compared favourably with any in Canada, is well-known to you all. We are extremely fortunate in that Dr. Meltzer will continue as consultant and surgeon in the services of this Hospital. I trust that this institution will continue to flourish at its present high standard as long as it is required in the treatment of Tuberculosis, as a tribute to his work.

I solicit the loyal support and co-operation of both staff and patients so that the function and duties of this great institution will be well and ably accomplished.

So at the beginning of this new year I would like to close my first message in the Arrow with my best wishes for both your happiness and improved health for the future.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.,
Medical Director
IN APPRECIATION

Editor, Bulletin - We wish to publicly thank and gratefully acknowledge the kindness shown to our Indian, Eskimo and D.V.A. patients at this hospital during the past year and especially during the Christmas season.

An exceedingly happy holiday season was enjoyed by all those who were confined to their beds and away from their homes and families. This Christmas cheer was made possible by numerous organizations and individuals, who generously contributed financial aid, gifts, time and energy.

In particular we wish to specify: Hospital Recreation Council, The T.Eaton Co. Ltd., Elks' Club, Canadian Legion, Rotary Club, Catholic Women's League, Fort Vermilion Merchants, I.O.D.E. (Provincial Chapter), Kinsmen Club, Lions' Club, Kinette Club, Gyrette Club, Cosmopals, Daughters of the Midnight Sun, Tuesday Night Club, Ladies' Auxiliary of Fraternal Order of Eagles and many others too numerous to mention.

H. Meltzer, M.D.

Christmas, 1949

As this is the first issue of the Camsell Arrow since Christmas we feel that it is still not too late to express our most sincere thanks to all the organizations and private persons who made such generous donations of money, gifts and time to help make our fourth Christmas the best yet. A hearty 'thank you' is also due to the staff of all departments of the hospital - without whose co-operation we could never have had such a successful Christmas season.

WELCOME DR. FALCONER

On behalf of the patients and staff the "Arrow" extends a hearty welcome to Dr. Falconer and his family. Dr. Falconer has devoted many years to bettering the health of our Indians and Eskimos. We are very fortunate to have his services as Medical Superintendent. Already he has shown keen interest in the welfare and progress of our patients. His presence at the staff conferences, his frequent visits to the wards and his desire to acquaint himself with every patient by name, history and progress are proof of his genuine concern.

Our superintendent's first task is to make available for each patient the best and surest cure for his disease. Secondly, he must try to make each patient's stay in the hospital as happy and as comfortable as possible. To these ends we will all give him our best efforts.

We hope that Dr. Falconer, Mrs. Falconer, Janet and David will spend many happy years here.

William R. Barclay, M.D.

GAMSELL PATIENTS WIN IN ESSAY CONTEST

Congratulations are in order for six of our Gamsell patients for winning second prize in the recent Tuberculosis Essay Contest sponsored by the Alberta Tuberculosis Association. Two essays were entered, one in the High School division, written by Thomas Aneroluk, and one in the Intermediate division, written by Beatrice Callhoo, Minnie Sankey, Vivian Davidson, John Pascal and Harry Gray. These essays were judged in competition with other Indian schools. Because our hospital conditions are not like ordinary classroom conditions, it was decided by the Association that it would be fairest if the marks on the two essays were averaged and that mark taken. This plan gave us second prize.

Though this represents the first attempt of our patients to engage in such competition, we hope that many more opportunities will present themselves either for individual patients or for groups of patients.

The first Eskimo baby to be born in Alberta, the wee daughter of Mrs. Milly Apolotuk, (a patient in the hospital) was christened "Mary Margaret" by the Right Reverend Bishop Barfoot assisted by Archdeacon Clough in the chapel on Thursday, March 2. Doris Kikpak, patient, and Mrs. Edwardson, daughter of the Archdeacon were the godparents.
CAMSHELL HOSPITAL CHIEF SEES BIG YEARS AHEAD

By Stanley Burke
Bulletin Staff Writer

Indians of Alberta and the North West Territories have a death rate from tuberculosis sixteen times as high as that of the general Canadian public - but quiet, greying Dr. W.L. Falconer predicts that in five years the incidence of this scourge should be halved in the Indian population.

For Dr. Falconer, his new job as Medical Director of the Charles Camsell hospital represents the achievement of an ambition.

As a young doctor in the mining fields of northern Manitoba in the late 20's, he was shocked to see the conditions under which the native population lived and died. He did what little he could to aid them but it was a hopeless task.

"I remember a time when twenty out of a band of a hundred died of whooping cough. It makes a powerful impression when you see five or six children, all with tuberculosis, lying on the floor of a shack under a single, dirty, old blanket in forty below weather," said Dr. Falconer.

In 1938 he was able to do more effective work when he became medical superintendent at The Pas for the Indian Health Services; but it was still a near-hopeless task. His patients were almost always dying before they arrived for treatment.

In 1945, he came to Edmonton as assistant to the director of Indian Health Services, to make a report on the buildings for the proposed Camsell hospital. The new hospital would be the largest of its kind in Canada, serving 21,000 Indians and Eskimos in Alberta, the Yukon and the Northwest Territories.

"I've wanted this job ever since I first saw the place," he said. "It has everything. The University is nearby for teaching purposes. We have good transportation by rail and air to get the patients in to the hospital. We have everything we need here to do a real job."

Dr. Falconer succeeds Dr. Herbert Meltzer, under whose direction the hospital has already made almost startling progress. Last summer 20,000 chest X-rays were made so that now records are available

(Continued)
CAMSELL HOSPITAL CHIEF SEES BIG YEARS AHEAD (Continued)

for almost every Indian and Eskimo in the hospital's territory, something which has never been achieved with a similar group in the white population.

Since 1944 the incidence of tuberculosis in the Indian population of Alberta has been almost halved.

Dr. Meltzer, a noted tuberculosis specialist and surgeon, is returning to private practice. He will continue surgery at the hospital.

"It has been a hard struggle to win the Indians' confidence but we are making excellent progress now," said Dr. Falconer. "You've got to start them going back cured to the reserves. That's the important thing. The Indians used to say, 'Our people go to your hospitals and we never see them again.'"

POLYGLOT RADIO BROADCAST

Before Christmas I visited CHFA, the French radio station in Edmonton, to meet the manager Mr. Gareau, and we had a little chat about the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital. I expressed the wish for a few minutes over the air, so that the patients could send their wishes to their folks in their own language. Mr. Gareau replied, "Well, Father, we will give you a half-hour programme on New Year's Day at 2 P.M. for the patients of Charles Camsell." Next day I was very pleased. So back to the hospital I went spoke to Dr. Meltzer and Dr. Falconer about it, and started to organize the programme.

A few days before New Year's Day Mr. Bouvier, of the National Film Board, came with machines to record our programme. We first had a word of introduction from Mr. Gareau. He stated that it was a pleasure for him to give the patients this opportunity to speak to their folks. In Doctor Meltzer's office we recorded messages from Dr. Meltzer, Dr. Falconer, Miss Taylor (Matron), Mr. Capel (Accountant) and Mrs. Kerana (Teacher). Archdeacon Clough was absent so his message had to be recorded.

From the doctor's office we moved around the wards to pick up the messages of the patients. Unfortunately we did not have enough time to broadcast all the messages taken as we were limited to the half-hour. We first heard messages in Eskimo for Coppermine and Aklavit; in Selkirk, Carmak, Clinket and other languages for Yukon; in Loucheux, Hareskin, Slave, Beaver and Dogrib for the North West Territories; and in Chipewyan, Cree, Stoney, Sarcee and Blackfoot for the Alberta Indians.

We also had on our programme a lady, Dr. Demchenko, who spoke in Ukrainian and, too, a young girl, Christiana MatwieJozyk, who spoke in Polish.

Let us hope that in the near future we will again have the opportunity to organize another polyglot programme.

(Continued)
Dr. Meltzer:
I am very pleased to have this opportunity of saying "Hello" to the many friends of this hospital in the North. I am particularly anxious to speak to our many ex-patients scattered from Fort Smith to the Arctic and through the Yukon Territory. To you ex-patients I say: Take good care of yourselves and all will be well. For 1950 I wish you all good health, happiness and prosperity. This same wish carries to our many friends as well.

We in the Camsell Hospital will always be ready and anxious to serve the northern population of our wonderful country - Canada. I will say again "au revoir" and Best Wishes for the New Year!

Dr. Faloon:
Father Rheaume has very kindly given me this opportunity to say a few words to you in way of greeting. I am assuming the Directorship of the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital the first of the year, taking over from our good friend, Dr. Meltzer. I trust the good work he so ably started and has carried on so well during the past four years will be continued.

It has been recognized that this Hospital is filling a long-needed requirement. Tuberculosis is still taking a tremendous toll on the health and lives of the first citizens of Canada, and increasing effort with the co-operation of all concerned, is necessary to gain control of the disease and to decrease the death rate. Your co-operation in attending surveys and seeking treatment when it is indicated, is needed to reduce the rampage of this dread disease.

Now on behalf of The Honourable Minister Mr. Paul Martin; the Director of Indian Health Services Dr. P.E. Moore and the Staff of the Hospital, who are all vitally concerned in your health and welfare, I wish you a Happy and Healthy New Year.

Miss Taylor:
On behalf of the nursing staff I would like to wish you all a very happy New Year and the best for 1950. I hope that this year will see many more of your friends and relatives restored to health and back home with you. The nurses join us in sending greetings and best wishes to all of our ex-patients. Happy New Year!

Mr. Capel:
I have been asked to convey to all our friends in the North, Best Wishes for the New Year on behalf of the staff of the Camsell Hospital.

Having been received into many of the homes in Dawson City, Whitehorse and all other Yukon Territory points, as well as in the North West Territories -- in particular Fort Simpson, Fort Resolution, Hay River, Fort Smith and Fort Chipewyan-- I wish to assure you all that your brothers, sisters, mothers and fathers, husbands and wives, are being excellently cared for here, and everything possible is being done for them. They are very happy and contented and we hope that they will soon be home with you again.

Mrs. Kerans:
On behalf of the teaching staff I wish to extend our best wishes at this festive season to all the ex-patients and friends of the hospital.

We miss you but are pleased that you are able to be at home with your family, relatives and friends. We had the usual Christmas activities -- decorations, parties, Santa Claus parade on Christmas Eve and a special dinner on Christmas day.

We are always glad to hear from you and thank you for your letters which we have received from time to time.

May you enjoy health, happiness and prosperity in the New Year.

E. Rheaume, O.M.I.
The following is an account of a trip by air from Edmonton, Alta., to Cambridge Bay, N.W.T., for the purpose of examining a little Eskimo boy who had received an injury to his eye. We left the Edmonton airport around noon on Dec. 13 in an RCAF Dakota aircraft, with our immediate destination being the town of Fort Nelson, B.C. There is an Air Force station at this port, which we reached uneventfully after about four hours' flying. There we spent the night as guests of the RCAF.

Take-off was at 5:30 the following morning, while the post was still in darkness. Our next stop was at a small landing strip on the shores of Great Bear Lake at a place called Sawmill Bay. We landed on the snow-packed runway there at about 10:00 a.m., and had a cup of coffee while our aircraft was re-fuelled. Then we took off on the last lap of the journey to Cambridge.

Shortly beyond Sawmill we could see that the trees below us, which had formerly been packed tightly over the land, were now beginning to thin out. As we continued on to the north they became still smaller and farther apart, and eventually disappeared altogether. We had passed the tree-line and were now in the Arctic.

The country below us now could scarcely be called country at all, or at least it appeared from the air. That land there was was low, smooth, covered and featureless, so that it was difficult to tell which was land and which was sea. One of the members of the crew quoted a phrase which described pretty well this portion of terrain. He described it as consisting of "endless miles of absolutely nothing, spread very thinly, over an exceedingly large area". No one argued with him.

We reached Cambridge Bay at about 2:00 o'clock in the afternoon of Dec. 14th, and the midnight sun, which is as much light as one gets in that part of the country at this time of the year. The salt-ice of the bay was not yet thick enough to permit a landing to be made there, so the men at the station had prepared a landing strip on a small lake about two miles beyond the settlement. We landed on this runway, between the two pairs of rows of glowing flare-pots which marked its boundaries. As we looked out of the window into the semi-darkness we could see the Eskimo children dressed in their deerskins playing in the snow.

It was only 20 below at Cambridge on that particular day, but there was a cold north wind blowing. We stayed there an hour and had a good meal while the aircraft was again re-fuelled, then we loaded our little patient aboard and took off for home.

It was now quite dark, and was to remain so for the remainder of the trip. We came down at Sawmill again about 10:00 o'clock that night to pick up some more gas, and then flew on to Edmonton. We arrived at about 3:00 o'clock in the morning. It had been a long day and we were all ready for a good sleep.
"I WENT NORTH."

-- Dr. J. T. Orford

Edmonton was only 30 below zero in January so I went North where it was more comfortable at 40 below. This was my first trip into the western side of sub-Arctic Canada. I expected to see something quite different to what I had known in the East. It was a surprise, but not a disappointment, to find that the people were just the same types as in the James and Hudson Bay areas. They live in similar houses and tents, hunt and trap in much the same manner and eat the same foods.

My first stop was Fort Resolution which is quite a settlement. There is a new hospital here, which can handle eighty cases of Tuberculosis. Dr. Greenidge, the doctor at Resolution, is very enthusiastic about his big job of helping to stamp out this disease. The hospital is run along the same rules as the Camsell. Dr. Greenidge does pneumothorax and pneumoperitoneum treatment and has Streptomycin which he uses upon advice from here. The purpose of the hospital is, first of all, to cure Tuberculosis. It is planned to use the hospital for admission of all local cases of T.B. Full treatment will be carried out there, whenever possible; but when a patient needs surgery, he or she will be brought to the Camsell where that part of the treatment will be taken care of.

There is a beautiful new Public School at Resolution. It was built by Indian Affairs Branch and will probably be opened this summer. It is modern in every respect and is just as well equipped as any school in Edmonton. It is heated by huge oil furnaces, has electric light and running water. I must say it makes one envious -- I wish I were a boy again and could start school all over. The school I attended was a little stone building in the country with a big wood stove in the centre, a coal oil lamp and outside "conveniences". That was in well-populated southern Ontario -- and to think that nowadays such a wonderful building can be built at such a northern spot as Fort Resolution. The Indian boys and girls should be "tickled pink" to go to school there.

I also visited Fort Rae. This is a much smaller village than Resolution but there are many more Indians in the surrounding hunting grounds. There is a hospital at Fort Rae also of (Continued)

Charles Camsell Indian Hospital

Please find attached the magazine published by our teachers at the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital, Edmonton, Alberta. Among their many other duties as hospital teachers, they act as editors of this little magazine. AT CHARLES JAMSSELL INDIAN HOSPITAL SCHOOL
EDMONTON, ALBERTA - APRIL 1, 1950

The above table shows a net increase of 60 patients receiving instruction in the past eleven months. In August, 1949, a fourth teacher joined the staff which made it possible to assume the heavier patient load.

Many adults and children admitted to hospital learn to read while here. These patients require additional instructional time. Over the last year the child population has remained fairly stationary while the adult population has increased by one-third. There are also a number of youngsters between five and six years of age who will be ready for school work by September 1, 1950.

The average patient population per teacher is 85, which is above the number most educational authorities consider that one teacher can properly handle.

Prior to September 1 each ward had one show per month. At the request of the medical staff, since then, the program in the boys' wards was increased to one a week. This overall program entails 31 showings per month. The films are of an educational and recreational nature and are obtained from the National Film Board in Edmonton, and the University of Alberta Extension Department.

The Camsell Arrow, the hospital paper, is now being published six times annually with a special pictorial review in the first issue of each year. Copies reach the agencies (the superintendents report that the agency copies posted on the bulletin board are well-thumbed before the arrival of the next issue), field stations, other sanatoria, residential schools as well as many individuals in Canada and U.S.A., and organizations who have become interested in this hospital. One organization uses the Arrow as part of its campaign toward Tuberculosis control. Many patients after reading the copies send them home where they help to build goodwill between the relatives and the hospital. The circulation of the paper has doubled in the past two years. The Arrow is serving many purposes as far as the patients are concerned: it is instructional, it improves their written expression and serves as a means of communication between patients.

The supplementary library now contains about 2000 books, the majority of which have been donated. The interest in reading is increasing steadily. Every patient above grade two level is encouraged to begin reading for pleasure. All available dictionaries are distributed among the patients who use them intensively in an effort to improve their pronunciation and interpretation. Many become so interested that they buy a dictionary of their own, so that they may take it home. It is felt that more dictionaries than those required for hospital use, should be provided in order to help the less fortunate patients who are unable to buy their own, so that they, too, may have one to take home, to help keep alive the interest in reading aroused while in hospital.

In December 1949, two entries from groups of patients were submitted in the Alberta Tuberculosis Health Essay contest. They were awarded second prize in the Indian Schools' competition. This was the first in a series of such annual competitions.
As part of the welfare program, encouragement and assistance in writing letters home are given to all. Many children have to have the letters written for them. This is done to improve the parent-patient relationship and to make the patient feel that he is still a part of the family group.

Since all instruction is individual bedside teaching, and in view of the foregoing and other welfare activities, it is felt that in order to fulfill the needs of these patients, further additions in teaching staff are required.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Hospital Schools - Records and Reports

It seems to me that a beginning could be made by the use of records that would give a more objective appraisal of each individual who is receiving or who is expected to receive the hospital teacher's attention. I have discussed this with teachers in various hospitals inviting them to make suggestions as to how this can be done. I have put forward the suggestion that for each case the approach might well be clinical. The individual differences to be considered seem to compel the use of a cumulative record card and a folder file for each individual. On this record would appear the appraisal of the pupil's initial educational state i.e., a diagnosis in the pedagogical field, the tentative plans of the teacher adjusted to the pupils' needs, interests and hospital routines. It might help if we could have a description of the routines in vogue at each hospital with the Medical Superintendent's opinion as to what mental and physical activity is allowable for each routine. I mention this because I am not sure that the routines are standardized for all the sanatoria in which schools are operated. For example, the Government of Canada operates the Charles Camsell Hospital, but the Government of Manitoba operates those within that Province.

I anticipate that the Medical Superintendents may have misgivings if the proportion of diversional therapy is reduced by the intrusion of mental disciplines in the earlier stages of hospitalization, and some of the teachers, just as they do in some classrooms, would rather keep the pupils busy with handwork than attempt the task of making them literate, because such teachers are not expert in the techniques of teaching reading.
On the basis of such individual records we could evolve a report form summarizing the statistics which we think are significant and thus leave out a great deal of paper work which Mr. Dew in his faithful attempts to report the situation in his hospital school has thought proper to forward. For example a summarized report, rather than giving the Grade of each pupil might rather give the number of pupils receiving instruction in subjects in the various Grades as the individual profile is scarcely likely in many cases to be suited to the work of all subjects in one Grade.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.
