Dear Doctor Moore:

Re: Educational Work and Occupational Therapy at
the Charles Camsell Indian Hospital.

The above-mentioned departments in this hospital are doing a great deal of work, but in my opinion this could be better organized. The teachers are conscientious and work hard in the time available to them; they have nearly 300 patients taking courses. They apparently receive sufficient supplies, but the necessity of individual instruction, and the curtailed period in which this instruction may be given, due to rest periods, limits the amount of teaching the staff can carry out -- even by working Saturday mornings.

Occupational Therapy is still more limited in that we have only one full-time therapist, and she has far too much to do. When this department was organized, an allotment of funds on a revolving basis was made, and it was considered that this department should be self-supporting from the sale of the various articles made. As a result, the work has been confined to too narrow limits: Patients have been led to believe that they will be paid for whatever they do, and the standard of some of the work is actually below market demands. Supplies are limited to purchases which can be made from funds realized from sales. We have no special place that can be allotted as a work shop where the patients on higher routines could work at prescribed hours.

Both Occupational Therapy and ordinary school work in themselves are of great value, provided the patient is kept interested and contented. When they become a monotonous drudgery they lose their value as therapy. Our patients are in hospital for relatively long periods of time, and when they are discharged they are usually on restricted activity for years, if not for the rest of their lives.
Our aim should be not only to give them a good general education, but to interest and prepare them for some form of activity by which they can hope to make a living when they return home.

In my opinion, the Occupational Therapy and Education branches should be organized under one chief who had special training which fits him to evaluate the talents and abilities — particularly of the adult patients — in much the same way as vocational advisers in high schools.

I do not intend this as a criticism to the present educational staff, but do feel that some improvement can and should be made. I had a long discussion recently with Mr. Dew, the head of our Education Branch, Miss Hopkins, the Occupational Therapist, Miss Taylor, the Matron and Mr. Horns, the Business Manager, and the consensus of opinion is that a more adequate program is required and could be devised. It is felt that some person especially interested in this type of education should visit the hospital, investigate the matter and make recommendations. I feel that Col. Neary is well fitted for this task and we would appreciate a visit from him at the first opportunity.

Yours very truly,

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Medical Director.

Dear Mr. Neary,

According to the Indian School Bulletin issued last September welfare teachers are required to have a degree in social service work in order to receive salary allowances for university training. Inquiries that we have made indicate that such a degree is obtainable only by attending winter sessions at certain universities.

Two members of the hospital school staff now hold degrees, one a Bachelor of Arts from McMaster University and the other a Bachelor of Education from the University of Alberta. The other two members are working toward a Bachelor of Education and a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Alberta.

During the winter session courses are offered to Edmonton teachers after school hours or on Saturday mornings by the University of Alberta toward these degrees. The members of this hospital school staff would like to avail themselves of this opportunity to complete undergraduate degrees or to work toward post-graduate degrees, if arrangements could be made. As the hospital school hours are longer, due to required rest periods, than regular day school hours and as we work Saturday mornings, it precludes attendance at these lectures. As welfare teachers we can only attend Summer School every three years, which makes it difficult to complete a degree within a reasonable time.

In view of the foregoing, is it possible that arrangements might be made whereby at least a part of the staff could attend these Saturday morning lectures and that credit would be given for degrees other than Social Service degrees?

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.
August 17, 1950.

Mr. Fred N. Dew,
Charles Cassell Indian Hospital School,
Edmonton, Alberta.

Dear Mr. Dew:

I have received your letter of July 25, and we are quite prepared to permit certain of the teachers to not conduct Saturday classes in order that they might attend sessions at the University of Alberta.

I regret, however, that there can be no change with regard to the credit for Social Service degrees. The classification of welfare teacher was set up primarily for teachers on isolated Indian reserves who could do welfare work in addition to their normal teaching duties. I could not recommend exceptions for hospital teachers.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard P. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

General Correspondence
Michel School
I beg to inform the Department that the Indians at the north end of the Michel Reserve have asked me for a day school for their children saying that they have 19 of school age ready to attend the school (10 of these are already in the St. Albert S school but they want them to leave to attend the day school). The farthest and the most of the children reside with their parents about one and a half mile from where the school site is proposed to be and others are a mile and a quarter. I have explained to them the unreasonableness of the application but they were very determined that I should write the Department on the matter. The cost of building and maintaining the school and paying a school teacher would be wholly inadequate for the results to be obtained. It is however for the Department to make decision in the matter and not for me.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH.

Stony Plain Indian Day School
Michel Indian Day School

In our 1947-48 estimates we have included the sum of $8000.00 for the construction of a one-room day school and residence for the Michel reserve in the Edmonton agency.

We have also included the sum of $8000.00 for the construction of a one-room school and residence at Saddle Lake reserve in the Onion Lake agency (this latter agency is included in our Alberta Inspector's district).

On his recent visit to this office Mr. Gooderham our Inspector of Agencies for Alberta pointed out the necessity for a school at Stony Plain in the Edmonton agency. In view of his reports it has been decided to build a one-room school and residence at this reserve rather than at Saddle Lake. Therefore, would you delete Saddle Lake from our list and substitute Stony Plain.

These two reserves are located some forty miles apart and are only twenty-five miles from Edmonton. Therefore, one contractor may be interested in obtaining the bids for both buildings. Would you please arrange to have one of your officials in Edmonton contact Mr. Robertson our Indian Agent there and visit these sites as soon as possible.
It is understood that you have completed now the plans and specifications for a standard one-room day school and teacher's residence which we intend to construct this year. Therefore, if you would air mail them to Edmonton, we hope the advertisement to appear in the Edmonton newspapers by May 15th. We are most anxious that these constructions be advertised for as soon as possible, as we understand from Mr. Gooderham that there is an opportunity of having bids entered if we advertise early enough in the Spring.

[Signature]

Director

BFN/HM.

The location chosen at Michel Reserve is in the South-east corner or the S.E. ¼, 25-54-27-W4M. At Stony Plain Reserve, the site chosen is approximately one half (S.W.¼ Sec. 22) mile west of the Agency and two hundred yards south of the road. Both of these locations were inspected and approved by Mr. McNair and Mrs. Peatfield, of the Engineering Branch, Banff, on May 13th and 14th.

At Michel Reserve the site is covered with light poplar and it will be necessary to brush and level about 400 feet square. At this reserve they do not have much trouble in securing a supply of water at about 35 to 40 feet, and I would suggest that a bored well, 3 ft. hole, well into the gravel, would give a sufficient supply, and I would request that when the school site is located on the property by the Architect, that I be given authority to bore a well as close to the building as possible.

The cost of boring a three foot hole at Michel would be $2.00 a foot, estimated depth 40 feet. The well driller suggests that the most permanent type of casing would be regular wooden casing in the bottom with about 12 feet of cement casing on the top. The wooden casing costs $1.00 per foot and the cement casing $3.00 per foot.

The cost of drilling a deep well is about $1.25 per foot and the cost of 6" casing is $1.50 per foot. The well would probably have to be drilled to a depth of about 400 feet.

Memorandum:

Michel Indian Reserve.

Acting upon instructions, the writer, accompanied by the Indian Agent of the above Reserve, Mr. E.A. Robertson, inspected several prospective sites for a combined one room school and teacherage for the above mentioned Reserve.

The area chosen (2.05 Acres) lies on level land, all thickly covered with scrub willow and poplar 2" - 3" in diameter. TO HIS EXCELLENCY,

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined one room Indian day school and teacher's residence on the Michel Reserve, Edmonton Indian Agency in the Province of Alberta;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Michel Reserve and living quarters for the Indian day school teacher;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part, as follows:-

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

THAT efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the City of Edmonton and local towns near the said Reserve but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building contractor, namely the Poole Construction Company, Edmonton, whom our officials state are a very reliable firm, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus ten per-cent;

THAT it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.
The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the construction of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time next school term commences.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.

1. All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this Trade.

2. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying heating drawing are intended to provide for a complete system of Gravity Warm Air Heating in the building. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

3. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention given to the grading of all warm air leaders, and making connections. All connections shall be made to provide free and unobstructed flow and shall be made as tight as possible and in a manner consistent with the best practice.

5. WARM AIR SURFACE

Furnish and set up complete in the basement, where shown on plan, one first grade furnace as described on drawing, having a rated output equivalent to that called for on the plan. The furnace shall have a double casing; and shall be equipped with manually operated chain, controlled draft and check dampers, water pan and a complete set of firing tools.

6. SMOKE PIPE

Provide and install galvanized iron smoke pipe of a gauge and diameter called for on plan. This smoke pipe shall have a close fitting manually operated key damper in horizontal run.
Provide suitable collar at a point where smoke pipe enters chimney.

7. **LEADERS**

Provide and install circular warm air leaders of sizes noted on plan, made up of bright tin or 20 gauge galvanized iron, with locked seams. Joints shall be lapped not less than 1/2" and shall be banded and soldered to make tight connections. All leaders shall be carefully connected to furnace cone, register boxes and wall stocks, with all necessary elbows, twisters, boots, transformer sections, etc., as may be required to provide complete job. Leaders shall be supported from joists and shall be installed with a rise of not less than one inch per linear foot.

All leaders, except as noted on plan, shall be provided with dampers located not more than 2'-0" from furnace cone.

Where leaders are run within 1' of any woodwork, the woodwork in the immediate vicinity shall be protected with sheet asbestos wall board.

Where leaders pass through partitions, galvanized iron flanged sleeves shall be provided, the flanges having diameters sufficient to cover opening in partition. The sleeves shall be made of No. 24 gauge galvanized iron.

8. **STACKS**

All warm air stacks shall be made up of bright tin or No. 26 gauge galvanized iron, and shall be of sizes as noted on drawing.

9. **RETURN AIR DUCTS AND LEADERS**

From the cold air register faces located where shown on plan, provide and connect up return air ducts of sizes and gauges noted on plan. These return air ducts shall be fastened directly to the underside of the joists and run to the furnace room where wound return air leaders shall be connected therefrom to cold air ducts, typically as shown on large scale section. Care shall be taken to make all joints as tight as possible, and all panels shall be cross broken to provide rigidity.

10. **ELBOWS**

All elbows shall be not less than 3 piece style, and all shall be adjustable. Care shall be taken to obtain tight connections between elbows and leaders.

11. **REGISTERS AND FACES**

Supply and install baseboard and floor registers where shown of sizes noted on plan. Supply registers shall be provided with movable louvres and suitable for connection to register boxes.

Return air faces shall be cast with bronze finish or hardwood. Wall faces adjacent to stair well or first floor shall be steel with bronze finish of sizes as shown.
12. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

13. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Engineer. Blueprints for this purpose shall be furnished by the Department.

14. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense as soon as possible after being notified that such defect has appeared.

GLAZING

WINDOWS & DOORS

All sash for double hung and casement windows, as well as glazed doors, shall be glazed with 24 oz. sheet glass.

STORM WINDOWS AND STORM DOORS

Storm sash and lights in storm doors also shall be glazed with 24 oz. sheet glass.

Glass shall be free of waves, bubbles or other imperfections and shall be cut with straight edges of full size required by the openings.

All glass in windows shall be bedded in putty, sprigged and finished with putty, coloured to match printwork.

All glass in glazed doors shall be sprigged and held in place with wood beads or moulds. The glass in exterior doors to be back putted.

Priming of sash and frames may be carried out at the mill, and the contractor may arrange to have all or any part of the glazing also completed at the mill.

Previous to priming sash and frames, the engineer in charge shall be notified so that inspection may be arranged.

PROTECTION AND CLEANING

During construction the contractor shall protect all glass from damage, repairing at his own expense all breakages from any cause. He shall clean all glass before the buildings are accepted. He shall also prevent the accumulation of painter's materials and rubbish in the buildings and arrange for storage of his materials elsewhere to prevent as far as possible a fire hazard from such cause.

COMPLETION

When painting and glazing work has been completed, the contractor shall clean all spots from finished surfaces, refinish any rubbed or damaged work, whether it be caused by himself or others. He shall touch up where work of other trades require, and leave the buildings in a clean and orderly condition.

WALLBOARD SURFACES

All gypsum wallboard surfaces throughout the building shall be examined to ensure completely filled joints, and secure fastening before finish is applied.

All such surfaces to be first coated with a sealing primer manufactured for the purpose applied in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, and finished with two coats of semi-gloss paint of selected colour.

CEMENT SURFACES

Cement wall and floor surfaces throughout the basement excepting only in furnace (or boiler) fuel and store rooms shall be finished as follows:

(a) Walls.

Carefully examine all cement finished wall surfaces, and remove all traces of oil, grease, dirt, or other foreign matter, then apply one coat, well brushed on of a concrete hardener as supplied by leading paint manufacturers, as it comes from the container.

When hardener is set and dry, apply a second coat, 50% of which shall be an approved sealer primer and 50% concrete paint of colour selected for finish coat.

Allow 24 hours for drying and apply a final coat of concrete paint of selected colour as it comes from the container.

(b) Floors.

Remove all grease, oil, dirt, efflorescence and other foreign substances from floors and when perfectly dry apply one coat of concrete hardener, well brushed in.

When hardener is set and dry, apply one coat of cement and concrete sealer as it comes from the container and allow 24 hours for drying, after which apply two coats of concrete floor paint in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.
METAL

First wipe over with vinegar all galvanized iron in flashings, etc., then prime with one coat of red lead paint, and finish with two coats of lead and oil paint of colour to match adjacent work.

Other exterior metal work shall be similarly painted three coats to match adjacent work in colour.

Galvanized wire mesh in fly screens will not be painted.

OUTSIDE TOILETS

The exterior and interior exposed woodwork of the outside toilet buildings shall be given two coats of good quality shingle stain. The colour of the stain will be medium dark brown, except for roof shingles which are to match the red roof shingles on main building.

INTERIOR WORK

SOFTWOOD FINISH

All interior fir pine or spruce trim and millwork throughout the building shall be painted three coats of white lead and oil semi-gloss paint of selected colour, except as hereafter specified. Shiplap partitions in the basement will not be painted.

PAINTING ON FIR

Where paint is applied to B.C. fir, the wood shall be primed with an oil filler of special manufacture to prevent the raising of the grain.

ALTERNATIVE PRICE FOR B.C. FIR - NATURAL FINISH

The contractor shall submit in his tender an alternative price for finishing all B.C. fir trim and millwork for natural grain finish as follows:

(1) Well rub in a wood paste filler.
(2) Apply a coat of pure white shellac.
(3) Apply coat of interior varnish thinned with 10% of turpentine.
(4) Apply second full coat of varnish after 24 hours.

BIRCH TRIM

Birch hand rails and newels to staircases to be stain-filled to approved colour and varnished two coats.

The first coat of varnish to be thinned with best quality turpentine and at least twelve hours must elapse before second coat of varnish is applied.

FINISHED FLOORS AND HARDWOOD STAIRS

All finished floors, including stair landings, and all stair treads and risers are to be finished with three coats

WORKMANSHIP

All work shall be carried out by skilled workmen in accordance with the best practice, and no paint or other finish shall be applied under unfavourable conditions, or to any surface which is damp, dirty, greasy, rough or otherwise imperfect. COLOUR SCHEDULES

EXTERIOR WORK

WOODWORK

ENTRANCE PLATFORMS AND STEPS

The entrance platforms and steps thereto in the Single Classroom building shall be primed and painted two coats of best quality gray floor paint.
ROOFING AND FLASHING

ASPHALT ROOFING SHINGLES

Cover all sloping roof surfaces on the asphalt felt previously specified, with twin - or 3-in-1 asphalt strip shingles, weighing 2½ lbs per square. Shingles to be of red colour laid 4-1/2" to weather and to include all necessary starters and hip and ridge shingles.

FLASHING

All roofs of the buildings shall be flashed wherever required to render same thoroughly watertight and weatherproof with No. 26 gauge galvanized sheet iron.

The roof valleys shall have 6" metal exposure at the top, extending to 18" at eaves, with 6" extension under the shingles.

Flash with similar metal above all exterior door and window and louvre heads in frame walls, the water tables around the buildings and elsewhere as may be required.

The cover flashing to chimneys shall be stepped and turned into brick course as described under "brickwork" and shall be secured in place with lead wedges. Base flashings shall extend under shingles and be turned up against vertical surfaces at least 6 inches. Step flashings shall lap base flashings 4" and shall lap over the adjoining step flashing a minimum of 2" at vertical joints.

Flash above the entrance door pediments and brackets shown on detail drawings, turned up against walls to lap behind the asbestos siding shingles at least 4".

CAULKING

Horizontal brick joints, into which flashing has been wedged, shall be caulked full with an approved asphalt caulking compound upon completion of the flashing work.

GUARANTEE

The contractor shall furnish a written guarantee that he will make good at his own expense any leaks or other defects in the roofs or flashings throughout the buildings, and any damage caused thereby, within a period of one year after acceptance of the buildings by the Department, and no final payment will be made before such document is received.

'Chief Engineer', or other words relative thereto, or of like import shall mean and include the person holding the position or acting in the capacity of the Chief Engineer, of the Engineering and Construction Service, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

SITE: The Contractor must contact the Indian agent, and visit the site. He shall familiarize himself with the nature and characteristics of the site, and shall bear such facts in mind when preparing his tender.
SECURITY DEPOSIT: The amount of the security deposit cheque submitted by the bidder whose tender has been accepted will be forfeited if such bidder declines to enter into a contract when called upon to do so or fails to commence work within a period of ten days after being notified of the acceptance of his tender.

SCHEDULE OF UNIT PRICES: The Contractor shall submit, immediately his tender is accepted, a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis for progress payments.

The prices so submitted shall be the basis for adjustments for any alterations, additions and omissions in connection with the work during the period of the contract.

Such classification of costs shall be prepared so that incidental charges, such as workmen's compensation, insurance, cost of permits, etc., shall be distributed over each trade in the proportion that such trade bears to the total cost of the work.

Payment for additional or extra work

Payment for any work or additional work done, or materials or things provided, under the written orders of the Engineer, for which no price or prices are named, and which is not covered by the contract, His Majesty, in consideration and subject as aforesaid, will pay to the Contractor the actual and reasonable cost, as determined by the Engineer, of such work, materials and things, with an additional ten per cent thereon for the use of tools, Contractor's plant, superintendence and profits.

EXCAVATION, DRAINAGE, BACKFILL AND GRADING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include all excavation for basement, piers, footings, foundations, catch basin, tile drainage lines, and backfilling for same.

It shall also include cutting away existing banks, prominences etc., to produce graded and terraced areas in the vicinity of the building as required, and fill to produce levels called for on the drawings where finished grade levels are to be higher than existing levels.

It shall further include replacement of top soil as specified herein after grading to lines and levels as shown on the working drawings or as may be directed by the Engineer, has been carried out.

TOP SOIL

From the area around the building, which is to be graded, remove top soil to a depth of 6" and deposit where and as directed by the Engineer.

EXCAVATION

Excavation for all purposes shall conform to the shapes and shall be carried to the levels shown on the working drawings. The sides of all excavations for building shall be sufficiently clear of the outside face of basement or foundation walls to permit erection and stripping of forms and the application of waterproofing, and the laying of weeping tile drains.

Other footing excavations may be cut the neat sizes of the footings where soil conditions permit; otherwise the excavation shall be large enough to accommodate the necessary forms.

All footings and foundations shall rest on solid undisturbed soil beds, which shall be at approximately true levels.

Where excavations for walls, piers or footings have been carried, by accident or design, to greater depths than intended, they shall be filled to the required level with concrete, as specified under Concrete Work.

All excavations shall be protected from damage by frost, accident or other cause, and shall be kept dry and free from refuse.

The contractor shall keep all excavations and basements free of water from any source whatsoever, and shall supply all pumps and labour required for the purpose.

All excavated material not required for backfill or for grading shall be moved to another portion of the site, as directed by the Engineer.

ROCK EXCAVATION

Any rock encountered in excavating shall be removed by drilling and wedging as far as possible. If blasting must be resorted to, it shall be done by experienced men, and all precautions shall be taken to ensure the safety of all persons, and to prevent damage to property.

All rough, sloping, loose or soft rock in the bottom of excavations shall be cut away leaving solid beds, and all rock projections at sides of any excavation shall be cut away so that clear space equal to other excavating previously specified is available.
Loose large boulders, which are visible or which may be encountered in excavating, are to be removed by the most convenient method either from the site or to other positions thereon, as directed by the Engineer.

**Shoring**

Supply and place all shoring that may be required to shore up and securely hold all banks or sides of excavations. Maintain and finally dismantle and remove it when work is completed.

**Backfilling at Buildings**

After waterproofing has been completed in accordance with the water-proofing specification and when so directed by the Engineer, fill in against the outside face of the basement walls of the Building with at least 6" of broken stone carefully placed and compacted so that weepers will not be disturbed or damaged. Over the broken stone, and to within 6" of finished grade, fill with well compacted soil. This fill to be well tamped, moistened and consolidated in layers to prevent settlement.

Backfill where necessary in basement around piers, footings and underfloor drainage lines, with excavated material as required to form level bed. Fill to be thoroughly tamped and consolidated to prevent settlement. To the top of footings over this bed spread broken stone as shown on working drawings to form base for concrete floor slab. Stone to be carefully placed and compacted to avoid injury to under-floor drainage lines.

**Drainage**

**Trenches**

Trenches for drainage lines from building as specified for the accommodation of vitrified tile piping shall provide gradients as indicated on drainage details or specified in the plumbing and drainage. Trenches shall be wide enough to permit workmen to operate.

**Weeping Tile**

Lay a drain of 4" agricultural weeping tile completely around basement foundation walls at proper gradients from bottom of footings as shown on drawings and if the site requires it, upon instructions of the Engineer, run branch lines 6' or 8' long running through footings or walls and under basement floor slab where indicated. Where each of these branches passes through footings or walls it shall consist of a section of 4" cast iron pipe of the same length as the width of footing or wall. Care shall be taken that concrete is thoroughly tamped around this cast iron pipe.

Weeping tile shall be laid with 1/2" open joints protected with tar paper strips 6" wide and then covered with not less than 12" of broken stone and gravel, before backfill is placed.

**Connect Drains to Catch Basin**

Carry all tile drains from foundation footings and basement floor drains and connect to catch basin (See Concrete Specification) in position shown or where directed by the Engineer.
VITRIFIED TILE

Lay an effluent drain of 6" vitrified salt glazed earthenware pipe from catch basin to discharge by gravity flow above grade. If the extent of this drain is not indicated, the contractor shall include in his tender price an amount for installing same to any point selected by the Engineer, within 100' O" of the building.

Lay 4" similar tile drain, or drains if shown, from catch basin to the proper positions at basement footings and connect same to cast iron basement floor drains.

During laying, each section of vitrified tile shall be solidly supported above bottom of trench and socket-jointed with cement mortar. After jointing, solid beds of soil shall be well packed under pipes.

IRON DRAINS

Run a 4" cast iron pipe drain, or drains if shown, under basement floor from floor drains and any plumbing fixtures to outside of foundation walls under footings and connect to the vitrified tile drains, specified above, running to catch basin.

Provide and install all required Ys, bends, etc., and a C.I. trap and floor strainer to each basement floor outlet.

BACK FILLING

Back filling over all tile and iron drains shall be carefully executed with approved material in a manner to avoid disturbing pipes.

GRADING

Upon completion of the buildings carefully clean up all debris, material, rubbish, etc., from the areas disturbed by building operations and grade up for a distance of 12 feet around the building to levels and lines shown on the various working drawings to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Where terracing is required, the fill is to be thoroughly rammed and consolidated to prevent settlement.

When all grading has been completed, all graded surfaces and areas are to be covered with topsoil previously removed.
