CEMENT

Cement shall conform to the "Standard Specification for Portland Cement" AS - 1940 of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association and subsequent revisions thereof. Aggregates shall conform to the "Standard Specification for Concrete and Reinforced Concrete", AS - 1942 of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association and subsequent revisions thereof.

AGGREGATES

Aggregate shall consist of natural sand and gravel, crushed rock or other clean, inert minerals, free from alkali, organic matter or other deleterious substances.
Fine aggregate shall be sand, preferably water-washed, and shall range in size from fine to coarse within the percentages by weight as specified hereafter for ordinary watertight concretes.

**ORDINARY CONCRETE**

Concrete used in the basement walls of the building, the basement floor slabs and in piers, steps and all footings shall be ordinary concrete as hereunder described.

**AGGREGATES**

Fine aggregates shall range in size fine to coarse within the following percentages by weight:

- Passing 3/8" sieve: 100 per cent.
- " No. 4 ": 95-100 "
- " No. 16 ": 45-50 "
- " No. 50 ": 5-30 "
- " No. 100 ": 0-3 "

Volume removed by sedimentation not more than 3 per cent.

Coarse aggregate shall consist of crushed stone or gravel, graded within the following percentages by weight:

- Passing a 1-inch sieve: 95-100 per cent.
- " 3/4 ": 37-70 "
- " 3/8 ": 10-30 "
- " No. 4 ": 0-5 "

**PROPORTIONS**

The proportions of cement, fine and coarse aggregate measured dry and water for all ordinary concrete shall be as follows:

One (1) part cement,
One and one-half (1½) parts fine aggregate,
Three (3) parts coarse aggregate (1" nominal size)
and not more than five and one-tenth (5-1/10) gallons of water per sack of cement.

Note: This mixture shall have a strength in compression at 28 days of at least 2,500 lbs. per square inch.

**WATERTIGHT CONCRETE**

In Basement Walls of Building

All concrete in basement walls of the building above the footings shall be of watertight density using the following approximate quantities:

The sum of separate volumes of fine and coarse aggregates shall be 5-3/4 cubic feet, measured dry, per sack of cement, using not more than 4.1 gals. of water, including surface water contained in the aggregates. The volume of coarse aggregate shall not be less than the volume of fine aggregate and not more than twice the volume of fine aggregate.

Fine aggregate should have from 10 to 20 per cent of particles passing a 50 mesh sieve and coarse aggregate made
up of particles graded from 1/4 inch up to not more than 1 inch. Coarse aggregate should be of a non-porous character.

The concrete should be of plastic consistency which can be placed without segregation of materials. In consolidating the concrete no excess water should rise to the surface.

In proportioning the aggregates, the contractor should make trial batches with the materials to be used, measuring the materials accurately and making due allowance for moisture, adjusting the proportions until suitable workability is secured. Special care shall be exercised to ensure that the concrete does not dry out during the curing period.

This concrete is designed to have a compressive strength of 3,000 lbs after 28 days.

**STORAGE OF MATERIALS**

Cement shall be stored in a weather tight building, the floor of which shall be raised above the ground to ensure dryness. When required by the Engineer, the cement shall be stored in such a manner as to permit ready identification of the various lots for test purposes.

Aggregates shall be delivered and stored separately. Storage shall be such as will avoid the inclusion of foreign materials.

**UNITS OF MEASUREMENT**

Units of measurement for all concrete shall be:

Water shall be the Imperial gallon, and for purposes of this specification 10 lbs. of water shall be taken as the equivalent of one Imperial gallon.

Cement shall be the cubic foot and for purposes of this specification, the Canadian sack of cement, weighing 37½ lbs. gross, shall be regarded as the equivalent of 0.9 cubic foot.

**MEASUREMENT OF AGGREGATE**

The aggregate shall be measured by volume or by weight, as may be directed by the Engineer. The method of measurement used shall be such as to secure the specified proportions in each batch, due allowance being made for free moisture and bulking effect.

**MEASUREMENT OF WATER**

The water shall be measured by a device such that the quantity of water in each batch can be regulated to give concrete of uniform consistency in successive batches, due allowance being made for free moisture in the aggregate.

**AGGREGATE MOISTURE**

When tests for moisture in the aggregate cannot be made, approximate values may be based upon the following:

- Very wet sand: 3/4 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moderately wet sand: 1/2 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moist sand about: 1/4 gal. per cu. ft.
- Moist gravel or crushed rock about: 1/3 to 1/4 gal. per cu. ft.
MIXING

Concrete shall be mixed in an approved type batch mixer of capacity commensurate with the volume of work to be carried out. It shall be mixed to such a consistency that it will flow when agitated, but will not be so wet that the materials will separate in handling.

The ingredients shall be accurately measured for each batch and mixed as follows:

1. Mix cement and fine aggregate.
2. Add coarse aggregate.
3. Add water.

The mixing of each batch shall continue not less than two (2) minutes after all ingredients are in the mixer, during which time the mixer shall rotate at a speed of from 14 to 20 revolutions per minute, unless otherwise rated by the manufacturer and approved by the Engineer.

NO RE-TEMPERING

The re-temping of concrete or mortar which has partially hardened, that is, remixing with or without additional cement, aggregate or water, will not be permitted.

DEPOSITING CONCRETE

Concrete shall be deposited in forms as rapidly as possible to avoid rehandling. It shall be thoroughly compacted with suitable tools and by approved means to eliminate all air bubbles and to prevent honeycombing. Pouring shall be continuous until the unit of operation, as approved by the Engineer, is complete.

Concrete in footings of basement walls shall be completed in one operation and brought to a smooth, level surface to receive membrane waterproofing in damp-proof course hereafter specified.

Under no circumstances shall concrete be removed from forms and deposited elsewhere in the work, nor shall any concrete which has partially hardened, be deposited in the forms.

BONDING

On recommencing the pouring of concrete after previous work has partially set, the surface of the hardened concrete shall be saturated with water and sprinkled with dry cement and the superimposed concrete shall be deposited in such a manner as will ensure an excess of mortar over the entire surface of the joint and a complete and satisfactory bond.

CONCRETE WALLS

Concrete foundation walls and footings shall be of full thickness and depths shown on working drawings of the building. Footings shall be laid on a solid foundation of undisturbed soil. However soil has been removed below the required depth, the excavation shall be filled with concrete as before specified resting upon a solid bottom, without extra expense to the Department.
GREEN CONCRETE

Green concrete shall not be subjected to any heavy blows or strains during the progress of the work. No wheeling or handling of concrete on partly set concrete will be permitted.

ANCHOR BOLTS

Set 2" x 12" bolts as shown on typical wall section details, with nuts and washers, to anchor the main sills of external frame walls to the concrete foundation walls. Bolts to be spaced not more than 4 feet apart. The top of the concrete walls shall be floated to a true and level finish to receive the sills of the frame walls.

SET SLEEVES ETC., IN PLACE

The contractor shall set in place as required, before the concrete is poured, all pipe sleeves, anchors and miscellaneous ironware.

BASEMENT FLOOR FOUNDATIONS

On a solid bottom lay a bed of broken stone and gravel 5" thick to form a foundation for the basement floor slab of each building. This bed shall be well tamped and consolidated, and brought to such levels as will conform to the gradients required to drain the finished cement floors to the floor drains where indicated on the basement plans.

FLOOR SLABS

Over the broken stone floor foundations above specified, lay a slab of ordinary concrete of the thickness shown on the working drawings. The slab shall be graded to the requisite levels to drain the finished floors and shall be floated to an even surface ready to receive cement finish. Reinforce the basement floor slab with 6" x 6" - 8" x 3" wire mesh, placed 2" above bottom of slab.

CEMENT FLOOR FINISH

When the floor slab has hardened, but before it has thoroughly dried out, the frame partitions should be set in place as described under Carpentry work, and there shall be applied a floor finish of cement, one inch thick, consisting of 1 part cement, 1 part well-graded sand and from 1/2 to 2 parts of pea gravel, or crushed stone, graded from 1/8 to 3/8 inches. It shall be of the driest consistency, possible to work with a sawing motion of the straight edge. The addition of fine aggregate, or water, to give workability will not be permitted.

After placing the concrete, it shall be screeded to the correct slope and compacted with a wooden float, as soon as possible after screeding. Floating shall not be continued more than is necessary to bring the minimum amount of mortar to the surface for finishing. When concrete has hardened sufficiently to withstand the moderate pressure of the thumb without leaving a depression, it shall be trowelled to a smooth and even surface. Over trowelling shall be avoided and no drier shall be used.
CONCRETE FINISH

After removal of the forms, any air holes or voids remaining in exposed concrete walls, piers, etc., shall be filled with cement mortar mixed in the proportions of 1 cement to 2 sand, and all rough surfaces rubbed down so that the concrete presents a smooth and even surface to the satisfaction of the Engineer. An excessive number of air holes and voids shall be sufficient reason for rejection of the concrete by the Engineer. All exposed concrete surfaces within the basement are to be finished to receive paint as specified hereafter.

THRESHOLDS

Form the thresholds of the grade entrances in precast concrete, with lugs and wash, in accordance with detail drawings. Concrete to be mixed in the proportion specified for watertight concrete. The exposed surfaces of the thresholds shall be rubbed with carborundum stone or wire brush until all irregularities are removed, the finished surfaces then to be thoroughly moistened and a coat of cement grout, brushed on.

GRADE ENTRANCE STEPS

Form a step to the grade entrances of the building of the dimensions shown, or ordinary concrete reinforced with 6" x 6" wire mesh and resting on a bed of broken stone, at least 12 inches thick, well consolidated down to a solid bottom.

DAMP-PROOF COURSE

Between the top of concrete footings and concrete basement walls, a damp proof course shall be formed consisting of layers of 12 lb. asphalt saturated felt mopped in place and on top with hot coal tar pitch the width of the footings to form a capillary stop.

WATERPROOFING

The entire exterior surface of all concrete foundation walls below the finished grade lines and the exterior top of footings of the building shall be given a coat of hot coal tar pitch well brushed in and of sufficient weight to render the walls thoroughly waterproof. In the angle formed by the foundation walls and footings on exterior side, mop on a strip of tarred 10 pound building felt 12" wide.

MASTIC JOINTS

At the junctions of basement floor slabs and vertical concrete surfaces form joints with an approved mastic compound.

REINFORCEMENT

All steel used as concrete reinforcement shall comply with the requirements of the C.E.S.A. Standard Specifications for intermediate grade steel, having an ultimate strength of 40,000 lbs per sq.in.

Reinforcing steel shall be clean and free from rust and coatings. It shall be accurately placed and secured against displacement by annealed wire ties or suitable clips at intersections.

FOUNDATION WALLS

The foundation walls of the building shall be reinforced with two 2-5/8" diameter rods placed at the top and at the
bottom and lapped 2 feet at corners.

**INTERIOR CONCRETE WALLS**

The 8 inch interior concrete walls shall be reinforced with 1-5/8" diameter rod placed at the top and at the bottom and bent 2 feet into adjoining concrete walls.

**BASEMENT WINDOWS**

Reinforce the walls around the basement window openings and all doors with two 4/8" diameter rods set vertically and horizontally 2" from the faces of the jambs and of the walls, as shown on detail drawings.

All reinforcing steel when in position shall be approved by the engineer in charge before proceeding with concrete work.

**CONCRETE CATCH BASIN**

Construct catch basin of ordinary concrete as previously specified to size shown on plan. Location and depth of catch basin to be determined by Engineer in charge of the work.
BRICKWORK

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include the erection of flues and chimneys in the building in the position and of dimensions shown on the working drawings; and the setting and building in cleanout doors and frames, smoke pipe, thimbles, etc., as may be required.

CHIMNEYS

From the level of the concrete chimney foundations, 2'-6" above the basement floor of the building, carry up the chimneys to a height of not less than 21'-0" above the ridge line of the building, as shown on elevations.

The chimneys where passing through the building shall be carried up in good quality well-burned common brick, laid 4 courses, including 4 joints, to measure 11". The flues from furnaces shall be provided with rectangular vitrified flue linings of the sizes shown on plans, carried up from the smoke pipe inlet to the cap of the chimney stack. Both flues of single classroom school to be so lined.

MORTAR

Mortar for all brickwork shall be composed of one part of Portland cement and three parts clean sharp sand to which may be added hydrated lime to the extent of 10 per cent by volume of the quantity of cement used.

JOINTS

All brickwork, whether exposed or concealed, shall be well bedded and with joints flushed full of mortar.

FACE BRICK

The exterior brickwork in chimney stack shall be carried up in a good grade of hard burned red face brick with weathered joints, coursed as described for common brick. Form caps to the chimney stacks as shown on elevations with precast concrete cap.

MISCELLANEOUS IRONWORK

Set and build into place all miscellaneous ironware, hereafter specified and as required, in the positions in brickwork as shown on the working drawings.

FLASHINGS

Prepare brickwork to receive metal flashings as indicated on working drawings and as specified under Roofing and Flashing.

All joints in brickwork to receive metal flashings are to be raked out to a depth of 1/2" and left clean for the insertion of flashing.

COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the face brickwork shall be thoroughly cleaned down with stiff brushes and clean water.
CARPENTRY AND MILLWORK

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall cover the furnishing of material and labour for all rough and finishing carpentry in the buildings and outside privies, specified herein, indicated on the drawings, or as may be necessary for the proper completion of the work. The general extent of the work is as follows:

(a) Setting out the work and providing all necessary shores, scaffolding, templates, bucks, blocks, mailing strips, furring, grounds, etcetera.

(b) The erection and removal of temporary privy, mixing platforms and concrete formwork, etcetera; also office and storage buildings as necessary for construction work.

(c) Framing all walls, floors, roofs, inside partitions, landings, beams, sub-floors, boarding and sheathing, including cutting for and making good after the work of all other trades as necessary.

(d) Application of asphalt felt to exterior walls and sloping roofs, bevelled siding to exterior walls and wood shingles to roofs or alternatively. The application of asbestos siding shingles to exterior walls and of asphalt shingles to roofs.

(e) Insulating frame walls and ceilings.

(f) Installing and caulking door and window frames. Installing sash, storm sash, storm doors, louvres, etcetera.

(g) Constructing and applying exterior finish for entrances, platforms, steps, and fitting and applying exterior casings for door, window and louvre openings; also corner boards, water tables, skirting boards, etc.,

(h) Installing all gypsum wall board and insulation board, strapping and interior finish to walls, ceilings and partitions.

(i) Installing all interior finish and millwork, fitting and hanging doors; installing kitchen dresser, shelving, door and window trim, baseboards, shoe strips, jamb linings, clothes closet fittings, etc.

(j) Installing all finished floors and staircases.

(k) Supplying, fitting and installing all rough and finishing hardware.

MATERIALS

All lumber and timber used in the buildings shall be square edged to size, well seasoned and dry. It shall be free from sap, shakes, wane edges, cracks, loose or dead knots and any defect that would impair its strength or durability.

Framing timbers generally shall be of merchantable spruce of B.C. Douglas fir, in Western areas, of equivalent grading.
All exterior woodwork where exposed to view or to the weather shall be of pine or Douglas fir, dressed for painters' finish.

FORMWORK

All foundation formwork shall be of merchantable grade spruce or hemlock; shiplaid to be out of 1" x 5" and framing timbers 2" x 4". S. LS. LE.

All formwork shall be set plumb and level and strongly wired to prevent buckling. Set in place cast iron sleeves of suitable size for all pipes passing through the concrete walls.

All shiplaid boarding shall be closely jointed and the inside faces coated with non-staining mineral oil or other approved liquid before concrete is deposited, to give a smooth even finish to the concrete surface.

FRAMING TIMBERS

Framing material shall be piled in such a manner that drainage and ventilation is assured, while awaiting use.

All framing and structural timbers shall be erected in the strongest manner in accordance with the working drawings and following the best practice. All studding and joists to be set plumb and level, bridged or bridged as necessary, and strongly nailed or spiked together.

Framing members shall be dressed at sawmill. The sizes named are nominal.

MAIN WALL SILLS

Provide and set in place main wall sills to carry first floor joists and exterior frame walls as shown on typical wall section. Sills to be anchored to concrete walls with anchor bolts set near ends of sills and spaced not more than 6 feet apart.

STUDDING

The studding of all exterior walls shall be framed up with 2" x 4" studs from the main sills, excepting over basement windows where it shall be supported by lintels of the depth of the joists. Studs to be spaced 16 inches on centres and doubled around door and window openings. Over the school classroom windows truss the studding with diagonal braces and the mullion studs to the wallplates. Check in 2" x 6" ribbon board where required and set two rows of 2" x 4" girtning to classroom walls and one row to the walls of teachers quarters. Wall plates to be 2" x 4" doubled. Partitions, unless otherwise described, to be framed with 2" x 4" sills, 2" x 4" studs 16 inches on centres, and 2" x 4" heads, doubled for bearing partitions and with girtning as described for exterior walls. Frame partitions in basements shall be carried up from the cement floors to the underside of the first floor joists with 2" x 4" sills, studs and caps. Partitions to be set in place before finishing coat of cement floor is trowelled under the sill, and are to be anchored in position with 5" spikes and well nailed to joists overhead.

FLOOR JOISTS

Joists are to be doubled where they carry partitions running in the same direction, and trimming joists for staircase,
chimney, etcetera, will also be doubled as necessary.

Generally all joints will be set not more than 16 inches on centres. Where a variation is necessary, the spacing is to be reduced. Set joists of the dimensions shown on drawings 16 inches on centres for all floors and landings throughout the building.

CROSS BRIDGING

Set rows of 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" x 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" cross bridging not more than 3 feet apart between the joists of all floors uniformly spaced and in line.

CEILING JOISTS

Ceiling joists of the sizes shown to be set 16 inches on centres spiked to the sides of rafters. Trim ceiling joists as required for vent over Classroom and for chimney, etcetera.

BASEMENT POSTS

Set in place where shown in the basement 8" x 9" wood posts 3.4.S. with 1" chamfered corners. Posts to be anchored at bottom to concrete footings with iron dowels and to be well spiked to beams at top.

RAFTERS

All rafters to be accurately cut, set true in line and securely spiked or nailed to wall plates, ridge boards and other supports.

Rafters of the main roof shall be 2" x 6" 16 inches on centres. Those over the Classroom to be trussed as shown, with braces and vertical pieces well spiked to support ceiling joists.

Rafters at overhang of eaves shall be D.4.S., shaped at feet and notched over wall plate, securely nailed to side of each main roof rafter. Roof boarding at overhanging eaves to be T. & G. V-joint, as shown on typical wall section detail.

Set in place at intersection of main roofs of two Classroom School building, valley rafters of dimensions shown, built up of 2" material well spiked together.

SHIPLAP SHEATHING

Line both sides of the exterior frame walls throughout the building and the inner side of the dwarf walls to the second storey of the Teacher's Quarters in the One Classroom building with shiplap sheathing out of 1" x 3" material.

The exterior sheathing to the building is to be laid diagonally.

Line both sides of the stud partitions in the basement fuel and furnace rooms and of first floor stud partitions which enclose Classroom and Coat rooms, also one side of stud partitions enclosing public stairways with similar shiplap sheathing.

Cover the whole of the sloping rafters of the building, with similar shiplap sheathing.

25.
SUB-FLOORS

Lay a sub-floor of 1" x 8" shiplap sheathing upon the first and second floor joists and the staircase lamings of building as required to receive finished floors. Shiplap for sub-floors to be laid diagonally.

WAXED KRAFT PAPER

Over the sub-floors of the building, before laying finished floors, apply one thickness of medium weight waxed kraft waterproof paper well lapped at joints and edges.

SADDLES

Form saddles behind chimneys as required to receive flashing.

BUILDING PAPERS

All exterior boarding to roof slopes and walls shall be covered with one layer of asphalt impregnated building felt. Felt used on roofs to weigh 15 lbs. per square, and on walls 12 lbs. per square. All felt to be well lapped at joints and edges and where used on walls to be carried behind all door and window casings, corner boards, etcetera.

ASBESTOS SIDING SHINGLES

Cover the whole of the exterior wall surfaces of the building where shown on the drawings, over the asphalt felt previously specified, with graded asbestos siding shingles, oyster grey in colour, size 12" x 44" laid with 3/4" exposure. Shingles are to be laid to butt tightly against the corner boards and exterior casings of doors and windows and to be cut to fit the rakes of verges and elsewhere and nailed in accordance with the manufacturers' directions.

ALTERNATIVE WOOD SIDING

The contractor shall submit an alternative price for covering the exterior wall surfaces where shown on drawings with 1" x 9" bevelled or drop siding of B.C. Douglas fir or pine, accurately cut and closely jointed. Below the wood siding set 12" x 10" skirting, weathered and rebated as shown on typical wall section.

MINERAL WOOL INSULATION

Furnish and install mineral wool insulation in waterproof paper backed batts, and loose as required, to completely insulate the outside walls and upper ceilings of the building as noted on the drawings or hereafter specified, and placed in accordance with the manufacturer's printed instructions.

The insulation shall be installed against the back of shiplap in all exterior frame walls from top of foundation walls to roof in order to provide a continuous blanket of insulation surrounding the occupied portions of the building.

Install mineral wool insulation between horizontal ceiling joists above occupied areas and between rafters where sloping ceilings occur, with the waterproof backing on the lower side, between studs, up to ceiling insulation in gable ends.
and in dwarf walls of Teacher's Quarters in One Classroom building.

Use batts in stud walls the full thickness of the studs (2-3/4") and between rafters and ceiling joists where so required use batts of similar thickness. Elsewhere use the granulated form to fill completely all voids in the spaces to be insulated.

**SOUNDPROOF INSULATION AND STRAPPING**

Line the underside of the first floor joists over the workshop, manual training and sewing rooms in the basement of the building with 1" thick sound insulating wallboard, "Ten-test" or equal, in sheets size 3 ft. by 4 ft., where electric wiring is installed set in place 1" x 2" strapping at 16 inch centres below the first floor joists to conform to the requirements of such installation and to receive the ceiling board.

**FIREPROOF INSULATING BOARD**

Line the underside of the first floor joists over the furnace (or boiler) and fuel rooms in the basement of the building with similar 1" thick, sound insulating wallboard and at right angles to same, line the ceilings with asbestos fire proof insulating board 1/4" thick in sheets size 6 ft. by 4 ft. laid with close joints. No stripping is to be applied to these ceilings.

**CAULKING**

Carefully caulk around all window and door frames, and wherever else necessary to fill voids and cracks in exterior insulated walls, with oakum tightly packed in from the inner side.

**GYPSUM WALLBOARD**

Cover the interior surfaces of shiplap on exterior frame walls, both sides of all stud partitions from the finished floors to the ceiling joists, and the underside of floor and ceiling joists throughout the building, except as otherwise specified, with gypsum wallboard 3/8" thick in sheets 48 inches wide with all edges bevelled. Joints to be taped and filled with plaster joint filler to form smooth unbroken wall and ceiling surfaces for painters' finish. External and internal angles shall be neatly taped and filled with plaster joint filler. Failing and jointing shall be carried out in strict accordance with manufacturers' directions.

Similarly line the strapping previously specified to the ceilings of the Workshop, Manual Training and Sewing Rooms in the basement, with gypsum wallboard.

Omit gypsum wallboard within the fuel boiler and store room of the building.

**MILLWORK**

All mouldings and trim used throughout the building to be of stock sizes and pattern, following as closely as possible dimensions and profiles shown on detail drawings, and to the approval of the Engineer.

**EXTERIOR FINISHED WOODWORK AND TRIM**

All doors and windows and their trim, and all exterior moulded woodwork in entrances, cornices, etcetera, shall be of selected factory grade pine or B.C. Douglas Fir S.4S. sanded for
painters' finish. All other exterior woodwork where exposed to view is to be of No. 1 Common Pine or Fir of equivalent grading S4S.

CASINGS AND ARCHITRAVES

Set 1-1/8" x 3-3/4" casings around all windows and louvre openings and casings of similar thickness to suit width of mullions; also 1-1/8" x 3-3/4" casings around the entrance doors in frame walls of the single classroom building. Architraves around entrance doors of two classroom building to be moulded 5-3/4" wide, including back bands, as shown on detail drawing.

CORNER BOARDS

Set in place corner boards out of 1" x 4" at the external angles of the building to stop the wood siding or asbestos siding shingles.

ENTRANCE DOOR PEDIMENTS

Construct the pediments over the entrance doors of the two classroom building in accordance with detail drawings, using stock mouldings as nearly as possible similar in profile and dimensions to those shown on the drawings.

OPEN EAVES

Under the open eaves of the building set a fascia board out of 1" x 8" rebated at lower edge to receive siding shingles. The fascia shall be accurately cut and fitted between the rafters, and a bed mould set in the angle of roof and wall as shown on detail drawing.

DOOR AND WINDOW FRAMES

All door and window frames and exterior frame walls shall be of a width equal to the thickness of the wall from the face of the finished inner wall surface to the face of the outside shiplap sheathing.

DOOR FRAMES

The door frames of the main entrances shall be of 2" B.C. Douglas Fir or pine, single rebated for 1-3/4" door opening outwards.

The entrance door frames of two classroom building where abutting concrete walls shall be strongly nailed to wood backs set in the walls as shown on detail drawing.

Door frames set in frame walls should have hardwood sills, weathered on upper surface and grooved and throated below.

WINDOW FRAMES

All double-hung and casement window frames shall be as shown on detail drawings. The frames for double-hung windows in the frame walls shall have 1-1/8" jambs and heads tongued into blind stops, complete with parting strips and stops to receive sash as hereafter described. Mullions for double-hung windows shall have jambs tongued into blind stops of the widths shown.
The sills shall be pitched to weather, throated for drip and grooved to receive exterior shiplap.

Frames of double-hung windows in concrete walls shall have sills shaped as shown and with water bar below.

Casement window frames in frame walls shall have double rebated jambs and heads cut of 2" material, and where mullions occur they shall be 2½" thick. They shall have sills, pitched to weather, fitted with iron water bar, throated for drip and grooved to receive outside shiplap and on inner edge for stool.

The frames of casement windows in concrete walls shall be out of 2" x 6" material; sills to be weathered and grooved on top and below to receive water bars.

**LOUVRES.**

Construct louvres in the gable ends of the building with jamb linings, sill, slats, casings and No. 16 mesh galvanized fly screen in accordance with detail drawings.

**DOORWAY TO ROOF SPACE**

Frame for access to roof space where shown and set in place double rebated door frame. Provide and hang T. & G. batten door on each side fitted with hook and eye fasteners.

**CEILING VENTS**

Form ventilators in the ceilings of the classrooms with wire mesh grilles, size about 18" x 24" and hinged shuttered shutters above. Vent grilles to be of No. 12 woven galvanized wire, 1" square mesh, all in accordance with detail drawing. Vents to be controlled from classroom walls by sash lines, pulleys and cleats.

**WINDOW SASH**

All windows, except where otherwise shown on the elevations, shall have double-hung sash, those in the classrooms to be 1-3/4" thick, and those elsewhere 1-3/8" thick.

All muntin bars shall have clean cut mouldings and shall be set straight and true.

All double-hung windows shall be fitted with spiral spring balances of approved type and make, neatly fitted into grooves formed in the sash, and attached to window frames in accordance with the manufacturers' directions.

Casement windows in all frame and concrete walls shall have sash 1-3/8" thick with bottom rails rebated to open inwards, and a suitable moulded drip set at the lower edge of the bottom rail.

**STORM SASH**

Furnish and fit storm sash 1-3/8" thick to all windows; those to double-hung windows to be rebated as required by blind stops. Storm sash of casement windows in concrete and in frame walls shall be fitted in the outer rabbet of the frame.
Sash shall be divided into lights to match the permanent sash and shall be fitted with ventilator slots and covers.

SCREENS

Furnish and fit in place to all windows throughout the buildings, strongly and neatly constructed fly screens complete in all respects for painters' finish.

Screens shall be factory made of B.C. Fir or pine 1-1/3" thick with stiles and rails dovetailed or tenoned together, and with horizontal mantin bars in line with meeting rails of double-hung windows. Omit bar in casement window screens. Screens to be fitted with 14 x 14 mesh galvanized wire cloth, tightly and evenly stretched and held in place with cover mould on outer edge. Screens to all windows in frame walls to be set between the exterior casings and to finish flush with same; those to windows in the basement walls of the school to be set in place of storm sashes. Attach hooks and eyes as necessary to secure all screens in place.

ENTRANCE PLATFORMS AND STEPS TO ONE CLASSROOM BUILDING

PLATFORM

Construct the entrance platforms to the One Classroom building with 2" x 6" triming joists resting on 6" x 6" posts (anchored to 3" dia. concrete piers) and railing blocks in the concrete wall. Bridging joists to be 2" x 6" set at 12" centres, and notched to ledger at ends. Lay the floor with 1-1/3" x 3-3/4" B.C. Fir or pine flooring to fall 1" away from building, all tightly jointed, blind nailed and smoothed off ready for painters' finish.

STEPS

Form the steps to entrance platforms as shown on elevations, with 2" x 12" cut and mitred carriages and treads out of two 2" x 4"s and a 2" x 5" spaced 1/4" apart with splicing pieces between. Set cove mould under tread nosings returned at ends; risers to be 2-1/4" thick mitred at corners. Steps to have 2" x 12" intermediate carriage resting on 6" x 6" cedar sill at grade level with broken stone and gravel bed beneath 10" deep.

Construct the railings and balustrades as shown with 4" x 4" posts, 2" x 4" rails and 1-1/2" square balusters.

DOORS

All doors shall be of No. 1 Quality B.C. Douglas Fir or White pine of the sizes indicated on plans strongly framed and glued together and of the patterns hereunder described.

All interior doors throughout the first floor to be 1-3/4" thick two panelled or of veneered slab type. Those to basement and to the second floor of teachers quarters to be two panelled struck moulded doors 1-3/8" thick.

Entrance doors to be three panelled 1-3/4" thick with two vertical panels and upper panel glazed as shown with double strength glass set in place with moulded wood beads.

METAL CLAD DOORS

Construct doors to furnace or boiler and fuel room in basement of building of 1" x 3" shiplap, with three 1" x 6" horizontal rails on back. Between horizontal rails cut in
vertical 1" x 5" pieces to reinforce edge of shiplap, and fill panels with shiplap applied diagonally. Trim shiplap to remove tongue or groove at edges of door and where it abuts rails. Fasten the shiplap to rails, and the two thicknesses of shiplap to each other with screws. Cover both sides and all edges of this core with 26 gauge galvanized iron fastened to core in a neat manner without bulges or buckles, and with joints in metal soldered.

**STORM DOORS**

Provide and fit 1-3/8" combination screen and storm doors of approved stock pattern, to the entrances of the Teachers' Residence in the one classroom school.

**INTERIOR WOODWORK, TRIM AND FITTINGS**

**MATERIALS**

All interior finishing woodwork throughout the building including the basement of the building, unless otherwise specified shall be of selected factory grade B.C. Douglas Fir, pine or equivalent grade of spruce, to the approval of the Engineer, and the two kinds shall not be mixed in similar work.

No trim will be required to windows in boiler, furnace or fuel rooms.

Dimensions used in describing trim are nominal only and slight variation in thickness or width of stock materials will be acceptable.

All finishing woodwork in interior trim to be sanded smooth, free from mill marks, with nail heads countersunk and ready for painters' finish.

**CASINGS**

Set 3/4" x 3-1/2" bull nose casing, unless otherwise specified, around all doors and windows, ceiling vents and elsewhere as required in the finished portions of the building.

Inside casings to the entrance doors of the building and to the door and window openings throughout the first storey of the Teachers' Quarters with the exception of the kitchen, are to be 3/4" x 3-1/2" moulded with 1-1/8" x 1-1/4" moulded back bands planted on.

Trim to all door openings to include base blocks of same height as base boards.

**STOOLS**

Set 1-1/16" x 2-3/4" stool with 3/4" x 3-3/4" bull nose apron and 5/8" x 7/8" cove mould under to double-hung windows in frame walls. The stool to double-hung windows in the basement to be 1-1/8" x 5-3/4" ogee moulded with bull nose apron and 5/8" x 7/8" cove mould.

The stool to casement windows in frame walls shall be 1-1/8" thick ogee moulded and tongued into the sills with 3/4" x 3-3/4" bull nose apron and cove mould under.
BASEBOARDS

Baseboards throughout the building shall be 3/4" x 7-3/4" bull nosed.

All baseboards to be accurately fitted and mitred at angles.

Bases to frame partitions in the basement shall be formed with expanded metal lath strips as described under concrete work and shown on detail drawings.

BLACKBOARDS

Provide and install on the school classroom walls where shown, and in accordance with detail drawings, manufactured asbestos slateboard "Black Asbestoslite" or equal, held in place with quarter round mould and casings and provided with chalk rail with apron and cove mould under.

HANGING CLOSET FITTINGS

Set two rows of hook rails out of 1" x 4" material bull nosed, in the school coatrooms, securely screwed to walls, and attach strong cast iron japanned hat and coat hooks set approximately 18" apart in staggered rows.

In the bedroom closets in the Quarters, set similar hook rails on the end walls and a 1-1/4" round hanging rod 5' 2" above the floor, where indicated. Set a 1" shelf 10" wide, 3' above the rods. Attach single cast iron cupboard hooks, bronze finish, 6" apart, to the hook rails.

CUPBOARDS WITH SHELVING

Set up shelving out of 1" material supported on 1" x 3" wall bearers in the storage cupboards where indicated. Shelving in the linen closet in the Two Classroom Teachers' Quarters shall be formed of 1" x 3" battens set 9/32" apart on similar wall bearers. Set up shelving in the closets and storage rooms where shown in the basements of the buildings, strongly supported on 2" x 3" framed bearers to the approval of the Engineer in charge.

STAIRCASES

Construct the staircases from the basement to first and second storeys in accordance with the working drawings, these specifications and detail drawings to be supplied later, following the best stair building practice.

Framing shall be of B.C. Douglas Fir or pine and will include outer intermediate and inner carriages, wall and outer strings, wedges, blocking, etcetera, required for rigid work. Carriages shall be 1-3/4" thick, strings 1-3/8" thick, of depths as shown on details.

Except as otherwise shown or specified, stairs shall be of closed string construction with carriages cut to conform to the rise and run of the steps. Wall and outer strings to be grooved to receive risers, treads and tapered bridges. Outer strings shall have a fascia and moulded cap. String cap will be ploughed to receive 1-3/8" square balusters and shaped filler pieces between balusters.
Balusters, string cap, fascia and filler pieces will be B.C. fir for natural finish or of pine for paint finish, as directed.

Treads, with rounded nosings and cove mould under, tongued and grooved for risers, will be 1-1/4" thick. Risers, tongued and grooved for treads, will be 3/4" thick. Treads and risers will be of first grade hard maple. Blocks 2" x 2" x 6" shall be screwed and glued into place midway between carriages at the junction of treads with risers. Built up newels 4-1/4" square with moulded caps and drops will be of birch. Moulded handrails 2-1/4" x 2-3/4" grooved to receive balusters, and filler pieces will be of birch.

Furnish and set in place to each flight of stairs in the building where stairs are enclosed between partitions one 2" dia. wall handrail supported on metal brackets.

Set up the balustrades to the landings and halls where shown with handrail and balusters to match those of the stairs and half newels set against partitions. Face the staircase well with 3/4" fascia with nosing to match finished floor and cover mould to ceiling joint.

KITCHEN DRESSER

Construct the kitchen dresser in the residence out of 1" material, with cupboards above and below counter, all in accordance with detail drawing. Counter tops to be covered with "Masonite" or equal with metal or plastic nosing. Cupboard member below drawers to be 1-1/8" thick, drawer fronts 7/8" and bottoms 3/8" thick.

Provide and fit 7/8" plywood slab type doors to finish flush with stiles and rails of cupboards.

FINISHED FLOORING

Hardwood flooring shall be graded in accordance with Canadian Hardwood Flooring Manufacturers' grading rules and shall be well seasoned, kiln dried, tongued, grooved and end matched.

All finished flooring throughout the school area, including hallways, landings and coat rooms shall be No. 1 or Factory Grade (second grade below "Clear") hard maple 13/16" x 2".

All finished flooring throughout the Teachers' Quarters shall be No. 1 or second grade (first grade below "Clear") hard maple 9/16" x 1-3/4".

All hardwood flooring shall be laid with close joints on the waterproof paper and sub-floors previously specified and blind nailed as follows: 13/16" flooring to be nailed with 2-1/2" cut flooring nails and 9/16" flooring with 2" flooring nails. No nails to be spaced more than 10" apart.

Provide and fix nosings to staircase landings of the thickness of the finished flooring.

SHOE MOULD

Set a 5/8" x 3/4" maple shoe mould in the angle of finished floors and baseboards where hardwood floors are specified. Moulds to be mitred at angles.
FINISHED FLOORING - ALTERNATIVE

If hardwood flooring is not procurable, the contractor shall so state in his tender and shall supply and lay instead throughout the building in accordance with the above specification, as it applied, No. 1 B.C. edge grain Douglas Fir Flooring.

OUTSIDE TOILETS

Construct outside toilets where directed on the school site for boys and girls in accordance with the working drawings. Each unit to consist of a small frame building resting on cedar sills.

Materials in superstructure shall be as shown on working drawings. Roof shingles and wall siding shall be similar to those used on main building.

No pits to be excavated, but metal receptacles as indicated on the working drawings are to be provided for use under privy seats and in boys' toilet, metal urinal trough.
MISCELLANEOUS, ROUGH AND FINISHING HARDWARE

ROUGH AND MISCELLANEOUS HARDWARE

MATERIAL INCLUDED

The contractor shall supply and install all rough and structural hardware including nails, spikes, bolts, anchors, clean-out doors and frames to all flues, and thimbles for stove pipe connections to flues, etc., which may be required for the complete erection of the building including the following.

COAL CHUTES

Provide and set in basement fuel room wall a coal chute of "Majestic" type or equal, wall opening size about 21" x 27" cast iron and steel with hopper and automatic door opening and locking device, complete with chain control.

CHIMNEY CLEANOUT DOORS

Furnish for setting and building into place, by bricklayer, hinged cleanout doors with frames to all flues in positions and of sizes shown on the working drawings.

CHIMNEY THIMBLES, COLLARS, ETC

Furnish for setting and building into place by bricklayers as required for each flue, thimbles and smoke pipe collars of sizes and in position to suit furnace and smoke pipes.

THRESHOLDS

Provide and set in place to the entrance doorways of the building a grooved bronze threshold size 4-3/4" x 7/8" made by the Chamberlin Metal Weather Strip Co. Ltd., of Kingsville, Ontario, or equal, securely anchored to the cement thresholds.

FINISHING HARDWARE

MATERIAL INCLUDED

Material under this heading shall include all finishing hardware required throughout the building, whether specified or not, which shall be selected to the approval of the Engineer in charge. Finishing hardware does not include spiral sash balances specified under Carpentry and Millwork. They shall be covered by the contract price.

All finishing hardware shall be attached in a neat and careful manner with screws of suitable kind and finish to match hardware.

Upon completion of the contract, a detailed list of finishing hardware supported by receipted invoices for same shall be submitted to the Department. Any portion of the sum named not expended on finishing hardware shall be deducted from the total contract price.

PROVISIONAL AMOUNTS

The contractor shall include in the amount of his tender for Single Classroom School and Residence a sum of
One Hundred and Seventy-five Dollars ($175.00) and for Two Classroom School and Residence a sum of Two Hundred and Seventy Five Dollars ($275.00) to cover the cost of all finishing hardware installed in the respective buildings. Such sum shall include the actual trade cost, of material, plus freight charges, but no allowance is included in these amounts for contractor's percentage.
ROOFING AND FLASHING

ASPHALT ROOFING SHINGLES

Cover all sloping roof surfaces on the asphalt felt previously specified, with twin - or 3-in-1 asphalt strip shingles, weight 210 lbs per square. Shingles to be of red colour laid 4-1/2" to weather and to include all necessary starters and hip and ridge shingles.

FLASHING

All roofs of the buildings shall be flashed wherever required to render same throughly watertight and weatherproof with No. 26 gauge galvanized sheet iron.

The roof valleys shall have 6" metal exposure at the top, extending to 18" at eaves, with 6" extension under the shingles.

Flash with similar metal above all exterior door and window and louvre heads in frame walls, the watertables around the buildings and elsewhere as may be required.

The cover flashing to chimneys shall be stepped and turned into brick course as described under "brickwork" and shall be secured in place with lead wedges. Base flashings shall extend under shingles and be turned up against vertical surfaces at least 6 inches. Step flashings shall lap base flashings 4" and shall lap over the adjoining step flashing a minimum of 2" at vertical joints.

Flash above the entrance door pediments and brackets shown on detail drawings, turned up against walls to lap behind the asbestos siding shingles at least 4".

CAULKING

Horizontal brick joints, into which flashing has been wedged, shall be caulked full with an approved asphalt caulking compound upon completion of the flashing work.

GUARANTEE

The contractor shall furnish a written guarantee that he will make good at his own expense any leaks or other defects in the roofs or flashings throughout the buildings, and any damage caused thereby within a period of one year after acceptance of the buildings by the Department, and no final payment will be made before such document is received.
PAINTING & GLAZING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall cover the furnishing of all materials and equipment and the execution of all priming, painting, staining, varnishing or other finishing work on all exterior and interior wood and metal surfaces, as well as interior concrete and wallboard surfaces as specified herein or as may be necessary for a satisfactory job, throughout the building.

WORKMANSHIP

All work shall be carried out by skilled workmen in accordance with the best practice, and no paint or other finish shall be applied under unfavourable conditions, or to any surface which is damp, dirty, greasy, rough or otherwise imperfect. Each coat of finish must be thoroughly dry before succeeding coats are applied.

All nail holes and joints in finishing woodwork shall be filled with putty, coloured to match finish and sanded smooth. Before applying priming coat, whether at the factory or on the job, all knots and sapwood shall be given a coat of best grade orange shellac. All surfaces shall be finished smooth and even, and shall be free from runs, sags, brush marks, bristles and other defects.

The contractor shall examine all finishing woodwork and other surfaces to receive painters' finish and ensure that it is in proper condition.

MATERIALS

All materials used on the work shall be of first quality standard brands of approved manufacture, delivered to the job in the original sealed containers. They shall be well stirred, thinned where necessary and applied strictly in accordance with manufacturers' directions.

COLOUR SCHEDULES

Schedules of colours for finished paintwork throughout the two buildings will be prepared and furnished by the Department before the paintwork is begun.

EXTERIOR WORK

WOODWORK

All exterior trim and any other exterior wood surfaces exposed to view or to the weather shall be painted three coats of exterior white lead and oil paint. All window sash, storm sash, exterior doors and storm doors shall receive three coats of paint on both sides and all edges.

ENTRANCE PLATFORMS AND STEPS

The entrance platforms and steps thereto in the Single Classroom building shall be primed and painted two coats of best quality gray floor paint.
METAL

First wipe over with vinegar all galvanized iron in flashings, etc., then prime with one coat of red lead paint, and finish with two coats of lead and oil paint of colour to match adjacent work.

Other exterior metal work shall be similarly painted three coats to match adjacent work in colour.

Galvanized wire mesh in fly screens will not be painted.

OUTSIDE TOILETS

The exterior and interior exposed woodwork of the outside toilet buildings shall be given two coats of good quality shingle stain. The colour of the stain will be medium dark brown, except for roof shingles which are to match the red roof shingles on main building.

INTERIOR WORK

SOFTWOOD FINISH

All interior fir pine or spruce trim and millwork throughout the building shall be painted three coats of white lead and oil semi-gloss paint of selected colour, except as hereafter specified. Shiplap partitions in the basement will not be painted.

PAINTING ON FIR

Where paint is applied to B.C. fir, the wood shall be primed with an oil filler of special manufacture to prevent the raising of the grain.

ALTERNATIVE PRICE FOR B.C. FIR - NATURAL FINISH

The contractor shall submit in his tender an alternative price for finishing all B.C. fir trim and millwork for natural grain finish as follows:

1. Well rub in a wood paste filler.
2. Apply a coat of pure white shellac.
3. Apply coat of interior varnish thinned with 10% of turpentine.
4. Apply second full coat of varnish after 24 hours.

BIRCH TRIM

Birch hand rails and newels to staircases to be stained filled to approved colour and varnished two coats.

The first coat of varnish to be thinned with best quality turpentine and at least twelve hours must elapse before second coat of varnish is applied.

FINISHED FLOORS AND HARDWOOD STAIRS

All finished floors, including stair landings, and all stair treads and risers are to be finished with three coats
of best quality floor varnish. The first coat of varnish to be thinned with turpentine, and succeeding coats applied twelve hours apart in full consistency from the container.

WALLBOARD SURFACES

All gypsum wallboard surfaces throughout the building shall be examined to ensure completely filled joints, and secure fastening before finish is applied.

All such surfaces to be first coated with a sealing primer manufactured for the purpose applied in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions; and finished with two coats of semi-gloss paint of selected colour.

CIMENT SURFACES

Cement wall and floor surfaces throughout the basement excepting only in furnace (or boiler) fuel and store rooms shall be finished as follows:

(a) Walls.

Carefully examine all cement finished wall surfaces, and remove all traces of oil, grease, dirt, or other foreign matter, then apply one coat, well brushed on of a concrete hardener as supplied by leading paint manufacturers, as it comes from the container.

When hardener is set and dry, apply a second coat, 50% of which shall be an approved sealer primer and 50% concrete paint of colour selected for finish coat.

Allow 24 hours for drying and apply a final coat of concrete paint of selected colour as it comes from the container.

(b) Floors.

Remove all grease, oil, dirt, efflorescence and other foreign substances from floors and when perfectly dry apply one coat of concrete hardener, well brushed in.

When hardener is set and dry, apply one coat of cement and concrete sealer as it comes from the container and allow 24 hours for drying, after which apply two coats of concrete floor paint in accordance with the manufacturer's directions.
GLAZING

WINDOWS & DOORS

All sash for double hung and casement windows, as well as glazed doors, shall be glazed with 24 oz. sheet glass.

STORM WINDOWS AND STORM DOORS

Storm sash and lights in storm doors also shall be glazed with 24 oz. sheet glass.

Glass shall be free of waves, bubbles or other imperfections and shall be cut with straight edges of full size required by the openings.

All glass in windows shall be bedded in putty, sprigged and finished with putty, coloured to match printwork.

All glass in glazed doors shall be sprigged and held in place with wood bushes or moulds. The glass in exterior doors to be back putted.

Priming of sash and frames may be carried out at the mill, and the contractor may arrange to have all or any part of the glazing also completed at the mill.

Previous to priming sash and frames, the Engineer in charge shall be notified so that inspection may be arranged.

PROTECTION AND CLEANING

During construction the contractor shall protect all glass from damage, repairing at his own expense all breakages from any cause. He shall clean all glass before the buildings are accepted. He shall also prevent the accumulation of painters' materials and rubbish in the buildings and arrange for storage of his materials elsewhere to prevent as far as possible a fire hazard from such cause.

COMPLETION

When painting and glazing work has been completed, the contractor shall clean all spots from finished surfaces, refinish any rubbed or damaged work, whether it be caused by himself or others. He shall touch up where work of other trades require, and leave the buildings in a clean and orderly condition.

FOR

WITH TEACHER'S QUARTERS

1. All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this Trade.

2. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying heating drawing are intended to provide for a complete system of Gravity Warm Air heating in the building. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

3. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention given to the grading of all warm air leaders, and making connections. All connections shall be made to provide free and unobstructed flow and shall be made as tight as possible and in a manner consistent with the best practice.

5. WARM AIR FURNACE

Furnish and set up complete in the basement, where shown on plan, one first grade furnace as described on drawing, having a rated output equivalent to that called for on the plan. The furnace shall have a double casing; and shall be equipped with manually operated chain, controlled draft and check dampers, water pan and a complete set of firing tools.

6. SMOKE PIPE

Provide and install galvanized iron smoke pipe of a gauge and diameter called for on plan. This smoke pipe shall have a close fitting manually operated key damper in horizontal run.
Provide suitable collar at a point where smoke pipe enters chimney.

7. **LEADERS**

Provide and install circular warm air leaders of sizes noted on plan, made up of bright tin or 26 gauge galvanized iron, with locked seams. Joints shall be lapped not less than 1/2" and shall be beaded and soldered to make tight connections. All leaders shall be carefully connected to furnace cones, register boxes and wall stocks, with all necessary elbows, twistors, boots, transformer sections, etc., as may be required to provide a complete job. Leaders shall be supported from joists and shall be installed with a rise of not less than one inch per linear foot.

All leaders, except as noted on plan, shall be provided with dampers located not more than 2'-0" from furnace cone.

Where leaders are run within 1" of any woodwork, the woodwork in the immediate vicinity shall be protected with sheet asbestos wall board.

Where leaders pass through partitions, galvanized iron flanged sleeves shall be provided, the flanges having diameters sufficient to cover opening in partition. The sleeves shall be made of No. 24 gauge galvanized iron.

8. **STACKS**

All warm air stacks shall be made up of bright tin or No. 26 gauge galvanized iron, and shall be of sizes as noted on drawing.

9. **RETURN AIR DUCTS AND LEADERS**

From the cold air register faces located where shown on plan, provide and connect up return air ducts of sizes and gauges noted on plan. These return air ducts shall be fastened directly to the undersides of the joists and run to the furnace room where round return air leaders shall be connected thereto from to cold air shoes, typically as shown on large scale section. Care shall be taken to make all joints as tight as possible, and all panels shall be cross broken to provide rigidity.

10. **ELBOWS**

All elbows shall be not less than 3 piece style, and all shall be adjustable. Care shall be taken to obtain tight connections between elbows and leaders.

11. **REGISTERS AND FACES**

Supply and install baseboard and floor registers where shown of sizes noted on plan. Supply registers shall be provided with movable louvres and suitable for connection to register boxes.

Return air faces shall be cast with bronze finish or hardwood. Wall faces adjacent to stair well or first floor shall be steel with bronze finish of sizes as shown.
12. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

13. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Engineer. Blueprints for this purpose shall be furnished by the Department.

14. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense as soon as possible after being notified that such defect has appeared.

15. HEATING SCHEDULE OF SIZES

Equipment listed under condition table "C" on sheet No. H-1 index No. 837 of the blue prints should be provided for this school.

Re; Day Schools, Michel and Stony Plain Reserves.

I regret to advise that I am experiencing considerable difficulty with the water wells at these two schools.

Mr. Lutz, the man mentioned in my letter of July 9th, found that he was unable to hire the man to do the work with his outfit and backed out of the job. I then located a Mr. Jas. Briede, who had bored wells for us on Wabamun Reserve on several occasions and he agreed to bore both wells. He started in on the Michel Reserve well and after getting down about 40 feet ran into a sand formation which he was unable to handle with his machine and has abandoned the job. He will not expect any pay for the work done.

Yesterday, I located a Mr. Philip Sharest, at Beaumont, Alta., an experienced well man, and he is of the opinion that he can handle the sand without difficulty. His charges, however, are $2.50 per foot for the 3 ft. hole, being 50¢s per foot higher than the former price. He is working at present on a well at a school in the Cooking Lake District but will be able to start on a well at Michel on Friday or Saturday of this week and do Stony Plain Reserve next week.

There are wells on adjoining quarters on the East, North and West of the present school site, and I would recommend that another attempt be made to secure water on this location.

If it is decided to change the site, I would recommend a site one half mile directly East of the present site. This is a good level site but is cultivated land and it would be
necessary to purchase the improvements and pay for the crop now on it, possibly around $100.00. This site would be only about 200 yards from the residence of Sol. T. Callihoo, who has a good well at his house, 38 feet deep.

Unless I hear from you to the contrary, I will have Mr. Sharest go ahead with another well on the present site at the earliest date he can make it as the cement should be received any day now and the contractors will be ready to make a start.

With further reference to my wire of August 19th, requesting five more copies of plans and specifications, would advise that the Contractors state the one set of plans sent do not comply with the specifications, the plans evidently being for a school being built in Quebec and showing some differences, particularly in shingles and siding.

E.A. Robertson,

(m) The singular number, where used herein, shall include the plural and vice versa and reference to persons shall include corporations and vice versa.

2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS

This contract shall enure to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

4. TIME

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

5. CHANGES IN THE WORK

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issued additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor on the work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS:

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of the contract and as to the meaning or intention of the contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specifications shall be final, and no work under the contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES

Referring to your letter of Sept. 25th, in connection with new day schools at Michel and Stony Plain Reserves.

It has not been necessary to change the site of the Michel school. The well at the original site was completed yesterday and the well borer was successful in getting a three foot hole down 54 feet, 3 feet into the gravel where a good supply of water is found in this district. This should provide sufficient water supply for Michel school for the life of the casing.

We have also been successful in securing water at the Stony Plain Reserve site. This well hit the water bearing quicksand at 45 feet and is three feet into the strata, giving about four feet of water in the three foot hole. We have found that the quicksand wells will eventually fill in with sand but in the meantime it should provide sufficient water for a few years.

The cement work for the basement of the Stony Plain school has now been completed and the contractors are at present working on the basement for the Michel School in an endeavor to finish all the cement work before the cold weather sets in.

The road in to the Stony Plain school, approximately 200 yards, has also been put through but will require a little more grading when the bulldozer is finishing up the levelling of the site.

EXCAVATION, DRAINAGE, BACKFILL AND GRADING

WORK INCLUDED

The work under this heading shall include all excavation for basement, piers, footings, foundations, catch basin, tile drainage lines, and backfilling for same.

It shall also include cutting away existing banks, prominences etc., to produce graded and terraced areas in the vicinity of the building as required, and fill to produce levels called for on the drawings where finished grade levels are to be higher than existing levels.

It shall further include replacement of top soil as specified herein after grading to lines and levels as shown on the working drawings or as may be directed by the Engineer, has been carried out.

TOP SOIL

From the area around the building, which is to be graded, remove top soil to a depth of 6" and deposit where and as directed by the Engineer.

EXCAVATION

Excavation for all purposes shall conform to the shapes and shall be carried to the levels shown on the working drawings. The sides of all excavations for building shall be sufficiently clear of the outside face of basement or foundation walls to permit erection and stripping of forms and the application of waterproofing, and the laying of weeping tile drains.

Other footing excavations may be cut the neat sizes of the footings where soil conditions permit; otherwise the excavation shall be large enough to accommodate the necessary forms.

All footings and foundations shall rest on solid undisturbed soil beds, which shall be at approximately true levels.

Where excavations for walls, piers of footings have been carried, by accident or design, to greater depths than intended, they shall be filled to the required level with concrete, as specified under Concrete Work.

All excavations shall be protected from damage by frost, accident or other cause, and shall be kept dry and free from refuse.

The contractor shall keep all excavations and basements free of water from any source whatsoever, and shall supply all pumps and labour required for the purpose.

All excavated material not required for backfill or for grading shall be moved to another portion of the site, as directed by the Engineer.

ROCK EXCAVATION

Any rock encountered in excavating shall be removed by drilling and wedging as far as possible. If blasting must be resorted to, it shall be done by experienced men, and all precautions shall be taken to ensure the safety of all persons, and to prevent damage to property.

All rough, sloping, loose or soft rock in the bottom of excavations shall be cut away leaving solid beds, and all rock projections at sides of any excavation shall be cut away so that clear space equal to other excavating previously specified is available.
Loose large boulders, which are visible or which may be encountered in excavating, are to be removed by the most convenient method either from the site or to other positions therein, as directed by the Engineer.

**Shoring**

Supply and place all shoring that may be required to shore up and securely hold all banks or sides of excavations, maintain and finally dismantle and remove it when work is completed.

**Backfilling at Buildings**

After waterproofing has been completed in accordance with the water-proofing specification and when so directed by the Engineer, fill in against the outside face of the basement walls of the building with at least 6" of broken stone carefully placed and compacted so that weepers will not be disturbed or damaged. Over the broken stone, and to within 6" of finished grade, fill with well compacted soil. This fill to be well tamped, moistened and consolidated in layers to prevent settlement.

Backfill where necessary in basement around piers, footings and underfloor drainage lines, with excavated material as required to form level bed. Fill to be thoroughly tamped and consolidated to prevent settlement. To the top of footings over this bed spread broken stone as shown on working drawings to form base for concrete floor slab. Stone to be carefully placed and compacted to avoid injury to under-floor drainage lines.

**Drainage**

Trenches

Trenches for drainage lines from building as specified for the accommodation of vitrified tile piping shall provide gradients as indicated on drainage details or specified under Plumbing and Drainage. Trenches shall be wide enough to permit workmen to operate.

**Weeping Tile**

Lay a drain of 4" agricultural weeping tile completely around basement foundation walls at proper gradients from bottom of footings as shown on drawings and if the site requires it, upon instructions of the Engineer, run branch lines 6' O.C. long running through footings or walls and under basement floor slab where indicated. Where each of these branches passes through footings or walls it shall consist of a section of 4" cast iron pipe of the same length as the width of footing or wall. Care shall be taken that concrete is thoroughly tamped around this cast iron pipe.

Weeping tile shall be laid with 1/2" open joints protected with tar paper strips 6" wide and then covered with not less than 12" of broken stone and gravel, before backfill is placed.

**Connect Drains to Catch Basin**

Carry all tile drains from foundation footings and basement floor drains and connect to catch basin (See Concrete Specification) in position shown or where directed by the Engineer.
VITRIFIED TILE

Lay an effluent drain of 6" vitrified salt glazed earthenware pipe from catch basin to discharge by gravity flow above grade. If the extent of this drain is not indicated, the contractor shall include in his tender price an amount for installing same to any point selected by the Engineer, within 100' O" of the building.

Lay 4" similar tile drain, or drains if shown, from catch basin to the proper positions at basement footings and connect same to cast iron basement floor drains.

During laying, each section of vitrified tile shell be solidly supported above bottom of trench and socket-jointed with cement mortar. After jointing, solid beds of soil shall be well packed under pipes.

IRON DRAINS

Run a 4" cast iron pipe drain, or drains if shown, under basement floor from floor drains and any plumbing fixtures to outside of foundation walls under footings and connect to the vitrified tile drains, specified above, running to catch basin.

Provide and install all required Ys, bends, etc., and a C.I. trap and floor strainer to each basement floor outlet.

BACK FILLING

Back filling over all tile and iron drains shall be carefully executed with approved material in a manner to avoid disturbing pipes.

GRADING

Upon completion of the buildings carefully clean up all debris, material, rubbish, etc., from the areas disturbed by building operations and grade up for a distance of 12 feet around the buildings to levels and lines shown on the various working drawings to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Where terracing is required, the fill is to be thoroughly rammed and consolidated to prevent settlement.

When all grading has been completed, all graded surfaces and areas are to be covered with topsoil previously removed.
CONCRETE WORK

The work under this heading shall cover all concrete work required in the execution and completion of the concrete in the building and shall include:

(a) All labour, material and equipment required in mixing and placing concrete in footings, foundation walls, piers, floor slabs, catch basin etc., wherever shown on the drawings or hereafter specified.

(b) The supply and placing of all bolts, dowels, anchors, pipes, sleeves and miscellaneous ironware wherever required in concrete work.

(c) The furnishing and placing of reinforcing rods in basement walls and of wire mesh in basement floor slab.

(d) The finish of all cement floors.

(e) The forming, making and installation of precast lintels, and thresholds.

(f) The patching of air holes and rubbing down all irregularities in exposed concrete.

EXTRA WORK
