The audit of the final Progress Claim, No. 5, in connection with the above contract has been completed by the undersigned at the Contractors' office in Edmonton, and in conjunction with records and information furnished by the Superintendent of the Edmonton Agency, Mr. E.A. Robertson, and the report thereon follows:

Labor and Labor Charges: $975.07

This amount represents the balance of payrolls and related charges to the completion of the school, and brings the total labor costs for the project to $6,934.17.

The payrolls submitted have been examined in detail and calculations have been found correct. Transfers from original time cards to the paysheets were also found in order.

The scale of wages paid by the Contractor was in accordance with rates that have been approved and set out in the Agreement. The rates observed were on the basis of an 8 hour day, 44 hour week with time and a half for overtime and double time for holiday work. Travelling time was paid at the regular rate and was not taken into account in the accumulation of overtime.

In compliance with an agreement reached between the Edmonton Builders' Exchange and the United Brotherhood of Carpenters & Joiners of America which became effective on April 1, 1949, the following rates were paid by the Contractors after that date:

(Cont'd Page 2)
Carpenter foreman - $1.50 per hour
Carpenter - 1.40 per hour
Laborers - .90 per hour
Superintendent - 2.00 per hour, based on a fixed salary of $80.00 per week for 40 hour week, with approval of the Edmonton Agency Superintendent.

Indian labor has been paid at 75¢ per hour, with approval of the Indian Superintendent.

An overpayment of $3.15 to J.D. Taylor on Payroll #43, Progress Claim #8 has been adjusted in the present claim by a credit voucher for $.42 which also takes other payroll charges into account.

Holiday Pay - $23.26

Discrepancies in the calculation of Holiday Pay in claims #1 to 4 inclusive have been adjusted in this claim by a credit voucher for $.12. The balance of $23.26 claimed in this application has been found correct and in order.

Holiday Pay Books have been examined and proof of payment has been established.

Holiday Pay has been taken into account in the computation of other Payroll charges.

Workmen's Compensation - $21.98

The Contractor has been assessed at the rate of 4% of estimated gross payrolls for the years 1947 and 1948 by the Workmen's Compensation Board of Alberta.

The amount of $21.98 presently claimed is a correct balance of the charges paid by the Contractor to cover employees on this contract, after taking into account a rebate of $21.79 on 1947 payments in connection with employees whose earnings exceeded the maximum assessable amount of $2000.00.

A further examination of the Contractor's records will be made as soon as returns for 1948 have been completed in order to secure any credit that may accrue on 1948 W.C.B. rebates.

The Poole Construction Co. have obtained the necessary clearance from the Alberta W.C. Board in respect to this contract.
Public Liability & Property Damage - $2.10

The Contractor is sufficiently covered against the above risks and has remained in good standing throughout the contract by prompt payment of premiums which were based on .51% of the estimated gross payroll for 1947 and .228% for 1948.

The calculations have been reviewed on all claims submitted and the above charge of $2.10 has been found reasonably accurate.

Unemployment Insurance - $3.86

This amount represents the employer's portion of contributions paid on behalf of employees on the project who were insurable. The Contractor has produced the Unemployment Insurance Books for examination and appears to have complied with the Act.

Income Tax -

In compliance with Income Tax Regulations, the Contractor has made deductions from taxable employees and remitted same to the Receiver General regularly.

Materials - $273.48

Invoices for materials purchased or supplied from the Contractor's stock have been compared with Purchase Orders and requisitions as well as checked for calculations and extensions. Although Delivery slips were not available to prove delivery, of materials, the Indian Superintendent has been able to certify that the materials charged were actually received and used on the project.

Materials transferred and divided between the Michel and Stony Plain schools have been checked closely and found reasonably well accounted for.

Small Tools -

The small tools that have been charged to the project have been recorded in a joint inventory for both schools. In view of the small amount involved, the adjustment for items retained by the Contractor, which amount to $24.97 has been credited entirely on Claim #8 of the Stony Plain contract.

Fire Insurance -

An Insurance Policy with the Aetna Insurance Company for $11,000.00 on the school while under construction has expired and on advice from the Indian Superintendent was not renewed by the Contractor.
Travelling Expenses - $30.00

This amount has been paid to Company employees for providing transportation to the men in their personal cars. The round trip covered some 36 miles and the rate of $2.00 per trip which has been charged, appears fair and reasonable.

Sub-Contracts

Millwork - W.H. Clark Lumber Co.

All invoices for millwork supplied by this subcontractor were included in previous claims 1 to 4. These amounted to $1,594.96 to the completion of the school, although they have not all been listed under sub-contracts. This amount compares favorably with the Company's approved tender for $1,829.00.

The details of transfer voucher #1439 on claim #4 for $51.59 covering millwork supplied by this Company, have been checked and the adjustments listed found in order as the following invoices disclosed:

The first item for $19.40 was to adjust Invoice #12096 for $38.80 which was charged to the Stony Plain school on claim #5, whereas one half was applicable to the Michel School.

The second item for $29.70 was to adjust Invoice #10544 for $59.40 which was also charged entirely to Stony Plain on claim #5, whereas one half applied to the Michel school.

The third item for $52.79 represents Invoice #90 for the same amount which was charged to Stony Plain on claim #4 whereas it pertained to the Michel School.

The fourth item for $80.30 represents one half of Invoice #10544 for $100.60 which was charged entirely to Michel whereas one half applied to Stony Plain.

All millwork and other materials supplied by the W.H. Clark Lumber Co. and included in the invoices submitted, have been paid in full by the prime contractor.

Painting & Decorating - $262.50 - Jack Mason.

This amount represents the balance of the account for the painting and decorating performed by Jack Mason at the agreed price of $1,050.00 which has been paid in full by the Prime Contractor.

Electrical - Al's Electric - Edmonton, Alberta.

The supply and installation of electrical wiring and fixtures in the school and living quarters have been completed by the above at a total cost of $490.40, which amount is within the estimated price of $510.00, approved by the Indian Affairs Branch.
All charges have been submitted in claims 1 to 4 inclusive and have been paid in full by the prime contractor.

This sub-contractor, although requested to do so, has not furnished a Statutory Declaration. As the owner has performed the work himself, the Contractor, having a sufficient hold back on other projects, is not alarmed over any liability that might arise and feels that the claim need not be held up any longer.

Plumbing - Dow & Scott, Ltd.

The above firm has supplied and installed the plumbing material and fixtures required at a total cost of $151.05 including $10.00 for labor. This account has been submitted in claims 1 - 4 and has been fully paid by the prime contractor.

Heating - $683.50 - Freeze & Maxwell Co., Ltd.

The prime contractor was not able to secure competitive bids for the completion of this portion of the work, and consequently had to have the work completed at current market rates.

The firm of Freeze & Maxwell who agreed to perform the work on this basis have submitted the balance of their charges amounting to $683.50. This amount, in addition to $404.66 submitted in Claims 1 - 4 inclusive, brings the total charges for this sub-contract to $1,088.46, distributed as follows:

Thus the total labor charge has cost the sub-contractor a total of $475.46 for both schools or $2,377.73 for each as compared with $356.61 actually charged for each. According to information obtained from the prime contractor (Poole Construction) and the Indian Superintendent, there was no alternative but to award the sub-contract to a firm that would agree to do the work at their regular rates, which the above firm has done in this case.

The Indian Superintendent has further confirmed that temporary buildings erected and used by the contractor were converted into latrines at the termination of the contract.

Report on the Michel Indian School. Nov.10, 1948.

This is a new one-room school with living quarters for the teacher as part of the building. The building is of modern construction with a basement playroom and an additional storeroom in which is installed a Delco light plant. This room was not closed, but was accessible from the playroom. The volume of the furnace is quite ample to heat the building. The inside measurements of the classroom are 28 feet by 22 feet. There is no provision for a work room.

The toilets are substantial outdoor buildings.

The school does not meet the specifications of the School Building Branch, Department of Education, Alberta, in the following respects-

(1) The hot air registers are in the floor.
(2) Window lighting is not ample in comparison to floor space.

It is possible that the installation of the Delco plant may not meet the regulations on the Alberta Fire Commissioner. It should not be left accessible to the children under any circumstances.

The levelling of the playground, and the installation of playground equipment is herein recommended as a project in the near future.

The building as at present constructed makes no provision for any work other than academic.

Respectfully submitted,

Inspector of Schools.

Re: Michel Indian Day School.

Referring to your letter of March 26th in regard to Inspector Scott's report on the Delco Plant at Michel School.

As requested I am enclosing sketch of the basement showing location of the plant and pump.

There is no reason whatever for the pupils to be in either of these rooms and the teacher has been warned on several occasions to keep the doors closed and see that the children cannot get near them. The pump at this school is not in use at present as the pipes between the well and the school have frozen, and they are getting the water with a pail and rope over a pulley. I think the freezing was due to the fact that the pipes were laid too late in the fall and the ground in the trench had no time to properly settle. The pipes are down six feet at the school and eight feet at the well which should be well below the frost line.

The Stony Plain School has no Delco Plant. They are on Calgary Power. Sketch showing location of their pump is also enclosed.

Ottawa, July 16th, 1947.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Stony Plain Indian Day School,
Michel Indian Day School.

Inspector Gooderham strongly advises the immediate construction of a new combined day school with teacher's residence at each of the above mentioned points.

Indian Agent Robertson and Mr. Gooderham were forwarded plans and specifications of the building required; these were prepared by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

We are now advised that the Poole Construction Company, Edmonton, is prepared to construct these buildings on a basis of cost plus ten per-cent. They estimate the total cost of each building at $11,500. Agent Robertson states that this is a very reliable firm.

I enclose Memorandum to Council for each of the above. This memorandum is prepared along the same lines as the one prepared for the construction of the day school, teacher's residence and agency residence on the Fisher River Reserve.

Acting Director.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 31 July 1947.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 16th July, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to Construct a combined one room Indian Day School and Teachers residence on the Stony Plain Reserve, Edmonton Indian Agency in the Province of Alberta;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Stony Plain Reserve and living quarters for the Indian day school teacher:

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C.1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

That efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the City of Edmonton and local towns near the said Reserve but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building contractor, namely the Poole Construction Company, Edmonton, whom our affaires state are a very reliable firm, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately, on the basis of cost plus ten per-cent;

That it is considered that the construction of this building is a pressing emergency and within the exemption provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources advise that authority be granted for entry into a contract with The Poole Construction Company as aforesaid.

A.D.P. HEENEY,

COMPETENT FOREMAN: The Contractor shall give efficient supervision to the work and shall keep at all times a competent foreman on the works, who shall represent him in his absence.

TEMPORARY BUILDINGS: The Contractor shall erect at his own expense the temporary buildings or workshop that may be required for the workmen or for the proper storage and protection of materials against damage and weather. He shall also provide an earth closet or other temporary privy as may be required for the use of the workmen, and maintain same in a clean and sanitary condition.

INSURANCE: The Contractor shall maintain and pay for fire insurance on the building in a reputable Fire Insurance Company for an amount equal to not less than eighty per cent (80%) of the value of the work done and material delivered on the site; any loss sustained by fire to be payable to the Department and the Contractor as their joint interests may be determined.

The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims by the Workmen's Compensation Act and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under this contract.

EQUIPMENT: The Contractor is to furnish all transportation, labour, scaffolding, tools, derricks, ladders, moulds, patterns and all forms and materials or substances whatever in connection with the same to the full extent found necessary or requisite in the opinion of the Engineer for the due and proper execution and completion of all works embraced in this contract. It shall be in the power of the Engineer to order off the premises any equipment, etc., which may be found defective, unfit or otherwise unsuitable for the proper execution of the works and the Contractor shall replace the same by a suitable and approved class of equipment, etc. Upon completion of the works, the plant shall be promptly removed from the site of the work.

CANADIAN MANUFACTURE: All material used in the erection of the building shall, as far as possible, be produced or manufactured in Canada.

DEFECTIVE MATERIAL OR WORK: No defective material, worked or otherwise considered by the Engineer to be defective, shall be used in the works. Should the Engineer consider any work performed or executed to be imperfectly or insufficiently done or consider that any work thought of good workmanship has been executed with defective material then the Engineer may order the Contractor to remove same and rebuild or re-execute to his satisfaction, the work or materials or both, so condemned.
If the contractor fails to comply with such orders within a stipulated time, the engineer may have executed the orders so given to the contractor, and retain all costs, expenses for same, from any amounts that may be due to the contractor.

INSUFFICIENT WORKMEN: If the engineer, at any time, considers the number of workmen, horses, machinery and equipment or its quantity of materials, provided for the work are insufficient for the proper progress of the work or an expert thereof, then the engineer may by written notice order the contractor to employ provide within a stipulated period such additional workmen, horses, equipment or materials etc as may be necessary to increase the speed of the works to the engineer's satisfaction. In the event that the contractor shall not supply all necessary workmen, horses, equipment and materials etc., as ordered by the engineer within such stipulated period then the engineer may, at his discretion, order any such additional workmen, horses, equipment or materials etc., as he deems necessary, for the proper progress of the works and charge all costs to the contractor and retain any sums, expenses, from any amounts that may be due to the contractor. The workmen, horses or equipment so provided may be subject to discharge by the contractor, but only with the consent of the engineer.

SETTING OUT OF WORK: The setting out of work shall rest solely with the Contractor who will be responsible for the same and if any discrepancies should be found he will have to alter and make good the same at his own expense.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR WORK: The Contractor will be held absolutely responsible for the work from the commencement of same to its completion. He shall provide, erect, and maintain all necessary guards, rails, fences, night lights, etc. All possible care must be taken to protect the works against accident or injury from fire, design, elements, or other causes, as the entire work is at the Contractor's risk who will be held responsible for all accidents or injury that may happen to the work or to individuals or property until the building is formally taken over by the Department. The Contractor shall take particular care of all finished work which shall be thoroughly protected from injury. Should any damage arise from any cause the same shall be made good by the Contractor to the satisfaction of the Minister.

ACCOUNTABILITY: The Contractor will be required to make good for any damage caused by overloading any construction. No load is to be placed on concrete work nor shall it be subject to blows or other strains until it has obtained its permanent set.

The Department will not be held accountable for anything injured from any cause whatsoever, incorrect, stolen or lost.

FROZEN WEATHER: During freezing weather all ingredients for concrete, cement, mortar and plaster shall be heated, before using, to a temperature of at least 40 degrees Fahrenheit. Concrete and cement finish shall be protected by adequate covering until the initial set is attained. Registers shall be installed and connected with the heating system as soon as practicable and until this is in operation such other methods as are necessary shall be adopted for complete protection of the works.

The Contractor will be required to make good any damage by frost to materials on the site or to work in which.

ARCHITECTURAL SERVICE ADDRESS

The contractor shall address all communications, data and record plans etc., as called for under the various trade specifications, as the contract work proceeds to the:

Chief Engineer,
Architectural and Construction Services,
Survey and Engineering Branch,
